text: PERSON GPE hasn't had a player drafted since 2002, and none of the six Hornets selected have been taken before the 24th round. That will change this June, when PERSON's defensive prowess should make him a second-day pick in a Draft light on legitimate shortstops.The 2014 LOCATION Conference player of the year, PERSON has all the tools to play shortstop in the big leagues. He has smooth actions, quick hands and a strong, accurate arm. Though his pure speed doesn't grade as better than average, he still offers plenty of range at shortstop.The PERSON Rican-born PERSON stands out much more in the field at the plate. He's a switch-hitter who's better as a right-hander, though he'll need to tone down his approach to hit for a decent average. He won't provide much power and probably will fit toward the bottom of a lineup.

Taken in the middle of the first round as perhaps the most advanced college bat in the 2016 Draft class, GPE was believed to be the type of hitter who could move quickly through the system. That was especially true since he was immediately moved from behind the plate, where he played at the ORGANIZATION of GPE, to first base. He did make his way to Double-A in his first full season and capped things off with a stint in the ORGANIZATION League.GPE utilizes an advanced approach at the plate to see a lot of pitches and draw walks, leading to a system-best 77 free passes in his first full season and a .375 on-base percentage. That, combined with a contact-oriented philosophy, should allow him to hit for a high average, and it was encouraging that he performed better in that category after his move up to Double-A in 2017. There are concerns that GPE won't have the power to fit the first base profile, but there is more pop for him to tap into and he sees value in knocking out 30 doubles annually while trying to get on base at a 40 percent clip, a pace he was keeping up in GPE has continued to work on his defense at his new position, something he prioritized in 2017, and he should be capable there. With some depth at first and ORGANIZATION, the Angels can give GPE time to develop on both sides of the ball.

The ORGANIZATION landed PERSON during their international bonus-pool-shattering spending spree in 2016, signing the then-20-year-old GPE righty for $3 million in December. He's done nothing but impress since joining the organization, showing a combination of physicality and stuff that enabled him to quickly jump to Class A Fort Wayne early in his first stateside campaign. Listed at 6-foot-8, 220 pounds, PERSON is a large and imposing presence on the mound who operates from a three-quarters slot. That size translates to premium velocity, as he'll consistently sit in the mid-to-upper 90s and flirt with triple digits, all while working on a steep downhill plane to both sides of the plate. PERSON has a hard slider that pairs nicely with his heater, flashing above-average potential with two-plane action, and he's impressed scouts with his feel for a changeup early in his career.Given PERSON's sheer size, learning to consistently repeat his delivery will be key in his development as a starter. If he can learn to do so while also refining his secondaries and command, the big right-hander could become a mid-rotation starter, if not more. At the least, PERSON's robust fastball and promising secondaries point to a bright future at the back end of a big league bullpen.

PERSON hit for power all three years of college, even while pitching part time as a freshman and sophomore. He has some of the most explosive raw thump in the entire class, and will hit balls 10 rows into the bleachers even when he doesn't get fully extended. He has some moderate swing-and-miss issues characteristic of hitters who have power-driven approaches, but he's also willing to take a walk. His is a traditional right field profile, and he's in the mix with late first, early second round college power bats.

Hyper-sculpted, switch-hitting athlete who could fit at a number of defensive positions. PERSON plus tools across the board, including power from both sides of the plate. PERSON largely been seen in workouts and not against live, high-quality pitching, so we don't know much about his feel to hit but the elements are there. There's perhaps some PERSON here, and PERSON is physically mature, but we don't know of another 16-year-old on the planet with tools this loud and struggle to think of a historic example.

The summer before his junior year at ORGANIZATION, PERSON had a strong Cape Cod League showing. That carried over to the spring when he emerged as one of the best all-around college hitters in the GPE. Ranked No. 7 among GPE prospects by ORGANIZATION, PERSON was taken No. 3 overall by the ORGANIZATION, as they believed him to be the best pure hitter in the GPE. He was having a relatively pedestrian pro debut last summer that was interrupted by a shin contusion caused by a pitch.PERSON has the potential to hit for average as well as power at the highest level. He has strength and excellent bat speed to go along with excellent strike zone control. As a result, he can draw walks and doesn't strike out much, especially for someone who can generate plus raw power. The ORGANIZATION are excited to have him work with new hitting coordinator PERSON and implement their more advanced program in 2019. While PERSON has worked on his defense at third, the jury is still out about whether he will be able to stay there. He did do a lot of agility and flexibility type of work during instructional league play after last season.The ORGANIZATION are committed to him sticking at the hot corner and have been pleased to see him forge a strong bond with shortstop prospect PERSON on and off the field. That could be the left side of the ORGANIZATION infield at some point in the future.

PERSON doesn't have the size (5-foot-10, 165 pounds), PERSON pedigree (22nd round) or radar-gun readings to stand out as a top prospect. But while he doesn't have a high ceiling, he does have a track record of success in college and pro ball. More of an infielder at ORGANIZATION (GPE) JC, he set single-season (19) and career (27) saves records at ORGANIZATION and recorded a 1.37 ERA in his first two years as a pro before the ORGANIZATION traded him to the ORGANIZATION for PERSON in November.Though PERSON's fastball tops out around 93 mph, it's effective because it features good life and he can locate it on both sides of the plate and down in the strike zone. He has shown the ability to get swings and misses with his curveball (his best offering), slider and changeup, though he'll have to prove that he can continue to do so against more advanced hitters.PERSON adds to his deception by varying his arm slot, and thus far he has confounded left-handed and right-handed hitters alike. His upside is probably no more than a middle reliever, but with his control and mound presence he has a good chance of reaching it.

Because PERSON stood 5-foot-5 and weighed 150 pounds midway through his junior year at GPE (N.C.) High, he wasn't a high priority for the 2017 GPE. But that has changed as he grown six inches, added 20 pounds and emerged as one of the fastest runners available. High-level decision-makers poured into GPE to see him throughout the spring and while he generates some mixed opinions, he might not last past the second round.PERSON famously clocked a 3.85 home-to-first time from the left side of the plate in front of several scouts in mid-April and gets running grades from 70 to 80 on the 20-80 scouting scale. Speed is far from his only intriguing tool, as he's a switch-hitter with surprising bat speed and deceptive wiry strength and also possesses a strong arm.There are some questions with PERSON. The ORGANIZATION commit doesn't always play with a lot of energy and some scouts wonder if he has the hands to stick in the infield, though the worst-case scenario is that he'd still be a valuable defender in center field. He'll be 19 years and three months old on GPE day, making him one of the older players in the 2017 crop.

PERSON ORGANIZATION, an ORGANIZATION II program, produced its first three big leaguers all from its 2009 Draft crop: Mike Fiers, J.D. PERSON and PERSON. The ORGANIZATION may have a fourth on the way in GPE, who signed for $60,000 as an 11th-rounder in 2013 and topped the low Class A GPE ORGANIZATION in slugging (.542) and ORGANIZATION (.933) in his first full pro season. Following the 2015 season, PERSON was one of four prospects traded to the ORGANIZATION in exchange for PERSON Kimbrel.GPE has extraordinary hand-eye coordination and controls the strike zone, producing line drives from gap to gap. He has surprising pop for a 5-foot-9, 160-pounder and is capable of reaching double digits in home runs on an annual basis. He's also an average runner with good instincts on the bases.GPE's fringy arm strength and range leave him without an obvious defensive home. He probably fits best at second base and also has seen time at third base, shortstop and left field as a pro. His bat will have to carry him and looks capable of doing so.

A closer in junior college and then again at ORGANIZATION, PERSON was another hard thrower drafted by the ORGANIZATION, taken in the 10th round in 2014. He reached Double-A in his first full season, then was having an up-and-down return to the level in 2016.The undersized right-hander has shown an ability to miss bats consistently, even when he struggled in the LOCATION. He can touch the upper 90s with his fastball and can sit comfortably in the mid-90s. He complements the heater with a solid hard slider that has good late movement to it when he's throwing it right. His quick arm tends to throw a lot of strikes, and he goes right after hitters.PERSON has closed games throughout his pro career, pitching across three levels during that first full season. His fastball might be a bit too straight at times for him to serve as a stopper at the highest level, but he's looking like another power arm in the ORGANIZATION system who can help out the bullpen in the future.

There has never been any question about Familiaâs arm strength and his ability to generate swings and misses, with his strikeout rate of nearly a batter per inning throughout his ORGANIZATION career. He can maintain his mid-90s velocity throughout his starts with good sink. His slider with short bite gives him a very good breaking ball to complement his fastball, and it has a cutter-type action. He shows some feel for a sinking changeup, though he doesnât throw it much, especially when heâs coming out of the bullpen. His lack of command and the lack of a consistent third pitch makes most thinking a relief role makes the most sense, with the potential to be a future closer.

PERSON PERSON threw the only perfect game in GPE history in 1987, and 31 years later his son PERSON joined him in the school record books with 18 strikeouts in one game. That's also the most whiffs in an ORGANIZATION Division I game this year and the performance gave another boost to his already rising PERSON stock. The ORGANIZATION signed PERSON as a 19th-rounder in 1989, while his son should go about 15 rounds higher this June. An unheralded recruit out of a ORGANIZATION high school, PERSON has added about 50 pounds in college and his stuff has gotten stronger as well. His fastball usually ranges from 91-94 mph and tops out at 97. But the key to his success is his low-80s slider, which can be a sharp, plus pitch at its best but also lacks consistency.PERSON's changeup is decent if a bit firm and should improve as he uses it more. He repeats his delivery well for a big guy and has no trouble filling the strike zone. His huge frame should lend itself to durability and adds to his profile as a potential innings-eating starter in the middle of a rotation.

The ORGANIZATION kept on drafting bats in 2012, taking this Cal Poly product in the sandwich round. His pro debut was cut short by a knee injury, but he is healthy and ready to show he's the kind of college bat that can move quickly through a system. Improved plate discipline helped him tremendously during his junior season, allowing him to tap into his above-average power more consistently and be a better all-around hitter. There will be some swing-and-miss to his game, but it looks like there should be walks, long balls and enough hitting ability to make him a regular. PERSON played center field in college, and that's where he played during his brief time on the field for the ORGANIZATION in 2012, but most see him shifting over to right, where his strong arm and offensive profile should play just fine.Bernie PERSON's scouting report Â»

One of the concerns in the scouting industry in today's game is that young pitchers are throwing too much. With that in mind, when a good arm comes along without a lot of mileage on it, scouts get excited. PERSON was the case with PERSON in GPE, who has a lot to learn but a lot to work with. There is little question about PERSON's arm strength, as he was throwing his fastball up to 93-95 mph this spring. He'll flash a very good slider as well, and while his changeup is below-average right now, he does show some feel for it, with hope that it eventually will be a third Major League-average offering for him. A former catcher, PERSON is still learning how to pitch. He has a tendency to come out of the gate full-tilt, running out of gas as he gets deeper into starts. Right now, PERSON looks more like a power fastball-slider guy, and that might make some feel that he profiles better in the bullpen. But everything works well delivery-wise, giving him a good chance to start at the next level once he cleans some things up. A team that feels he can do that could take him early enough to keep him from staying in ORGANIZATION and heading to GPE Diego State.Prospect Development PERSON - PERSON, GPE.

PERSON viewed PERSON as a tough sign heading into the 2012 Draft due to his commitment to play football at LOCATION. However, the ORGANIZATION took a gamble in the third round and landed him with a $750,000 signing bonus. PERSON spent much of the next three years focused on his football career, playing one season as LOCATION' quarterback before transferring to GPE and playing defensive back, before finally giving up the sport last offseason.Though he chose to pursue football, PERSON continued to play for the ORGANIZATION each summer and logged 25 games between the 2012-14 seasons. That made his performance in 2015 all the more impressive, as PERSON transformed from a raw athlete into a surprisingly well-rounded and polished ballplayer in his first full season, hitting .298/.398/.421 with 27 steals and 13.8 percent walk rate in 107 games across both Class A levels. That he hasn't come close to repeating that level of production in 2016 has more to do with PERSON's health than his abilities, as he made two separate trips to the disabled list for a knee injury and a concussion, respectively. PERSON stands out for his top-flight athleticism and physical tools, but it's his mature feel for the game that has scouts excited about his ceiling as a top-of-the-order hitter who can stick in center field. PERSON's plus-plus speed is a weapon on the basepaths as well as in the outfield. The right-handed hitter has some swing-and-miss to his game but makes a lot of hard contact and consistently works deep counts, and his combination of natural hitting ability and a patient approach should help him tap into more power going forward.

Signed as a skinny infielder at age 17 in July 2013 and immediately transitioned to the mound, PERSON has added size and strength to his 6-foot-1 frame over time. A big '17 that saw him go to the ORGANIZATION, lead the organization in strikeouts and get added to the 40-man roster put him more firmly on the map. He reached Double-A in 2018, but wasn't nearly as dominant in the process.Stuff-wise, PERSON has more than enough to get big league hitters out. He has a lively fastball that he throws consistently up to the mid-90s that can miss bats and get weak contact on the ground. He'll show a plus curveball that can be a true out pitch and a changeup that might be above-average when all is said and done. The premium stuff can play down at times because of his below average command and control. He walked just over four per nine innings in 2018, in line with his career rate, though he really struggled to find the strike zone when he moved up to Double-A.PERSON has some effort to his delivery and can fly open at times, leading to those control problems. There's long been talk about him being a reliever in the future, where his outstanding stuff would play up and his durability could allow him to handle multiple innings.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 5, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON sits in the upper 80s and lower 90s with his fastball, but despite his arm strength, he is more of a project on the mound.The high school junior has an unusual off-balance delivery.

It's hard to know when things will click for a pitching prospect. PERSON bounced around to three different colleges and was a reliever at ORGANIZATION when the PERSON took him in the seventh round of the 2015 Draft. He had a lackluster debut that summer, but then a light went off in 2016. PERSON dominated in the LOCATION, and then held his own in three starts in Double-A, finishing the year in the top three in the organization in a host of pitching categories. He made it up to Triple-A in 2017 before requiring PERSON surgery in June.The PERSON felt PERSON hadn't been allowed to just go out and pitch and learn from failure during his college career. So they let him do just that and his four-pitch mix was more than up to the task. Sure, the velocity would play up out of the pen, but he would pitch at 93-94 mph and reach back for 96-97 whenever he needed it as a starter. He currently has two distinct breaking balls and both flash at least above-average at times. One night, the slider will be a plus pitch and the curve is just average; the next start it will be flipped, and PERSON goes with the pitch he has a better feel for. His changeup is a solid average pitch, with room for improvement. His command took a large step forward as well.Before the injury, PERSON had been strong and durable and looked every bit a starting pitcher. Once healthy, he'll get back to showing he can continue to do that at the upper levels.

H.B. PERSON in GPE has churned out more than its fair share of GPE talent, none more famous than ORGANIZATION of ORGANIZATION. More recently, it produced outfielder PERSON, who went No. 5 in the 2015 GPE to the ORGANIZATION and is one of the top prospects in baseball. PERSON gets some comps to his former Plant outfield mate, albeit with less power and more speed.PERSON does have the makings of a five-tool player. Currently, his standout tool is his speed, which he uses to get down the line in a hurry and run down balls in center field. He has really good hands to hit and some feel the 6-foot-4 left-handed hitter will add power once he starts incorporating his lower half more consistently. He can defend in the outfield to go along with a plus arm.Committed to the ORGANIZATION of GPE, PERSON does have a backup plan on the mound, with a fastball up to 93 mph and a decent curve from the left side. But his tools on both sides of the ball as an outfielder should have him in play in the early going, and he was firmly in first-round conversations despite missing time with a hamstring injury.

PERSON is an above average runner whose strides allow him to adequately traverse center field for now, though he has a very projectable frame and could move to a corner. His swing is flat and his timing is poor, but PERSON has loose hands and gorgeous extension through contact. He has the physical tools to thi, he just needs a mechanical adjustment, and it's even more imperative he gets one if he eventually moves to a corner.

When the ORGANIZATION nabbed PERSON in the fourth round of the 2015 Draft, they were getting a college bat with power and a good approach, one who finished tied for second in home runs among Division I hitters and who led the nation in GPE. That wasn't the player who showed up for his pro debut, but the ORGANIZATION are hopeful that will be the exception and not the norm.In college, PERSON thrived with terrific plate discipline, drawing more walks than strikeouts in his career. During his pro debut, his walk rate was below average and he never really got his bat going. The ORGANIZATION product has plus raw power, and a return to his refined approach should allow him to do what he did in college. PERSON's defense is a bigger question mark. He's fringy, at best, at the hot corner, with a below-average arm. PERSON has a ways to go on that front, and a move to first, where he played during his junior season, isn't out of the question.It was the bat the ORGANIZATION were buying when they selected PERSON. If he can fulfill his potential on that front, his power and run-production potential should profile well wherever he plays defensively.

A year after signing as a 17th-round pick in 2012, PERSON injured his elbow, and a subsequent medical exam revealed that he was missing a muscle in the rotator cuff of his pitching shoulder. The condition hasn't hampered him, as he has stayed healthy since and had a breakout season in 2015 that included winning a gold medal with PERSON at the ORGANIZATION Games.Though he has averaged slightly more than a strikeout per inning in the lower Minors, PERSON isn't overpowering. He relies more on mixing four pitches and locating them well, giving him a ceiling as a back-of-the-rotation starter. PERSON's best pitch is his changeup, a major weapon against right-handers, and he can put lefties away with his curveball. His fastball usually sits at 88-89 mph and can reach 92. He also utilizes a slider.

PERSON established himself as one of the best power hitters in the 2014 Draft, winning the home run derby at the ORGANIZATION All-American Classic the previous summer before batting .580 with 13 homers in 28 games as a high school senior. He had only sporadic success in his first three seasons after signing for $1,870,500 as the 26th overall pick, however, before a change in approach led to a breakout 2017, when he finished third in the Minors in extra-base hits (68) and fifth in homers (31) while reaching Double-A. But after testing positive for a performance-enhancing substance during the offseason, he had to serve an 80-game suspension at the beginning of this year.The key for PERSON was understanding that he doesn't have to swing for the fences and that his bat speed, strength and loft in his right-handed swing will create plenty of natural power. He stopped trying to pull every pitch he saw out of the park and did a better job of recognizing pitches and adopting a two-strike approach. He cut his strikeout rate to 22 percent last year but still may not show enough patience to hit for a high average against quality pitching.PERSON broke into pro ball as a shortstop before moving to third base in instructional league following his pro debut. While his below-average speed limits his range, he has a strong arm and has worked hard to become an acceptable defender at the hot corner. Blocked by PERSON in GPE, he began playing some first base late last season and in the ORGANIZATION, and some scouts wonder if he could become a second baseman in the ORGANIZATION mold.

A late bloomer in high school, ORGANIZATION opted for GPE instead of the ORGANIZATION, who had taken him in the 26th round in 2015. PERSON surgery wiped out his freshman year, but he came back and pitched well as the ORGANIZATION' Saturday starter. He's kept it going as ORGANIZATION's ace this year, among the best in the nation in strikeouts per nine innings and being one of 40 named to ORGANIZATION as a result, though his command regressed later in the spring.ORGANIZATION has as good of an arm as just about any college pitcher in the ORGANIZATION, and the fact that it's his left one certainly doesn't hurt his ORGANIZATION stock. He's touched triple digits this year with his fastball consistently all spring, hitting 97-100 on a regular basis. He combines that with a plus changeup, a pitch he throws with good arm speed that features a ton of late drop to it. His slider gives him a third at least average pitch. While his strikeout rate has been really high, his walk rate has been as well. That, plus a delivery that features a fairly big recoil, have some wondering if he's better suited for a bullpen, especially if that could get him to the big leagues in a hurry. With a loose and very athletic frame, though, ORGANIZATION might be able to get away with those mechanics. He's elicited some PERSON comps, with some scouts thinking he has better stuff now, at least with the fastball, than PERSON did in his ORGANIZATION year.

PERSON's lack of arm strength really boxes him in at second base, which means he has to hit enough to be a regular there because defensive versatility, and therefore a viable utility role, isn't part of his profile. Much of the pressure will be on the bat to ball skills as PERSON is a compact guy with average bat speed. He probably needs to be a 60 bat or better to play every day, which is feasible considering that his attributes, dating back to high school, are lead by a short swing and barrel control. He's off to a good start in 2019, walking nearly as much as he has struck out.

/29: PERSON fans 20 in masterful ORGANIZATION was coming out of the ORGANIZATION high school ranks in 2014, he was a raw, projectable left-hander with arm strength, but with undeveloped secondary stuff and fringy command. Three years later, after working with PERSON pitching coach PERSON, he is looking like the more complete pitcher scouts who saw him in high school envisioned.Much of PERSON's success stems from his fastball-slider combination. He'll throw his fastball in the 89-94 mph range and backs it up with an above-average slider that flashes plus at times. He effectively mixes in an average changeup and will throw a below-average curveball as a "get me over for strike one" type offering. While he's still refining his overall command within the zone, his control has been tremendous, keeping his walk rate at a miniscule level as a junior.Over the summer, PERSON's stuff was somewhat ordinary pitching out of the GPE ORGANIZATION's bullpen. But the 6-foot-6, 240-pound southpaw, with a strong and durable build made for starting, has seen his stuff tick up this spring. That, along with a performance reflecting those improvements, has put an up arrow next to his name as the ORGANIZATION nears.

PERSON has uncommon on-field self-awareness for a two-sport high school athlete who was only 20 last year. He has excellent plate discipline and an all-fields, gap-to-gap approach that suits his plus-plus speed; everything he slices down the line or sprays into the gap goes for extra-bases. PERSON also put on a shocking display during BP at the ORGANIZATION and hit two absolute seeds during the game. He never did anything remotely like that in the ORGANIZATION (nor, frankly, did any of the other prospects who played in GPE and then later in GPE) and actually struggled to turn on balls there, but there's a chance of huge, if dormant, in-game power here, too. PERSON runs well enough to play center field (by a lot), his arm strength still might limit him to left field. That's where we have him projected, where we think he'll be a ORGANIZATION or PERSON type of defender. He projects as an excellent leadoff hitter with some pop, but there's a chance he ends up hitting for more power at some point.

PERSON's fastball hovers in the 92-94 mph range and he's reached 96. His two-seam fastball might be his best pitch, but it's not his only weapon.PERSON's repertoire also features a power breaking ball. He also has a good feel for his changeup, which features some sink. The teen knows how to attack hitters and has shown good command of his pitches, and like most pitchers his age, PERSON's control will improve as he develops and receives more instruction. There's some deception in his delivery and there's lot of aggressiveness in his approach. In short, he's a competitor with an edge and a strong arm. He profiles as a starter with top of the rotation projection because of his skill set and pitch abilities. The teen still has to learn how to harness his energy and power arm, and that process will begin in earnest once he signs with a team and enters the club's academy. PERSON trains in GPE with PERSON and is represented by PERSON of ORGANIZATION. The Nationals are the favorites to sign him.

PERSON boosted his stock at the final major event of the high school showcase circuit, leading all pitchers at the World Wood Bat Association World Championship by averaging 93 mph and touching 96 with his fastball. He already has a strong build at 6-foot-2 and 220 pounds, and it enables him to maintain low-90s velocity deep into games and touch as high as 99 mph.PERSON also has some power to his 81-83 mph slider, which shows flashes of becoming a solid pitch when he doesn't overthrow it. He hasn't needed to use his changeup much yet but will have to develop it against better competition. There's some effort to his delivery, so he may never have fine command. He's part of a typically strong ORGANIZATION recruiting class, though PERSON could get drafted high enough to forgo college. Clarksville (Tenn.) PERSON hasn't had a player selected since 1967, but that will change in June.

During college, PERSON was used primarily as a reliever, but both at ORGANIZATION and in two summers in the ORGANIZATION. After drafting him in 2012, the ORGANIZATION gave him a chance to start, but they scrapped that plan in 2013. His fastball plays up out of the bullpen and has touched the upper-90s. More typically, PERSON throws in the low- to mid-90s and mixes his fastball with a hard curveball. He throws from a good downhill angle and gets lots of groundballs as a result. Dating back to college, however, PERSON has suffered from control problems, stemming from his extreme overhand arm action and unorthodox delivery. If he can improve his command, PERSON would fit well into the back of a Major League bullpen.

The ORGANIZATION actually picked PERSON one spot ahead of PERSON in the first round of the 2009 Draft. While PERSON was rocketing to superstardom, PERSON had trouble staying healthy. He finally did so the past two seasons, hitting a combined 40 homers while reaching Double-A, before GPE sent him to ORGANIZATION in a trade for PERSON Freese.PERSON has the tools to hit for some average and power in the big leagues. He has a quick bat, and he has room on his frame to add some more strength. PERSON is very aggressive at the plate, something pitchers might exploit at higher levels.PERSON has played all three outfield positions in the Minors, fitting best in right field with his average arm and his fringy speed. The ORGANIZATION have a logjam of outfield talent, so his versatility could help when he is ready for ORGANIZATION.

GPE's PERSON is the favorite to go No. 1 overall in the 2019 Draft, and the player who shared catching duties with him on the GPE collegiate national team last summer won't go far behind. PERSON' defense alone could make him a first-rounder. Recovering from hitting .252 as a sophomore, he has looked better offensively this spring despite breaking the hamate in his left hand and rushing back after just three weeks. He homered three times and set an ORGANIZATION Division I tournament record with 11 RBI in one game two days before the Draft.PERSON has a cannon arm that can produce 1.7-second pop times in workouts and 1.8-second clockings during games, and he used it to erase 70 percent of basestealers as sophomore. The 2018 Rawlings/ABCA Gold Glove recipient as the best defensive catcher in college baseball, he's a quality receiver who's more agile and athletic than most at his position. He also has the strong leadership skills teams desire in a backstop.Even when PERSON slumped last year, he still made consistent contact and doesn't have any glaring flaws in his right-handed stroke. It was more a matter of trying to do too much at the plate rather than letting his solid to plus raw power play without selling out for home runs. He's a below-average runner but quicker than a typical catcher.

O'Hearn has been a revelation since signing for $125,000 as an eighth-round pick in 2014. After totaling 11 home runs in three seasons at ORGANIZATION, he hit 13 in 64 games while winning Rookie-level PERSON MVP honors in his pro debut. He has continued to pound the ball in his first full pro season, easily leading the low Class A GPE ORGANIZATION in home runs.The Royals believe O'Hearn's power is for real, stemming from a change in approach that has him turning his left-handed swing loose instead of focusing on contact. More aggressiveness at the plate has resulted in more strikeouts, so he may not hit for a high batting average. While O'Hearn needs to improve defensively, he's a decent athlete for a first baseman. He's not a baseclogger and he has some arm strength, so PERSON has given him some playing time in right field.

PERSON owns a career 3.43 ORGANIZATION and has now reached Double-A. He has an average four-pitch mix that works because he has above-average command, and because his fastball, which lives in the top part of the zone, has flat, tough-to-catch plane. While PERSON got most of the attention at ORGANIZATION, and with good reason as the two-way star went No. 4 overall in the GPE, it was PERSON who led the LOCATION in batting average, home runs and ORGANIZATION as a red-shirt sophomore. PERSON was hitting the mid-90's in his freshman year at ORGANIZATION and has been a shutdown closer his whole career. He could move quickly, especially since ORGANIZATION aborted an attempt last fall to start PERSON, so now a team won't need to look into it.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 21, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON has attended numerous Under GPE showcases, and he earned a 2015 ORGANIZATION and a selection onto the 2016 ORGANIZATION Second Team for his efforts.At the high school level with PERSON, ORGANIZATION won GPE 6-6A ORGANIZATION, which helped spark his commitment to PERSON A&M.

He may have hot stretches where he hits for tons of power, and ice ages when he strikes out a ton. We think it's a high-variance profile with a shot to make some All-Star teams while other years will be lean, and closer to replacement level.

Catching is always hard to find, and as a result, it's in high demand every Draft. PERSON has always been blessed with tremendous raw tools, but has had trouble developing them, dealing both with injury and off-the-field issues. PERSON was rapidly becoming one of the more exciting pitching prospects in the D-backs system, reaching full-season ball as he turned 20 years old. When healthy, he has electric stuff, albeit from a slightly undersized frame. His fastball will reach the mid-90s and can touch the upper-90s at times, all coming from a quick arm. His hard curveball gives him a second above-average offering as an out pitch. His changeup is below-average, but he's shown some feel for it. A decorated college performer, PERSON's fastball sits 89-93 though he'll show you 94+ on occasion. His high effort delivery limits his command projection but he has a nasty 12-6 curveball and might be able to pitch in the back of a bullpen if he doesn't work out as a #4 starter

PERSON has gained notoriety as a switch-throwing pitcher who can throw in the upper 80s and is equally effective with either arm. The GPE recruit has close to average speed, making him quick for a catcher, and shows good instincts in all phases of the game.

A big-bodied arm strength relief type whose fastball has ticked up from the 90-95 area to the 92-97 range. It has consdierable life and ride. PERSON also has a curveball and changeup, both of which are more 45s or 50s on the scouting scale. He projects as a fastball-heavy reliever.

His stuff is plenty good, too, as the quick-armed right-hander will reach 95 mph with his fastball while flashing a sharp, above-average curveball and showing feel for a changeup. The ORGANIZATION, however, are excited about his upside, viewing him as a late-bloomer who has the potential to stick in the starting rotation.

Three-pitch lefties with mid-90s heat always have a shot, so while PERSON's walk rate remains a disconcerting 13%, the fact that he showed 96 with an occasionally good changeup and breaking ball means he's still pretty interesting. His arm action is so long that it needs to be split into two movies and while that is probably part of why he so badly struggles to throw strikes, it also makes him really tough on left-handed hitters. The existence of three pitches (the fastball, an upper-80s change, low-80s slurve) better positions PERSON for the three-batter minimum rule, but he still needs to throw more strikes or he's just upper-level depth.

A late bloomer in GPE, PERSON was nearly 18 when he signed in 2012 and commanded just a $10,000 bonus. The ORGANIZATION praise his makeup and work ethic and believe he eventually can settle into the middle of their rotation.

MLBPipeline.com's No. 2-ranked prospect for the 2016-17 international signing period, PERSON pitched for PERSON's 12-and-under team, 15-and-under team and 18-and-under team, and he was the ORGANIZATION of the 15-and-under World Cup in GPE in 2014. PERSON graduated a semester early from PERSON (Fla.) and enrolled at GPE in 2012, bypassing the Draft in the process. There are high school pitchers who fit the mold of tall and projectable. Then there are those who are more physically mature, with a good idea of how to pitch. PERSON improved in each of his three years at ORGANIZATION, earning Big GPE All-Conference honors as a junior. The ORGANIZATION took PERSON in the 12th round that June, signing him for $150,000. After scuffling in the lower PERSON for a few seasons, PERSON broke out in 2012. As a 20-year-old, he moved up to Double-A Binghamton for the first time. PERSON spent the first two years of his college career at FACILITY, where he got just 31 at-bats and 29 innings, before transferring to LOCATION. PERSON had a rough first season in pro ball as a 20-year-old in the ORGANIZATION. A former shortstop who's new to the outfield, he also needs more polish defensively but has the quickness to outrun his mistakes.

PERSON was acquired from GPE in the January PERSON trade. PERSON has shown a combination of intriguing stuff and subpar command since joining the ORGANIZATION as a 14th-round Draft pick in 2013. PERSON has all the ingredients to serve as a late-inning force coming out of the bullpen, allowing him to better utilize his two plus pitches without worry about throwing strikes or working deep into games.

PERSON keeps trickling down the defensive spectrum -- he was pretty good defensive shortstop in high school but is a bigger-bodied third baseman now, and may have to move to an outfield corner eventually -- but with that weight has come substantial raw power, and he now has two consecutive 20-homer seasons on his resume. PERSON captured scouts' attention on last summer's showcase circuit with his hitting ability. He has good bat-to-ball skills and produces plenty of line drives. He uses a high kick as a timing mechanism in his swing, but when he is timed up, he produces consistent, hard contact. Scouts expect him to develop more power as he physically matures.  PERSON is a fringy runner and his arm strength has been hampered by a shoulder injury he suffered last year. He is a capable outfielder and likely fits best in left field.  A GPE native, PERSON transferred to The FACILITY and ORGANIZATION in GPE, Fla., for his senior year of high school. He is committed to GPE.

Many of the teenage prospects on this list received big bonuses or were flagged after a season in the ORGANIZATION as a prospect to watch; it's unsurprising when those types move up this list. Though he might have become a No. 4 starter if he had stuck in the rotation, he has a greater chance of becoming a useful bullpen piece who has had success against lefties and righties alike.

GSP is the quintessential scrappy college shortstop. PERSON had spent his first two years at ORGANIZATION as a starter at shortstop when he headed to PERSON for the summer. He plays a quality first base and should be able to handle right field, though the ORGANIZATION have taken it easy on him defensively because he doubles as their closer. Scouting Grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 40 | Run: 30 | Arm: 55 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45Taken a year ago by the ORGANIZATION as a Draft-eligible sophomore in the 30th round, PERSON returned to GPE for his junior year and has cemented himself as one of the more highly regarded college two-way players.As a left-handed starter, PERSON was terrific in GPE's weekend rotation this season, using a three-pitch mix well. The ORGANIZATION spent a franchise-record $74.2 million on bonuses and penalties for their 2014-15 international class, including $63 million in a bonus and tax for PERSON and $8,000 for PERSON. Though the ORGANIZATION forfeited their 2016 first-round pick to sign free agent PERSON, they felt like they got a first-round talent in the second round with PERSON. PERSON is considered by some scouts to be the best defensive shortstop from the ORGANIZATION in this year's class of international prospects.Evaluators like PERSON' lean build and projectable body. Originally a shortstop in the ORGANIZATION before moving to the mound and signing with the ORGANIZATION for $85,000 in 2012, PERSON emerged as one of their best pitching prospects around the time he made his GPE debut in '15. A minor shoulder problem may have impacted PERSON's ultimate place in the 2014 Draft, but the ORGANIZATION were confident enough in his health and stuff to take him in the second round and give him nearly $800,000 more than pick value to sign him away from GPE John's.Already 6-foot-6 and 210 pounds, PERSON has the look of a big leaguer. When the FACILITY put PERSON in charge of rebuilding their international scouting department following a bonus-skimming scandal, his first six-figure signing was PERSON, who turned pro for $250,000 out of GPE in December 2011. There's a lot of projection remaining in his frame, though he hasn't been able to add much strength since signing.

With the way his sinker and slider could play up in shorter stints, he has closer upside if he does head to the bullpen.

In 2016, PERSON was the 36th-best Draft prospect according to ORGANIZATION. PERSON' older brother, PERSON, was a 2014 fourth-round pick of the ORGANIZATION out of high school. PERSON opted to head to PERSON rather than sign in 2015 as a 22nd-round pick of the ORGANIZATION. PERSON was a legitimate pro prospect as a catcher, but it became clear during showcase season that he fit best on the mound and aside from biceps tendonitis in the spring, he was on a trajectory to go in the top half of the first round. Think a young PERSON. That's how some scouts have described the 20-year-old center fielder from GPE. Evaluators like his body -- described as solid and compact -- and his athleticism. Though few left-handers in the Minors can match PERSON's velocity, his development has progressed very slowly. PERSON popped up as an intriguing yet raw high school player over the summer, sneaking on to the end of ORGANIZATION's PERSON 50 list. He struggled with the bat this spring, showing an inability to hit decent breaking stuff. His other tools also have been inconsistent, sometimes showing average speed, arm and defensive ability, other times not showing quite as strongly.PERSON is clearly a project, one that might take some time to come to fruition. There is little question that PERSON can handle the defensive rigors of playing shortstop at the highest level. A switch-hitter who's a bit better from the right side, PERSON has always been adept at putting the ball in play and has shown decent strike-zone knowledge. With very limited power and below-average speed, he doesn't have that much of an offensive ceiling.PERSON had played shortstop and little else for much of his career, his path to the big leagues might be as a utility man who can play on both sides of the infield. He saw more time at second and third in 2014 as a result.

The jump to Double-A is thought of as a huge separator for prospects. PERSON, whose older brother PERSON is a third baseman in the GPE system, learned that the hard way when the ORGANIZATION double-jumped him from the Class A ORGANIZATION to the LOCATION in 2015.PERSON found out that hitters at that level will make you pay if you make a mistake, and he made plenty of them in 2015, giving up more than 12 hits per nine innings in the process. His secondary stuff, a slider and changeup, are inconsistent, with not enough separation between any of them.For PERSON to remain a starter, he'll need to find a way to differentiate his pitches to keep hitters more off-balance. If not, he could be an effective sinker-slider reliever who sees an uptick in velocity in shorter stints and gets called upon when a ground ball is needed.

During his college career at ORGANIZATION, PERSON changed roles a couple of times, relieving for his first two seasons, then starting during his junior year before returning for his senior campaign out of the bullpen. After letting him work as a reliever during his summer debut, the ORGANIZATION moved PERSON back into the rotation during his first full season and it's a move that looks like it's paying off. He finished tied for third in the ORGANIZATION in strikeouts (fourth in the organization). PERSON has the chance to have four at-least-average pitches with his fastball, curve, changeup and above-average cutter. All of them play up with his above-average to plus control. He could undoubtedly help PERSON out of the bullpen more quickly, but it would be hard to argue with keeping him in the rotation. A future PERSON Medlen-like role might make a lot of sense.

PERSON recorded a 5.45 ERA in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION in his first two pro seasons and walked more batters than he struck out in his GPE debut in 2015. He didn't arrive in full-season ball with any fanfare this year, but he has raised his profile significantly after pitching well at low Class A PERSON and displaying one of the best fastballs in the ORGANIZATION system.PERSON's fastball hit 99 mph in his first game with PERSON and has soared as high as 101 while usually sitting at 95-97. His hard slider is an intriguing second pitch that will require some more polish, and he also has a changeup that won't get much use because he's destined to be a short reliever.He's still learning to harness his stuff and has yet to find the strike zone with regularity, but PERSON's live right arm will buy him plenty of development time. He doesn't miss a lot of bats yet because opponents sit on his fastball. If he can sharpen his slider and his control, he could develop into a late-inning option.

There are three players from GPE in ORGANIZATION's PERSON 200 this year. Few see him sticking at the position, however, because he's a bit heavy-legged in terms of his range and while he does have some arm strength, he doesn't always show the ability to throw from different arm angles, a skill needed for the premium position. A move to second might work, with others suggesting third or left field, where his arm would probably play up to average. Playing a corner spot would put more pressure on his bat, and there is some serious raw power for him to tap into.That power, and the hope he'll hit enough to get to it consistently, is what teams will be banking on should they take the left-handed hitter. When the PERSON drafted PERSON in the eighth round out of the GPE high school ranks in 2014, he was the type of player who looked the part as a physical specimen but was considered raw in all facets of the game, given his two-sport background as an amateur. He took a major step forward in 2015, however, when he paced the ORGANIZATION York-Penn PERSON in home runs (11), ORGANIZATION (46) and ORGANIZATION (.933) in his second professional season. He began the 2016 on the disabled list while recovering from a wrist injury before finally making his full-season debut for Class A Greensboro in late April. But PERSON's time in the LOCATION PERSON turned out to be short lived, as a botched knife prank by roommate PERSON in early June resulted in a right thumb laceration and subsequent surgery.Though PERSON has long possessed impressive strength and bat speed, his stiff swing limited his production during his pro debut. The PERSON helped him clean up his mechanics last season, and it allowed him to hit for a higher average while tapping into his plus raw power more consistently. PERSON still needs to tighten his approach and improve his pitch recognition, as cutting down his strikeouts and continuing to increase his walk rate will only make him more dangerous at the plate. PERSON spent all of 2015 in center field, though it remains to be seen if he can remain there long term. He's an above-average runner with enough range to handle all three outfield spots, but with below-average arm strength, he's more likely to end up in left field if he's unable to stick up the middle. PERSON will have to show that the progress he made in 2015 can transfer to full-season ball and up the ladder, but the early signs of improvement certainly are encouraging.

PERSON confounded scouts while he was at ORGANIZATION. He had better all-around tools than most college players and hit well with wood bats in the ORGANIZATION, but he never put up big numbers with the ORGANIZATION. Signed for $248,800 as a sixth-round pick in 2015, he had a so-so pro debut before performing better in high Class A this summer.PERSON has plus-plus speed and can display impressive raw power during batting practice, but neither tool plays quite as well as hoped during game action. He should be a more aggressive and successful basestealer than he is, and he has spent most of his college and pro career in right field rather than center. He has a history of not driving the ball consistently during games, though he has been better in that regard in 2016.His left-handed swing can get busy and he has trouble handling breaking balls, so PERSON has some swing-and-miss issues that limit his ability to hit for a high average. He does have an eye for drawing walks and is more likely to be an on-base threat than a big power source. While he doesn't have the pop of a typical right fielder, he does have the requisite strong arm for the position.

The ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON out of the GPE high school ranks in 2013, but never made a serious run at signing him away from his PERSON commitment.
