However, he keeps finding a way to make consistent hard contact and has gotten better at controlling the strike zone. He has solid speed as well, though he's not much of a basestealer. PERSON's jumps and routes in the outfield leave something to be desired, so he's better suited for a corner. His below-average arm relegates him to left field, but his bat still gives him the upside of a big league regular there.

When PERSON first joined the ORGANIZATION organization, signed back in 2008 out of GPE, he was a thin, awkward, Bambi-like teenager who could really defend and barely hit. While he's still a glove-first shortstop, PERSON has matured considerably into a guy ready to play in the big leagues.PERSON did just that during his Major League debut in 2015, filling in for the injured PERSON for nearly all of September. While he's never going to have much power, PERSON has added enough strength to show the bat won't be knocked out of his hands by high-level pitching, making consistent line-drive contact. He's slowed down a tick as he's matured, but he's still a good baserunner who can steal a base. He also has more than enough range and arm to stay at shortstop long term. He's not the flashy type, but will make every play, the kind of infielder you want the ball hit to.PERSON is obviously blocked at short by PERSON, who is under control through 2018. The 24-year-old is ready for another big league opportunity, especially after a strong showing in his home country's winter league.

The son of the former big leaguer created some serious buzz when he signed early in 2011 and set the ORGANIZATION on fire, winning the rookie-level league's ORGANIZATION honors. His aggressive push to full-season ball didn't go quite as well, though he's clearly young enough where even a repeat of level wouldn't be such a bad thing. There is obviously plenty to project when evaluating PERSON. He has a good feel for the game and has shown a solid approach at the plate. He has the chance to be an average hitter with PERSON average power, even if it takes a bit longer than expected to get there. He's been better than expected defensively and he should be able to stay at third base. PERSON gets high marks for his makeup and work ethic, so the adversity he dealt with in 2012 isn't likely to have long-term adverse effects.

PERSON spent three years in GPE ball after he signed with the ORGANIZATION out of GPE in 2011. He went straight to the Class A Advanced level for his full-season debut in 2014, where he ranked among the GPE League leaders in hitting when he was dealt to the ORGANIZATION at the ORGANIZATION in a prospect package for PERSON. After having his 2015 campaign was cut short after he fractured his right elbow while sliding in GPE, PERSON returned fully healthy in 2016 and was named to the ORGANIZATION Mid-Season All-Star squad. PERSON stands out more for his floor than his ceiling, as he's a well-rounded player who projects to have four average-or-better tools. A right-handed hitter, he makes consistent contact with a flat path through the zone, with barrel control that allows him to spray the ball from line to line. Though he rarely strikes out, PERSON can be aggressive to a fault at times and will need to develop more selectivity as he continues to progress through the Minors. PERSON's average speed stands out most at shortstop, and he has the necessary range, footwork and arm strength to remain there long term. Yet, despite having all of the defensive tools to become a big-league regular at shortstop, it will be up to PERSON's bat to make good on the projection.

PERSON GPE has an enviable track record of baseball success, producing a Hall of GPE (PERSON), 12 GPE 4-A state championships and 15 picks in the last 20 Drafts. The school's latest prospect is PERSON, the fastest runner in the 2015 Draft. Though his senior season came to an early end with a hamate bone fracture in early April, the injury shouldn't affect his Draft status.PERSON' top-of-the-line speed helps him beat out grounders for base hits, wreak havoc on the bases and cover plenty of ground in the field. More than just a slap hitter, the ORGANIZATION recruit shows bat speed from both sides of the plate and has gap power. He had one of the better batting practices at the workout before the Under PERSON All-America Game, hitting balls out of Illinois-Chicago's PERSON as a lefty and righty.While PERSON' quickness allows him to cover ground, scouts aren't sold that he has the arm for shortstop or the hands for the middle infield. He draws a lot of comparisons to PERSON, albeit with more strength, and could follow the ORGANIZATION' speedster's path from shortstop to center field.

PERSON hasn't taken the most direct route to a shot at the big leagues, but after a 2012 season that saw him pitch across three levels and get added to the 40-man roster, he's now knocking on the door. PERSON signed after the 2007 season, and in 2008, he split time between the A's system and GPE in the ORGANIZATION. He's been with the A's since, and almost exclusively as a reliever. He had PERSON surgery in 2010, throwing 10 1/3 innings in 2010 and 2011 combined. He started slowly, back in the GPE, but then threw very well in stops in Double-A GPE and Triple-A Sacramento. PERSON isn't going to blow people away, but he does throw an average fastball and changeup, along with a fringy breaking ball, but when he stays on top of his pitches, he gets a lot of movement down in the zone. He followed up his 2012 with a strong performance in the ORGANIZATION Winter League, which could prepare him for a shot at the big league bullpen.

PERSON electrified ORGANIZATION fans in 2012, when he did a backflip on ORGANIZATION right after getting drafted 13th overall and played well at two Class A stops at the end of his debut. He still shows glimpses of the high ceiling that earned him a $2,475,000 bonus but has struggled for much of his four full pro seasons. In the last two years in Double-A, he has had trouble making consistent contact and missed time with finger, foot and oblique injuries.PERSON' bat speed and strength give him jaw-dropping raw power, but it remains to be seen whether he'll be polished enough as a hitter to make the most of it. His right-handed swing can get out of control at times and his plate discipline regressed in 2015 after improving the year before. He may never hit for a high average but could produce 25 or more homers per year at GPE Cellular Field if he can refine his approach.Coming out of high school, PERSON had solid speed and arm strength. He since has lost a step as he has matured physically and his throwing motion is a bit stiff, so he now fits best in left field after playing primarily in center field in his first two pro seasons.

The son of FACILITY director of strength and conditioning PERSON, PERSON is a three-sport star at ORGANIZATION (GPE). If he follows through on his commitment to PERSON, he wants to try to double as an outfielder in baseball and a slot receiver in football. PERSON's 2017 Illinois baseball player of the year as a junior, he has the hitting ability and athleticism to get drafted high enough to forego college.With his compact left-handed stroke, impressive bat speed and mature approach at the plate, PERSON smacks line drives to all fields. He has no trouble barreling quality fastballs and led gold medal-winning PERSON in hitting with a .361 average at the 18-and-under World Cup in September. Though he's not very physical, his feel for the barrel and sneaky pop should produce at least 12-15 homers per year in pro ball.PERSON enhances his plus speed with good instincts on the bases and in center field. While he has below-average arm strength, it's playable in center field. His game earns him comparisons to the likes of PERSON and PERSON, and PERSON is more advanced at the same stage of their careers.

PERSON missed his high school senior season with an elbow injury that led to PERSON surgery and a redshirt year as a freshman at ORGANIZATION. He pitched just 36 2/3 innings and posted a 11.05 ERA while battling knee problems in two seasons with the ORGANIZATION, but the ORGANIZATION bought into his velocity enough to sign him for $225,000 in the seventh round in 2011. Then he needed another operation to repair the labrum in his shoulder, so he didn't make his pro debut until 2014.PERSON was worth the wait, however, as he averaged 18.1 strikeouts per nine innings and showed the best consistent velocity in the ORGANIZATION. He operates around 100 mph with his fastball and can dial it up to 103, and the pitch also features impressive life. There's power to his downer curveball as well, and it gives him a second swing-and-miss pitch. His delivery isn't the cleanest, but PERSON has helped him clean up his mechanics to give him a better chance of staying healthy and throwing strikes. A lat injury sidelined him for part of 2015, though he continued to unleash triple-digit heat when he took the mound.

If PERSON had worked out a deadline deal with the ORGANIZATION in 2014, they also would have landed PERSON with a seven-figure bonus in the 21st round. When PERSON opted not to sign, PERSON didn't have enough pool money for PERSON, who headed to PERSON but abruptly left in the fall. He surfaced at ORGANIZATION (Fla.) and signed for $750,000 after the ORGANIZATION took him in the fourth round.For the most part during the spring, PERSON looked like the same pitcher who could have gone in the second round out of high school had he not been strongly committed to ORGANIZATION. His fastball usually arrives at 90-92 mph, making it an average pitch, but that's ORGANIZATION because he's left-handed, and it might be only his third-best offering. His fading changeup is a legitimate plus pitch and his curveball can be solid at ORGANIZATION has good feel for pitching and enough control to remain a starter. He lacks projection, so his stuff doesn't figure to get much better, limiting his upside. He'll also have to prove he can stay healthy after having elbow tenderness in each of the last two years, as well as a forearm issue this spring.

PERSON is a big-bodied late bloomer from GPE Florida who wasn't a top notch recruit but developed into an elite prospect in his sophomore year in GPE. He took a softer 6-foot-6, 270 body and got in better shape for the spring, and it took a high effort relief type into a possible workhorse mid-rotation starter. PERSON still stands out for his fastball/slider combo and the changeup and command are around average, so it may be more of a power multi-inning arm than a true 200-inning starter, but his two best features are also ORGANIZATION friendly. This means that progressive clubs see a quick-moving arm with PERSON McCullers-type qualities, and traditional ones see someone they could mold into a power starter.

Since his high school days and through his collegiate career at ORGANIZATION, PERSON has tantalized with his physical presence and his raw tools. Injuries have somewhat limited him from reaching his upside potential as a pro. PERSON was off to a very good start in his first full season in 2014 and was likely about to be promoted out of the ORGANIZATION when an GPE injury forced him out of action for all of 10 games in the summer's final two months. Surgery on his elbow - an issue that affected him in college - kept him from getting work in at instructs as well. PERSON's tools are considerable, particularly his raw power, but he hasn't been able to translate it consistently into games. If he can learn to make adjustments, that would help him fit the profile of a corner outfielder, one with decent speed and a strong arm. PERSON is praised for his work ethic and makeup and that could help him reach his ceiling, something that could help him make it from potential to performance consistently.

A mainstay on the high school showcase circuit, PERSON kicked his game up a notch in his senior season opener, reaching 95 mph with his fastball during an 18-strikeout perfect game. He looked like a top-three-rounds pick early in the spring, but his curveball regressed as the ORGANIZATION drew closer, which may knock him down a bit. Though he's committed to ORGANIZATION, he's considered fairly signable for a mid-rounds prepster.PERSON' fastball has parked in the low 90s all spring and he should add more velocity once he adds muscle to his skinny 6-foot-3 frame. He works from an overhand slot that creates downhill plane but not much life on his four-seamer. He has flashed a solid curveball in the past but it devolved into a mid-70s slurve this spring.PERSON has deceptive arm speed and fade with a changeup that may have more upside than his breaking ball. He has a quick arm but also a deep plunge in the back of his delivery that affects the consistency and command of his pitches. He'll continue to develop as a starter whether he turns pro this summer or attends college, though he might deal in the mid-90s as a reliever once he gets stronger.

The winner of the 9/10-year-old division of the GPE, PERSON & Run competition at the 2005 All-Star Game in GPE, PERSON has the tools to get back on a big league diamond. If he does, he'll become the fifth ORGANIZATION State shortstop to reach the Majors this millennium, following PERSON, five-time Rockies All-Star Troy Tulowitzki, PERSON and PERSON. A third-round pick last June, PERSON led the short-season LOCATION in triples (eight), walks (48) and steals (36) in his pro debut.PERSON has a quick bat and barrels a lot of balls from the right side of the plate, though he lacks the strength to provide much power. He did a better job of putting the ball on the ground and using his plus speed in pro ball after hitting too many easy flyouts in college. He drew almost as many walks and stole almost as many bases in his debut as he totaled in his final two years with the 49ers, an encouraging sign that he may be able to hit near the top of a batting order.Though his average arm strength isn't ideal for shortstop, PERSON has the actions, range, hands and internal clock to stay there. The Rockies have given him a lot of time at second base this year, in part because shortstop PERSON opened the season alongside him in high Class A. PERSON thinks PERSON can be a plus defender at second and provide solid glovework at shortstop.

Even before the FACILITY acquired PERSON from the GPE in the ORGANIZATION trade, he had dealt with a multitude of injuries. Hamstring and shoulder issues plagued him while he was still with the GPE, and limited him to DH duty, or forced him to sit out for a few days at a time, or altogether kept rehabbing him on the ORGANIZATION backfields. He has continued to have various issues since the GPE acquired him. In 2018 alone, PERSON dealt with patella tendinitis during the early part of spring training, then was left back in extended due to a strained pec. He suffered a strained left adductor in GPE, and finally a quad strain this winter, which ended his ORGANIZATION Winter League season. 
But while PERSON has missed considerable time with injuries and sometimes played through them, he has mashed like few other players in the minors. He split 2018 between Double-A Birmingham and Triple-A Charlotte, slashing .337/.384/.577, his strikeout rate plummeting to 13% at the latter stop. Despite his limited speed and at-bats, he somehow managed to net 53 extra-base hits and seemed ready for a big league cup of coffee in September. The FACILITY refused to brew him one, and PERSON's agent threatened to file a grievance against the club, an issue that was resolved during 2019 spring training with a record contract extension. He'll likely be up all year, and while we think there's a chance injury or a lack of mobility limit PERSON's ceiling the way flaws have similarly limited some of GPE's other recent prospect graduates, we still think he'll hit enough to be a star.

After slipping to the fourth round of the 2013 Draft following a bit of a tumultuous senior season of high school, the ORGANIZATION brought PERSON along slowly in his first year and change of pro ball. Then, in 2015, he exploded on the scene, finishing third in the Minors in ORGANIZATION and fifth in batting average against. PERSON was particularly dominant in the first half while in the ORGANIZATION, learning what he needed to work on upon his promotion to the ORGANIZATION State League, as his fastball command and aggressiveness on the mound weren't quite what they were during the first half. The projectable lefty has the chance to have a plus fastball and changeup when all is said and done. His curveball has improved with added power and he continues to work on a slider that could give him a second usable breaking ball. As he continues to physically mature and improve his mechanics, there's the chance there's more in the tank.During the offseason, the ORGANIZATION may have received more inquiries from other teams about PERSON than just about any prospect in the system, with his projectability, feel for pitching and left-handedness making him a very hot commodity.

PERSON missed his first college season in 2011 with rotator-cuff and labrum tears in his shoulder that required surgery. He came back the next year to win Most Outstanding Player honor at the ORGANIZATION World Series. PERSON helped PERSON capture its second national title, hitting a go-ahead two-run homer and earning a save in the championship game. In his first season at ORGANIZATION in 2013, he was the only ORGANIZATION Division I player to lead his team in homers, wins and saves, and he has focused mostly on pitching this spring. When he's at his best, PERSON works at 91-93 mph and touches 96 with a heavy fastball, flashing a plus slider with good tilt at 84-85 mph. At other times, he pitches with an 88-91 mph fastball and a flatter slider in the upper 70s. He has a strong, athletic frame and earns praise for his control and his competitiveness.Moved into the ORGANIZATION' rotation for the final three weeks of the season, PERSON responded with two complete games and pitched into the ninth inning of his third outing. He has a chance to start in pro ball, though he'll need a better changeup in that role. After graduating as a redshirt junior with a degree in sociology, he's expected to sign after turning down the ORGANIZATION as a 29th-rounder in 2012 and the ORGANIZATION as a 40th-rounder last year.

PERSON is closer in age to many international free agent prospects than he is to some of the older high schoolers in this draft. He is fast, capable of staying at shortstop, and has one of the more projectable frames in the class. PERSON' showcase summer contact was middling, but better the following spring. Some teams think it's just a product of facing weaker pitching; others think he's truly emerging and cite his age as evidence that late improvement is legitimate. Draft models that factor in age likely have PERSON very high on some teams' boards, probably in the late first round mix.

The jump to Double-A is thought of as a huge separator for prospects. PERSON, whose older brother PERSON is a third baseman in the GPE system, learned that the hard way when the ORGANIZATION double-jumped him from the Class A ORGANIZATION to the LOCATION in 2015. A second attempt at Double-A in 2016 also didn't go well, but PERSON might have righted the ship with a move to the bullpen with PERSON Lakeland.PERSON found out that hitters at that level will make you pay if you make a mistake, and he made plenty of them in 2015, giving up more than 12 hits per nine innings in the process. The right-hander's bread and butter is his heavy sinker that generates a ton of ground-ball outs, though he is still learning to command it. His secondary stuff, a slider and changeup, are inconsistent, with not enough separation between any of them.His days as a starter perhaps behind him, PERSON can focus on becoming an effective sinker-slider reliever who sees an uptick in velocity in shorter stints and gets called upon when a ground ball as needed.

GPE burst on the scene with the Dodgers by making his GPE debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2011 and pitching extremely well. His followup in the GPE League didn't go nearly as well, and the first part of his 2013 season was up and down, but his youth, stuff and size are all likely reasons the PERSON wanted him as part of the deal for PERSON in July. He has a live arm and a free and easy delivery, which brings fastballs that touch 95 mph with good movement. His secondary stuff is more inconsistent, though he's shown glimpses of a strong, tilting slider and an effective changeup. The ball jumps out of his hand, and if he can learn to command the ball within the strike zone more effectively, he still has the chance to get back on track.

After a bonus-skimming scandal rocked the FACILITY' international scouting department in 2008, it didn't make a significant signing for five years. That drought ended when PERSON signed PERSON, ORGANIZATION's No. 2-rated prospect in the 2013-14 international signing period, for $1.6 million out of the ORGANIZATION. PERSON and hamate maladies limited him to a total of 91 games in his first two full pro seasons, but he finally started to hit as hoped when he stayed healthy in 2017.PERSON combines bat speed and strength with loft and leverage in his right-handed swing, giving him as much raw power as any FACILITY prospect. He hit just .225/.283/.356 with a 36 percent strikeout rate in his first three years a pro, when his stroke often got too long and too steep. Getting regular at-bats has helped him make adjustments this year, as he has started to recognize pitches better and become less pull-happy.PERSON's arm strength is just as jaw-dropping as his power, and those two tools make him an easy fit for the right-field profile. He's already starting to mature and could lose a step off his presently average speed once that process is complete. That shouldn't stop him from becoming an average defender, however.

While he faded a bit at the end, Suarezâs first taste of full-season ball can be qualified as nothing more than a huge success. He finished the year second in the organization in on-base percentage and third in hits. He has knack for contact with a short stroke that generates excellent bat speed. His approach at the plate is very advanced for someone his age/experience level, showing excellent on-base ability. He does have a little power to his pull side, which can get him in trouble at times. While his speed is fringy, at best, he has excellent instincts both on the basepaths and defensively.  He has very smooth defensive actions with good hands and more than enough arm for shortstop. Heâs seen some time at second, and some think his lack of speed will necessitate a move to the right side of the infield, though it might be too soon to write off his abilities to stick at short long-term.

PERSON showed well in GPE's rotation as a sophomore but was unable to make progress the next year, spending much of the season in the bullpen with underwhelming results. The ORGANIZATION selected him in the 23rd round that June, and he pitched at both Class A levels during his full-season debut before advancing to Double-A in 2016 and making his big league debut early in the '17 season.A physically strong right-hander, PERSON pitches with a plus fastball that sits 94-96 mph and touches 97 with late sinking action that has resulted in strong ground-ball rates throughout his career. His low-80s slider plays well against right-handed hitters thanks to its depth and tilt, at times flashing above average, though his overall consistency with the pitch leaves much to be desired. PERSON holds his own against lefties in spite of his lack of a changeup, but he may need to add the pitch to his arsenal in order to retire them at the highest level.PERSON has the ability to work more than one inning, which he did in 23 of his 48 appearances (including four starts) in 2016. That stamina could make him a long reliever in the big leagues, though he does have the potential for a greater role if he can improve his slider and fastball command.

A teammate of GPE first-rounder PERSON at ORGANIZATION (ORGANIZATION, Ala.), PERSON spurned the Indians as a 12th-rounder in 2013 to stay home and attend GPE. He has been a power-hitting presence in the middle of the ORGANIZATION lineup since day one as a freshman and ranked second with 21 home runs entering the ORGANIZATION Division I tournament this year. With the exception of Reds 2013 first-rounder PERSON, he's the best prospect in GPE history.PERSON proved himself with wood bats against quality competition last summer in the ORGANIZATION, where he ranked third in extra-base hits (14) and fourth in slugging (.486). He doesn't have the prettiest right-handed swing, but he's exceptionally strong and makes enough contact to do damage. He's also willing to take a walk when pitchers are loathe to challenge him. A good athlete for his size, PERSON has average speed out of the box and is a shade quicker once he gets going. His solid arm strength helps him fit the profile in right field, where he gets the job done.

GPE of a bumper crop of ORGANIZATION catchers in the 2016 Draft -- four went in the first 43 picks -- PERSON signed for $1,772,500 out of ORGANIZATION as the 32nd overall selection. The first catcher taken in the first round by the ORGANIZATION since PERSON in 1993, he has lived up to his reputation as being a better athlete and thrower than most backstops. His defense earned him a promotion to Double-A in the middle of his first full season, but an errant pitch broke his right hand in his first game at that level and sidelined him until the ORGANIZATION League.PERSON's solid speed would allow him to beat most catchers in a race and helps him excel behind the plate. His good-not-great arm strength plays up because his feet are so quick and he threw out 48 percent of basestealers in 2017. His soft hands and agility are two more assets, and he's athletic enough to handle second and third base in short stints.There was some question as to how much offense PERSON will provide after he had just one big season at ORGANIZATION and batted .238/.357/.393 in his first two pro seasons, with his strikeout rate jumping from 10 percent in college to 22 percent in pro ball. But he has taken to adjustments to add loft to his right-handed swing and has hit for average and power in Double-A this year. He also has an eye for drawing walks and has the upside of solid tools across the board, a rarity for a catcher.

The ace of a 2012 ORGANIZATION (Calif.) JC juggernaut that also included outfield prospects PERSON (now with the GPE) and PERSON (GPE), PERSON went in the fourth round of the 2012 Draft. He needed PERSON surgery midway through his first full pro season but returned last June and quickly regained his stuff. He missed the first two months of 2015 with a neck injury before returning in mid-June.PERSON's arm strength has been evident since he was a star quarterback in high school. He operates at 92-94 mph with his fastball, tops out at 96 and has heavy sink that elicits a lot of groundballs. His second option is a low-80s slider that's solid at times but flat at others.Refining his changeup will be crucial to PERSON remaining a starter, and he also needs better control. If he can't add enough polish, he could move to the bullpen and possibly turn into a set-up man.

PERSON has been able to pitch with such top college talent like A.J. PERSON, the ORGANIZATION. 6 overall pick in 2016, and PERSON, who went ORGANIZATION. 18 last June, at the ORGANIZATION of GPE. After playing a pivotal role in helping the Gators win a national title, and pitching better than PERSON in many ways, it's now PERSON's turn to be the GPE ace. At first it seemed like PERSON would have the chance to be the ORGANIZATION. 1 overall pick in the ORGANIZATION, but a slow start to his junior season knocked him down a peg.PERSON checks off all of the boxes teams are looking for out of a potential top pick. GPE and lean, he has a terrific pitcher's body that has thus far proven to be durable. He'll throw his fastball up to 95-96 mph consistently, with plus life. His slider plays well off of his fastball, a second above-average pitch he manipulates in terms of depth and velocity. His changeup continues to improve and should give him a third above-average offering. He commands the ball well, gets high marks for his makeup and is a plus competitor.Both PERSON and PERSON entered into their ORGANIZATION seasons as potential 1-1 selections, but they didn't perform quite well enough to go in that top spot, and in some ways PERSON followed suit. His stuff was bouncing back as the ORGANIZATION approached, so don't expect him to slide too far down boards.

There were high hopes for PERSON in 2015, as the ORGANIZATION jumped the right-hander with outstanding stuff and an advanced feel for pitching from the Class A Short-Season New York-Penn League up to the Class A Advanced PERSON. Elbow issues hampered him when he was on the mound, then forced him off the mound for much of the season. PERSON surgery sidelined PERSON for all of 2016.When healthy, PERSON throws his fastball up to 94 mph with really good life. He'll combine that with a solid breaking ball and an average changeup to give him three average to above-average offerings, along with the ability to command all of them. PERSON will throw his slider for strikes and miss bats with it, showing good depth with the pitch when he's throwing it right. He has confidence in his changeup, throwing it in all counts and to both sides of the plate. PERSON has posted a miniscule walk rate of six percent.PERSON should get back on a mound at some point this summer, with every expectation that he'll get back to being the starting pitching prospect he was before his injury.

In watching PERSON, the 6-foot-6 projectable right-hander, make his full-season debut in 2016, the ORGANIZATION learned two things: He did not enjoy the LOCATION in April and he is developing a strong ability to make adjustments.After allowing 17 earned runs over 9 2/3 innings in April of 2016, PERSON allowed more than three earned runs just once over his remaining 20 starts. The ORGANIZATION were pleased how he weathered -- pardon the pun -- the adversity and gained confidence from there. The biggest advancement he made was in the development of his breaking ball. Though he started to rely on it a bit too much, it has the makings of an eventual plus pitch to go along with his fastball that can touch 97-98 mph regularly. PERSON shows a feel for a decent changeup, and it could eventually be a third average or better offering. His command after those first few starts improved considerably.Big-bodied and long-armed, it will take time for PERSON to gain consistent control of his body on the mound. As he does that, his strike-throwing will improve even more. His arrow is pointing up and his ceiling is as high as any pitcher in the system.

PERSON was frustrating to scout as an amateur. He flashed plus speed, potential plus power, and plus bat speed, but also suffered through a number of nagging injuries on his way to being a speculative second round pick by the ORGANIZATION. The raw tools have still been there in pro ball but so have the nagging injuries, mostly of the hamstring and elbow variety. PERSON also hasn't shown much bat control at any point in his career, so his path to success (after staying healthy) is as a lower average hitter with some power playing a solid average center field. He'll find himself lower on this list if he doesn't stay healthy and produce this year, but there's a route for him to turn into a player along the lines of new ORGANIZATION center fielder PERSON.

An elite athlete, PERSON is a three-sport star in high school. The same athleticism that allows him to throw down dunks on the basketball court has helped him develop into a coveted right-hander. PERSON' fastball sits in the low 90s and tops out at 95 mph with excellent life. His sharp slider is his best secondary offering and has the potential to be a swing-and-miss offering. His changeup and curveball give him two more pitches that have the chance to be average or better. PERSON, a GPE recruit, has a loose, easy delivery and repeats it well. His long, lean build leads scouts to believe he could add more velocity as he gets stronger and focuses solely on baseball.

PERSON was pitching in the ORGANIZATION as a 16-year-old when the ORGANIZATION signed him in 2011. He had no trouble adjusting to pitching in the GPE and was the youngest player in the ORGANIZATION on Opening Day in 2013.PERSON throws his fastball in the low- to mid-90s with good movement. His slider is his best offspeed pitch, and his changeup shows promise. He is the nephew of former ORGANIZATION reliever PERSON, and his bloodlines seem to have helped. He has better command and more pitchability than most teenagers.PERSON underwent PERSON surgery in July 2013 and returned to the mound this July, a little less than a year later. Though he missed most of the 2014 season, he won't turn 20 until Spring Training 2015, so he has time on his side and the stuff to get back on track.

PERSON starred during three seasons at ORGANIZATION and two summers with the GPE collegiate national team, though his lower arm slot led some teams to question his long-term future as a starter. He'll both miss bats and generate ground-ball outs with it. He'll complement the heater with a hard slider. He has a changeup, but has exhibited a limited feel for it ths far. He doesn't have the cleanest delivery in the world, but nothing that raises major red flags and he's generally around the strike zone.Because of his physicality, PERSON does have a chance to start and he continued to do so effectively in 2016. But his fastball-slider combination could get him to the big leagues quickly if the ORGANIZATION decide to go that route.

The ORGANIZATION gave PERSON a $160,000 bonus in November 2011 because they believed in his bat. He spent the first three years of his career in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION before making his GPE debut this spring. He broke out in May with eight home runs -- two more than he totaled in three ORGANIZATION seasons. PERSON's carrying tool is his left-handed power to all fields. While he does have some swing and miss in his game, he also has promising feel for hitting and a willingness to draw walks when pitchers try to work around him.PERSON began his pro career as a corner outfielder before seeing action at first base in 2013 and moving there full-time the following season. He's not especially quick but has some softness to his hands and some arm strength.

If adversity is indeed a good teacher, then PERSON might be the smartest pitcher in the ORGANIZATION' system. The GPE lefty was humming along the lower levels of the Minors when an elbow injury shut him down late in 2014 and led to PERSON surgery in the spring of 2015. He missed all of that season and when he came down with mono as he was rehabbing in 2016, that season was lost as well. He returned and threw well enough in 2017 to get added to the 40-man roster in the offseason, then turned in a solid, and healthy, 2018 season in Double-A, getting invited to the ORGANIZATION in the process.PERSON is looking more and more like the starting pitching prospect with a four-pitch mix he appeared to be before the injury and illness setbacks. His fastball will sit in the low 90s, touching a tick more at times, with solid command of it. His changeup is his best secondary weapon, an above-average offspeed pitch thrown with good sink. His two breaking balls are distinct pitches, with a tight slider and more of a pure curveball he mixes in effectively. He's generally around the strike zone, and it's his overall command has improved the further removed from the disabled list he gets.A full, normal year without any further hiccups is just what the doctor ordered for the left-hander. He's getting closer to reaching his ceiling of a No. 3 or 4 starter.

PERSON raised his profile by homering off PERSON's PERSON during the summer of 2011, helping propel him into the third round of the next year's Draft. He reached Double-A at the end of his first full pro season but missed most of 2014 with a strained rotator cuff that didn't require surgery. He returned last year to hit 20 homers in the Minors, then three more during his big league debut, as well as win a silver medal with the GPE Pan American Games team.PERSON is physically imposing and his most obvious tool is his well-above-average raw power, generated by a combination of bat speed, strength and loft in his right-handed swing. He sells out for home runs by getting pull-happy and overly aggressive, which could affect his consistency at the plate and will prevent him from hitting for a high average. Once his shoulder was 100 percent again, PERSON regained his solid arm strength and quick release, which he used to erase 29 percent of basestealers in 2015. He has cleaned up his receiving since entering pro ball and gets the job done well enough to be a big league regular. He offers little speed but moves well enough behind the plate.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 5, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON made an All-Tournament Team with PERSON at the 2016 18U ORGANIZATION Day tournament. He also participated in the 2016 Area Code Games and the 2016 ORGANIZATION World Championships.The outfielder has a tall, good-looking frame and an athletic body that gives him promise. With the bat in his hands, PERSON has a straightaway stance with a strong trigger. In order to continue to improve, he could make some mechanical adjustments to shorten his stroke. In the field, PERSON has an arm that projects as average as well as solid overall defensive skills.

PERSON led the ORGANIZATION with a 1.17 ERA in 2012, and PERSON made him the highest player drafted from GPE in the '13 PERSON. PERSON teamed with PERSON, the team's first-round pick, during their professional debut, and the two will be closely linked for the foreseeable future.PERSON throws his fastball in the low 90s, with good sinking action. The ORGANIZATION blew so far past their allotment during the 2015-16 international signing period that their four bonus pool slots became meaningless, so they traded all of them. He also mixes in a fringy cutter and changeup.PERSON's delivery creates some deception without detracting from his ability to throw strikes. He's an extreme flyball pitcher with little margin for error, so he's vulnerable to home runs. While he doesn't have a high ceiling, PERSON could prove to be a solid No. 5 starter or long reliever at the highest level.

A catcher at the ORGANIZATION of GPE, GPE was one of the best pure hitters among a relatively weak college bat crop in the 2016 GPE. The ORGANIZATION moved GPE to first base upon signing and that's likely his long-term home. While he did play some first at GPE, he was a bit rough around the bag during his debut, though the ORGANIZATION are pleased with the progress he's already made with his footwork.GPE is the kind of college bat that should be able to move relatively quickly through a system. With a bit of a logjam at first base and ORGANIZATION, the ORGANIZATION could have an embarrassment of riches when GPE shows he is ready.

The younger brother of GPE prospect PERSON, 'Bo' is a better athlete with similar feel to hit, but less raw power. He has the neccesary twitch and just enough pure arm strength to catch as long as his throws becaome more accurate. There's a subsection of teams who like him better at third base because they think he'll move more quickly through the minors by avoiding the developmental burdens of catching and/or because the physical grind of catching often dilutes offensive production. PERSON is athletic enough for this, as well. Even if PERSON's in-game power manifests itself as doubles, he profiles at either spot.

GPE had an unusual start to his pro career, with paperwork issues stemming from his childhood in GPE earning him a one-year suspension from ORGANIZATION and only a $200,000 bonus despite loud tools before signing. Credit the ORGANIZATION for staying on top of GPE and pouncing one his suspension was over, as his three plus tools (raw power, speed and arm strength) are quickly obvious even to amateur observers. The only question on GPE is on his contact ability, as he will show scout extremely varied looks--some think he'll get to his power but just with plenty of swing and miss, while others question if he'll ever make enough contact to be an everyday player. No one disputes the sky-high ceiling and the ORGANIZATION have rebuffed many efforts of other clubs to trade for GPE, but the variance in his possible outcomes may be the widest among any hitter on this list.

The ORGANIZATION gave seven-figure bonuses to seven position players as they spent more than $17 million on talent during the 2014-15 international signing period. They also quietly signed PERSON out of the ORGANIZATION in December 2014 for $10,000. Since then, he has developed into one of the hardest throwers and most intriguing arms in the system.PERSON's fastball jumped from 90-93 mph in 2015 to 94-97 mph last year. He topped out at 99 mph and has more velocity to come once he adds strength to his lanky 6-foot-8 frame. His size and long arms create unusual angle and plane, making it even harder to catch up to his heater.PERSON's curveball and changeup both show the potential to become at least solid offerings, with the latter more consistent because his long arm action sometimes prevents him from staying on top of his breaking ball. Considering his size and youth, he does a decent job of repeating his delivery and throwing strikes, but he still has a ways to go. Unless he adds more polish, he'll end up in the bullpen with late-inning upside.

PERSON PERSON's eyes lit up when he was told that the last name of the player he was set to announce as the ORGANIZATION' second round pick is pronounced 'bro', a word GPE uses as linguistic filler the way most of us use 'um' or 'like' more than we want to. Two-way duty in college means PERSON is currently raw as a receiver and a hitter, but he has a rare opportunity to become an impact bat behind the plate if he can start recognizing pro breaking stuff. If not, the mound is a terrific fallback option.

PERSON ORGANIZATION produced big-bodied corner infielders who went early in the last two Drafts. While PERSON didn't go in the first round as PERSON did with the Pirates in 2016, he commanded an over-slot $2 million bonus as a second-rounder in June. PERSON moves well for his size but still grades as a well-below-average runner. He has gotten better defensively with more reps at first base and has a strong arm well-suited to turn 3-6-3 double plays. With first base and DH as his only possible positions, he'll have to produce at the plate.

GPE is a generational on-mound athlete whose 2018 season ended with an elbow sprain. A strong two month run of starts in the early summer culminated in a 7-inning shutout start (2 H, 0 BB, 10 K, it took 69 pitches) on July 2 at FACILITY followed by his feat of strength at the ORGANIZATION.  Eleven days later, GPE's season was over. He had a ORGANIZATION injection and rehabbed the sprained UCL in GPE with broad plans to start throwing during the winter and so far, he seems on track for spring training. GPE's development was already pretty likely to be slow. He was able to throw strikes with that upper-90s fastball in high school, but his breaking ball was just okay, and he had no use for a changeup, so both of his secondary pitches were behind other pitchers in the class. PERSON needed to project heavily on GPE's stuff to buy him as a top five pick, but he's such an exceptional athlete and success-oriented person that many of them did. Focusing solely on pitching for the first time, GPE's slider improved in 2018. His ceiling will be dictated by the continued development of his secondary stuff.
GPE is a polsihed defensive catcher who has been of interest to teams in trade discussions with GPE for each of the last two seasons. He projects as a well-rounded everyday catcher.

PERSON became just the third No. 1 pick in GPE history not to sign when he spurned the ORGANIZATION in 2014 after a post-GPE physical raised concerns about his left elbow and caused PERSON to cut its original bonus offer of $6.5 million to $5 million. PERSON passed on signing and enrolled in ORGANIZATION's (PERSON, Fla.) post-graduate program in 2015, only to leave his first outing with elbow pain that required subsequent PERSON surgery. Thrilled to find PERSON still on the board halfway into the first round, the GPE selected him 17th overall, and he signed for $2,513,280. He made his highly anticipated pro debut in June 2016, albeit with mixed results, and he has yet to get back on track in 2017 with PERSON County.PERSON's potential for three plus pitches made him an elite prospect as an amateur, but his stuff has played closer to average since making his return to the mound last summer. His fastball, which touched 97 mph in high school, sits mostly between 87-91 mph, while his curveball remains his best offering, a potential above-average pitch. He also has a changeup that he throws with late fade and tumbling action. Evaluators have said that he's lost some athleticism, which has led to problems in repeating his delivery and at times a complete lack of control. Though the GPE were pleased with their left-hander's progress in 2016, PERSON's progressed has backed up considerably this season in full-season ball. Though he still has a high ceiling, many scouts now view PERSON as no more than a No. 5 starter, provided he regains his feel for the strike zone.

There may not have been a prospect in baseball who saw the wheels fall off more than PERSON in 2011. ORGANIZATION goes to the ORGANIZATION for allowing the lefty to go home to work with his old pitching coach, and PERSON deserves credit for coming back and throwing better upon his return. His 2012 season showed just how good his stuff is and what he needs to work on: He led the GPE League in strikeouts and walks. He can reach back and hit 95 mph on his fastball, though he sits in the low 90s as he continues to work on his pitchability. His fastball has some good life as well. His curve will show flashes of being a real weapon with tight bite to it. His changeup is inconsistent, but he continues to work on it. If he can continue to improve his consistency in the strike zone, he's still young enough to get back on the right track toward the ORGANIZATION' rotation.Bernie PERSON's scouting report Â»

After a year of sitting 90-94, GPE's fastball velocity fluctuated pretty significantly both start-to-start and within individual games, often resting in the upper-80s like it did while he was in college. But he was also up to 95 at times, even reaching back for that kind of heat late in his starts. Some of the drop in velocity may have been artificial, a result of GPE working more on sinking and cutting his fastball rather than just throwing it hard. He's a plus on-mound athlete who we anticipate will be a sinker/changeup No. 4 or 5 starter relatively soon. His season ended in mid-July due to an oblique strain.

PERSON was regarded as one of the best hitters in the international signing class of 2011 and the ORGANIZATION have pushed him aggressively so far. He's responded well and led short-season Bluefield in home runs as an 18-year old in 2013.PERSON is a natural hitter with a knack for putting the bat on the ball. His exceptional feel for the barrel makes him a good bad-ball hitter and difficult to strike out. He creates good bat speed and has a surprising amount of raw power in his small frame.Defensively, PERSON has good hands and is a capable shortstop. He's a below-average runner, however, leading some scouts to think he is destined to move to third base. His bat looks like it'll be good enough to profile no matter what position he plays.

The ORGANIZATION took redshirt sophomores with consecutive early-round picks in the 2016 Draft, and second-rounder GPE outperformed supplemental first-rounder PERSON in their debuts by posting a spotless ERA with 30 strikeouts in 22 innings. GPE had PERSON surgery after graduating from high school in 2013 and saw his velocity and prospect stock soar after he moved into PERSON's rotation last spring. He went 65th overall, making him the highest PERSON pick since PERSON went in the same spot in 1995, and signed for a well below-slot $590,800.GPE opened 2016 with his fastball sitting around 90 mph but started hitting the mid-90s toward the end of the college season and worked at 92-96 in pro ball. His heater plays up because of its natural life, but his best pitch is an upper-80s cutter that can be unhittable. His downer curveball should be at least a solid offering, while his changeup is more of a work in progress. With his athleticism, sound delivery and strong build, GPE has the necessary ingredients to remain a starting pitcher. He has no trouble throwing strikes but still is refining his command, which continues to improve as he gets more innings and puts his elbow reconstruction further behind him.

Signed out of the ORGANIZATION in 2011, PERSON was doing exactly what organizations want to see from pitching prospects: Getting better with age and more experience as he moved up the ladder. After having no problems handling the ORGANIZATION State League in 2016 and finishing things off with a playoff win in Double-A GPE, he was set to start the year back in GPE, but an 80-game suspension levied at the start of the 2017 season for a performance-enhancing drug put some of that progress in question.PERSON is more or less a three-pitch guy who relies on mixing his pitches well, though he has seen an uptick in the velocity of his fastball. He was up to 95 mph consistently at the end of last summer. He can spin a good curveball and he'll even mix in an occasional slider. His changeup looks like it could give him another Major League average pitch. PERSON's secondary pitches have improved enough that it keeps hitters honest and allows him to get swings and misses on his fastball.PERSON exudes confidence on the mound and stays around the strike zone. His mix is better than any one of his pitches, and he was looking like a future mid-rotation starter, though he'll have to prove himself all over again following his suspension.

When PERSON inexplicably fell to the bottom of the first round of the 2016 Draft, the Cardinals were more than happy to be the beneficiaries, signing the ORGANIZATION State standout to a slightly above pick value bonus of $2 million. He rewarded their faith in him by going straight to Double-A for his full-season debut, earning both PERSON All-Star and Pitcher of the Year honors while getting a late bump up to Triple-A.While some worried about his delivery and arm action pointing to a future in the bullpen, the Cardinals love PERSON's durability and pitchability. His fastball will sit in the mid-90s and he can touch 97 mph, throwing the heater with heavy sink to get a ton of groundball outs. His slider has cutter-like action and is a plus pitch and he's separated out a curve that he showed strides with during his first full season. His changeup should give him a fourth at least PERSON average offering.PERSON can still stand to refine his overall command and despite the good stuff, he didn't miss many bats, though the Cardinals aren't worried about that and feel his stuff will play as a starter. They do know that his fastball-slider combination will also play well in a bullpen if there's a need in GPE.

The ORGANIZATION didn't have a first-round pick in the 2010 Draft, but that's not something that bothers them all that much thanks to the development of GPE, their first selection that June. The 2012 Futures PERSON was the youngest pitcher in the LOCATION and was dominant in the first half, though he did falter in the second half. He has the makings of an excellent three-pitch mix, with a plus fastball, complemented by a curve and changeup, both of which have the chance to be at least above-average. He still needs to tighten up his command, but his athleticism - he was a basketball standout in high school - should allow him to do improve on that and become the frontline starter people project him as.Bernie PERSON's scouting report Â»

Relations between the GPE and GPE may be improving, leading to more open markets, but the D-backs didn't wait for that, making two big free agent signings. PERSON was the big one; GPE ranks No. 2, though only his bonus of more than $8 million counts towards their international spending total. PERSON thinks GPE was worth going way over their allotted pool and incurring the penalties that come with it. The 6-foot-3 right-hander has a solid three-pitch mix, starting with a fastball he can get up to 95-96 mph. While his breaking ball is inconsistent, it has the chance to be at least an above-average curve ball. He has a good feel for a changeup and projects to be PERSON average as well. GPE stays around the strike zone with all three pitches. There's projection in GPE's 6-foot-3, 190-pound frame, so there might be more to come stuff-wise. The 22-year-old might not take very long to be big league ready, with an upside of a No. 3-type starter in the future.

When the ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON out of the GSP high school ranks in 2011 and gave him an over-slot deal to sign him away from GPE, they knew it might take a while for the big right-hander to figure things out.So there was no sense of panic when PERSON struggled with his first taste of full-season ball at age 19 in 2013. He still has a good chance to develop into a solid starting pitcher, with a fastball in the 91-94 mph range, a curve that can be a big breaking ball with bite and a feel for a changeup, though it's behind the other two pitches. PERSON struggles to repeat his ability, and he will need to learn better balance to improve his command.PERSON is still figuring out both his body and his stuff. When he does that, the end result could be a part of a big league rotation.

The best junior college prospect in the 2016 Draft, PERSON took a huge step forward last spring after adding strength to his already physical frame. The result was a breakout sophomore campaign for the right-hander, who went 12-1 and posted a 1.22 ORGANIZATION in 13 starts with 117 strikeouts in 103 innings, ranking among the national junior college leaders in wins, ORGANIZATION and whiffs. In June, PERSON became the second-highest drafted player in GPE A. Logan (Ill.) CC history when the ORGANIZATION selected him in the second round.After topping out at 93-94 mph in 2015, PERSON now consistently works at 91-94 mph with his fastball and has hit 98 in short stints. His slider has gotten harder and sharper as well, showing flashes of becoming a solid pitch. He also has made strides with his changeup, enhancing his chances of remaining a starter.With his 6-foot-6 frame and three-quarters delivery, PERSON creates good angle with his pitches. He has no problem filling the strike zone, though he'll need to improve the command of his fastball and the consistency of his secondary pitches to make it as a big league starter. If he can't, he has promise as a late-inning reliever.

After spending a second-round pick and $670,000 to sign PERSON out of high school in 2009, the ORGANIZATION deployed him mainly as a reliever for three seasons before trading him and fringe infield prospect PERSON to the ORGANIZATION for PERSON in December 2011. PERSON shifted to the rotation with his new organization and reached Double-A at age 22 before PERSON surgery cost him most of 2014 and a lat injury knocked him out for most of 2015. He bounced back to reach the big leagues in 2016, again back largely in a relief role. The ORGANIZATION sent him to the ORGANIZATION in December. A big-bodied right-hander in the mold of GPE, PERSON had a so-so fastball in the past but returned from surgery with more velocity, working at 91-94 mph and touching 97. He flashes a plus slider, but it's mostly an average pitch, while his curveball and changeup are effective at times. PERSON' 270-pound frame doesn't lend itself to an athletic delivery, so the ORGANIZATION thought his stuff could play better in shorter stints, and they moved him to the bullpen in late May as a result. He did have success as a starter in the upper Minors, so it's not out of the question the ORGANIZATION will give him another shot at making the rotation.

GPE runs well enough to stay in center field but his bat speed is below average which limits his offensive impact and, thusly, his role. He projects as a fourth outfielder, though his patience, if refined, might allow him to reach base enough to play every day.

PERSON has a power forward build at 6-foot-8 and is an extreme power projection long shot. Scouts see 65-grade future raw power and a chance to stay in center field, so PERSON may be the heir to the ORGANIZATION young adult son hitting prospect throne.

GPE has 40+ FV tier stuff and 35 FV tier control. He pumps easy mid-90s gas, his fastball has tough-to-hit, downward angle, and his breaking ball has vertical action, depth, and is consistently plus. When dialed in, GPE looks like an unhittable, high-leverage relief prospect, and he struck out a ludicrous 46% of his 2018 foes -- nearly two batters per inning -- last year. He's a short strider who sometimes fails to clear his front side, causing his pitches to sail. His 2018 was much better from a strike-throwing perspective than 2017, but he still walked 12% of hitters faced, and he's very fly ball prone due to where his fastball lives in the hitting zone. There's some headwind, but also, utterly dominant stuff. GPE is a good bet to be a 40-man add after the 2019 season, so there's about an 18-month window for player dev to impact him before he debuts.

One of the best high school position prospects in the 2013 Draft, PERSON saw his chances of going in the first round disappear when he tore the meniscus in his right knee in a season-opening doubleheader. The ORGANIZATION made a serious run at him after selecting him in the 22nd round, but they couldn't divert him from attending ORGANIZATION. After three strong seasons for the ORGANIZATION, the ORGANIZATION made PERSON the highest-drafted position player to come out of ORGANIZATION since PERSON in 2005 by selecting him in the second round in June. PERSON does a nice job of controlling the strike zone and using the opposite field. He has the bat speed and strength to provide average power and shows it during batting practice, though his current approach is geared more to line-drive contact. PERSON has solid speed but isn't as quick as he was in high school, when he set a GPE national 18-and-under team record with five steals in one game.Though he has lost a step, PERSON gets the job done in center field and exhibits good jumps and routes on fly balls. He has a decent arm and makes accurate throws. Meanwhile, PERSON's game continues to draw parallels to that his head coach at ORGANIZATION, PERSON, the ORGANIZATION. 1 overall pick in 1995.

The GPE right-hander struggled with arm trouble in the early stages of his career, but things started to click for him in 2010 as he reached Double-A as a starter. While he did get to Triple-A in the rotation in 2011, his performance was not as consistent, so the ORGANIZATION moved him into the bullpen in 2012. The results were positive as he began the year in Double-A and ended it in GPE. The older brother of ORGANIZATION prospect PERSON, PERSON uses a very good two-pitch power arsenal now that he's in relief. He'll touch 98 mph with his fastball that has some sinking action to it. When he's in sync, delivery-wise, his slider can be above average. He struggled with his command during his big league debut but should get the opportunity to show he belongs full-time.

The ORGANIZATION made PERSON the highest-drafted position player in GPE State history when they selected him in the third round in 2011. He led the LOCATION with a .405 on-base percentage and 55 walks in 2014. The ORGANIZATION acquired him in January as part of their return for PERSON. PERSON has a smooth left-handed swing and exhibits a good understanding of the strike zone. But his swing has a tendency to get long, leading to a high strikeout rate and hindering his ability to tap into his raw power. He has developed into a solid defender as a professional, with the strong arm and soft hands necessary for the hot corner. PERSON will need to improve his consistency at the plate to reach his potential, but his raw power and defensive skills give him a chance to contribute full-time in the ORGANIZATION, something he was called upon to do for a brief spell in June.
Surprised many with his game power in 2018, lean athletic center field type.

GPE was a two-way prospect in high school before a shoulder injury ended his future on the mound. It didn't hinder his ability in in the outfield, however, and his above-average speed and athleticism make him a prototypical center fielder. He covers ground well and has shown improving outfield instincts. At the plate, GPE has quick hands and a smooth left-handed swing. In order to reach his potential, he will have to improve his approach. He has surprising pop in his wiry frame but has a tendency to try to hit home runs too often. PERSON hasn't had an easy transition to the ORGANIZATION, his raw tools still give him the chance to develop into a solid everyday player.
Unsigned by the ORGANIZATION after the 2018 draft, PERSON's velocity spiked into the mid-90s. He'll bump 98 and has a big, athletic frame and fluid delivery, but PERSON will need to develop the rest.

Signed for $75,000 as a 26th-round pick in 2013, PERSON, a GPE native, enjoyed a breakout campaign in '16, highlighted by an impressive second-half in Double-A, before being acquired by PERSON along with PERSON, PERSON and PERSON for PERSON in December 2016. PERSON made additional strides in his first season as a GPE, splitting the year between Double-A PERSON and Triple-A Colorado Springs while representing the World Team in the ORGANIZATION All-Star PERSON along the way. The ORGANIZATION added PERSON to their 40-man roster in November, only to lose him for much of the 2018 season after he underwent surgery to repair a torn ACL in May. PERSON can do a little bit of everything on the diamond. At the dish, he exhibits excellent hand-eye coordination and a quick right-handed bat, allowing him to generate barreled, line-drive contact with relative ease. Those qualities along with his solid approach lead scouts to project him as at least an average hitter. PERSON also has had his power tick up as he's grown stronger, and it's resulted in improved home-run totals in each of his five seasons and a career-high eight in 2017. However, hitting for consistent power will never be a part of his game, and he's more likely to be a source of doubles and triples. PERSON's extra-base-hit totals are also a product of the plus speed that has netted him at least 30 steals in three straight seasons.PERSON is a true middle infielder, one with quick hands and feet as well as the arm strength to make plays from either side of the bag. He split time in 2017 between both shortstop and second base, showing well at both spots, and it's fair to think he'll be able to play whatever position the ORGANIZATION ask of him. GPE will regularly show a plus fastball/breaker combo, but there's some effort and relief risk. This spring he's dialed down the stuff a bit and the strike throwing is better.

He won PERSON in each of the last two years and made his big league debut this June, only to see his season end with surgery on his non-throwing shoulder a month later.Defensively, PERSON is ready to play regularly in the Majors right now. His receiving and blocking seemingly improve every year, and he gets the most out of his strong arm with a quick release and accurate throws. ORGANIZATION officials love his leadership skills and his ability to run a pitching staff.PERSON had the worst offensive year of his pro career in 2017, batting .241/.275/.323 in Double-A, and didn't hit much better this year. He continued to make contact and exhibit a good two-strike approach, but PERSON will try to get him to drive more balls and add some loft to his compact right-handed swing. More selectivity also could help because he rarely walks.

When the spring began, GPE was one of the few two-way prospects in the ORGANIZATION class that may have had a split camp over whether he should hit or pitch. As the ORGANIZATION drew closer, it became increasingly apparent that most teams saw his future on the mound.As a pitcher, GPE projects as a No. 3 starter at the big league level. While not the biggest pitcher in the world, he does have a compact and efficient delivery. His three-quarters delivery gives him good angle and movement on his fastball, which averages 89-91 mph and has reached 94. He could add more velocity if he focuses on pitching full-time, and he also features a promising curveball and a changeup with some life.The athleticism that made him a solid outfield prospect, and would help him be a potential two-way player at ORGANIZATION, should aid him in his development as a pitcher, though the ORGANIZATION winner for the ORGANIZATION team at the Under PERSON All-America Game at FACILITY last August will have to get past some makeup concerns to keep his ORGANIZATION stock up.

Built like an old school in-the-box ORGANIZATION safety, GPE is a physical dynamo whose entire offensive profile is undercut by his extreme propensity to hit the ball into the ground. GPE has a nearly 60% ground ball rate over each of the last two years. He does a lot of other stuff: he has raw power, great feel for the strike zone, and is a plus runner, with well-regarded makeup. The quality of his in-game contact is simply not good right now. Stiffness in GPE's hitting hands could mean this issue is less about a swing change than it is about innate talent.

While ORGANIZATION plays shortstop for his high school team in GPE, most see him as a third baseman at the next level because of his lack of speed and range.The good news is he has the hands and arm to work fine at the hot corner, and he might have the bat to profile there as well. He uses the whole field now with a line-drive swing, and while his power is mostly to the gaps now, there's more to come as he matures. He plays the game hard and is aggressive in all areas, which scouts love to see.ORGANIZATION's makeup combined with his hitting ability should garner plenty of interest on GPE day.

In the not-too-distant past, a player like PERSON would have been overlooked by many teams because of his size. The combination of more organizations embracing analytics and the success of players like PERSON, not to mention the superb performance of the 5-foot-7 infielder, had PERSON poised to perhaps be the top college position player taken in the 2018 Draft. A broken wrist at the start of the season slowed him down, but he returned in April swinging a hot bat.While PERSON might have been more of a gut feel kind of player for scouts, he now has track record on top of being a scout favorite. Analytics departments love him because of his approach at the plate that led to more walks than strikeouts in 2017, and while he doesn't have a ton of over-the-fence power, he makes consistent hard contact and is a legitimate extra-base threat. His speed and instincts should allow him to continue to be a base stealer.While PERSON has played mostly second base in deference to PERSON at FACILITY, some feel he could handle shortstop if need be. If not, he has the chance to be a ORGANIZATION caliber second baseman in the future. Even with the injury, he should land squarely in the top 10 in June.

After his strong sophomore season at ORGANIZATION, scouts were excited to see what PERSON could do to raise his profile as a power-hitting third baseman. A transfer to ORGANIZATION made it tougher for scouts to evaluate his performance, though PERSON certainly did his part by hitting .308/.351/.639 with 20 home runs and 15 doubles. It's that offensive upside that led the ORGANIZATION to take him in the second round of the 2016 Draft and then sign him for $1.15 million. PERSON made an immediate impact after signing, hitting .400/.452/.552 in GPE Pioneer League en route a quick promotion to Class A Wisconsin, followed by an Opening Day assignment to Class A Advanced Carolina for his first full season.PERSON has impact potential from the left side of the plate, with natural feel to hit, a solid approach and plus raw power that could make him a middle-of-the-order bat at maturity. Defensively, PERSON's athleticism should help him stick at third base, where he has a strong arm -- one that fired 93-94 mph fastballs as PERSON's closer -- that's ideal for the position. He also received positive reviews as a shortstop during the fall instructional league, highlighting PERSON's overall athleticism and versatility.The ORGANIZATION have long been trying to develop a homegrown third baseman, and while it's early in his career, PERSON, with his high offensive ceiling, could be the team's long-term answer.

An intriguing two-way prospect and athlete, PERSON had middling tools on both sides of the ball but had one of the biggest, most projectable frames in the draft. PERSON hoped he'd emerge during his junior spring, but PERSON fractured his elbow early in the season and was done for the year. He'll be a tough sign, but teams who think he could be a true two-way player may be motivated to pay him. He'll sit in the upper-80s on the mound and has a great curveball. Offensively, PERSON already has considerable power and will likely grow into more. He's also a massive, athletic target at first base.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 21, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON, a physical specimen out of PERSON, is an impressive right-handed hitter. He earned a nomination to the ORGANIZATION All-Region 1st Team as well as an appearance on the 17U ORGANIZATION All-Tournament team. GPE has also played in a plethora of diversity events, including the FACILITY in 2015, the 2015 High PERSON, the Breakthrough Series in 2016 and the ORGANIZATION. The high school outfielder has all the raw tools for success. GPE has rhythm at the plate, and the ball jumps off the bat when he makes clean contact. He shows off a big leg kick and his hands have plenty of life to accompany his athletic frame.

Projectable and physical left-handers with the potential to have mid-90s fastballs aren't easy to find. That's why PERSON, who has had an up-and-down spring, has garnered so much attention despite his inconsistencies and the difficulty it might take to sign him.At times, PERSON has been up to 94 mph this spring with his fastball, though he has had trouble maintaining it both within starts and from outing to outing. His 2-to-8 breaking ball is at least average when he's on, but he tends to come around it a lot. He tends not to use his front side well enough in his delivery, leaving his elbow out on his breaking ball and throwing it mostly with his arm only. His changeup has improved somewhat, but he'll slow down his body occasionally when throwing it and it's often not firm enough, serving more as a soft different look he throws out of the zone than a true weapon. While there are flaws, PERSON does have a good body and his arm works well, with considerable upside that could be unlocked. The bigger issue might be his signability, with his commitment to ORGANIZATION likely to be a tough one to break.

GPE's top high school pitching prospect in 2014, PERSON turned down the ORGANIZATION as a 23rd-rounder to attend PERSON. He has one of the most powerful arms in the LOCATION, though his inability to consistently harness it has led the ORGANIZATION to keep him in the bullpen for most of the last three years. He showcased some of the best stuff among PERSON starters last summer yet still profiles as a reliever, and his stock took a hit when he was sidelined with a forearm strain in May.In short stints, PERSON works in the upper 90s and can reach 99 mph with nice sink on his fastball. In longer outings on the GPE, he operated at 92-96 mph. He also can overpower hitters with a slider that reaches the high 80s, though it stands out more for its velocity than its sharpness.PERSON fiddled with a changeup as a GPE starter but it needs a lot of work and he doesn't use it as a reliever. He doesn't have a history of throwing a lot of strikes, and he gets hit harder than he should because he doesn't command his pitches. Yet if a pro team can polish him up, he has the pure stuff to turn into a big league closer.

PERSON established himself as a top Draft prospect with his impressive play in the summer of 2012, both for the LOCATION ORGANIZATION and in several showcases. He continued to play well this spring and ultimately joined PERSON and PERSON as GPE high schoolers drafted in the first round. PERSON played shortstop and led off in high school, but scouts think he will add muscle to his lean, athletic frame and develop a prototypical third baseman's profile. For now, the ORGANIZATION are playing him at both third base and shortstop. His strong arm and soft hands will play at either position. Offensively, PERSON makes consistent contact and generates good bat speed. That mostly translates into gap power now, but as he gets stronger, he could develop solid power. PERSON is an excellent athlete and has plenty of upside.

Bleday was an interesting but low-to-mid-six-figure two-way prospect out of a GPE panhandle high school, with mostly average tools on the mound and at the plate. He gave up pitching and began to emerge as a power threat at ORGANIZATION as an underclassman, then had a coming out party on the ORGANIZATION and early this spring, jumping into the top 10. He slowly climbed up from there as his quirky setup seemed less problematic as he torched the ORGANIZATION with a flat BB/K rate and 25 homers while also offering more than just a cursory level of outfield defense.

GPE two-pitch combo in the draft, showing two 70-grade pitches in his mid-90's heater that hit 98 and 3000+ rpm slider over the summer. This spring he was set to get his first extended look in the rotation and his velocity was mostly in the 80's without a clear reason. Rumors are it's believed to be a non-surgical nerve issue but some teams doubt that's the solution.

The ORGANIZATION used their first overall pick (in the second round) in the 2013 Draft on PERSON, an athletic and projectable right-hander from the ORGANIZATION prep ranks. He was eased into pro ball, spending two seasons in GPE ball before finally advancing to full-season Class A Wisconsin in 2015 and pitching well there. PERSON continued to make strides the following year, reaching the ORGANIZATION State League, but had his entire 2017 campaign wiped out by PERSON surgery that also cost him a portion of the '18 season. After struggling as starter upon his return from a 22-month layoff, PERSON was moved to the bullpen in 2019 and immediately took to the new role, showing improved velocity and a knack for missing bats at ORGANIZATION en route to a Futures Game selection in July. As a starter, PERSON operated with a low-90s fastball and flashed a plus breaking ball. But after tacking on some muscle while recovering from surgery, he's sitting at 95-98 mph out of the 'pen and at times touching 100 mph. He's learned to be aggressive with his heater, throwing it with late life that enables him to consistently beat hitters up in the zone His changeup features a 12-13 mph demarcation in velocity off of his fastball and has emerged as his best secondary weapon post-surgery, while his mid- to upper-80s slider gives him a third Major League-caliber offering. His control has improved along with stuff, though he still has gains to make with his command.The physical strength PERSON added during his rehab process has made him a more durable pitcher, and he's had no issues working multiple innings in 2019. The ORGANIZATION view him as potential multi-inning weapon out of the bullpen, and it's a safe bet that they'll add PERSON to their 40-man roster this offseason so as to protect him from the Rule 5 Draft.

PERSON had one of the best arms in the 2019 Draft. PERSON and athletic despite being quite small, he holds 94-97 deep into games and has touched 100. He can make his fastball ride or tail, and he uses it very frequently. His secondaries are not as nasty, but they're workable and flash average right now. There's a lot pointing to a relief role here because of the size, delivery (PERSON's arm action is very long) and the reality that two pitches need to develop for him to start, but the fastball give him a chance to be a high-leverage or multi-inning reliever.

PERSON's ORGANIZATION career started slowly, but he was the Most Outstanding Player in the 2014 College World Series, then helped the ORGANIZATION get back to the championship series again in 2015 en route to becoming the ORGANIZATION. 1 pick in the GPE. He signed right at the deadline for the highest bonus in the class, $6.5 million, still well below the assigned pick value. His debut was delayed after getting hit by a ORGANIZATION pitch during a simulated game, though he did return to get in 22 FACILITY games. He was the top prospect sent to the ORGANIZATION in the huge ORGANIZATION deal at the 2015 Winter Meetings.The top college position player in the GPE class, PERSON moved from second base to shortstop for his junior season and showed everyone he can stay there. Most scouts believe he has the quickness and arm strength to stay at the position long-term, even though he hadn't played there since he was a GPE high schooler in 2012, when the ORGANIZATION drafted him in the 38th round. PERSON is a technically sound hitter who fits at the top of his lineup with his on-base ability and speed. He showed as a junior that there might be PERSON average power in his bat as well. His makeup is off the charts and universally praised by coaches and scouts.

There's a lot going on in GPE's delivery, with twists and turns and some deep tilt in the back. But the leverage he achieves produces fastballs up to 97 mph and breaking balls with depth and bite. Once he fills out his lanky 6-foot-4 frame and develops more consistency, he could have two above-average pitches.GPE's fastball already sits in the low 90s and he still has a lot of projection remaining. When he stays on top of his breaking ball, it has slider velocity and curveball break. At the Under PERSON All-America Game at FACILITY in GPE, he fanned PERSON, the 2014 PERSON's top high school position prospect, on three straight breakers.GPE's changeup and control are still works in progress, though he's doing a better job of filling the strike zone.

PERSON had put his 50-game suspension for marijuana in 2016 behind him, making a huge impact in the big leagues in '16, both as a starter and out of the bullpen.
