He was going to be counted on to have a large role on the 2017 Cardinals' pitching staff but instead will spend the year rehabbing after being diagnosed with a torn UCL in his pitching elbow in February and undergoing PERSON surgery.When he's healthy, PERSON is arguable the best pitching prospect in the game, with his combination of elite stuff and missing bats all pointing to a future as a frontline starter. His fastball sits in the mid-to-upper-90s comfortably and he can reach back for more, hitting triple digits at times, something that happened consistently in relief outings. He backs that up with a nasty curve he'll throw in the upper 70s that also elicits swings and misses. PERSON actually threw his improving changeup, 88-90 mph, more frequently than his breaking ball during his time in the big leagues, with tremendous success.Command had been the only thing that had held PERSON back, with a walk rate of 4.5 per nine innings in his career, though most felt that would improve over time. The track record for ORGANIZATION surgery recovery is good, but it's going to take time for PERSON to build himself back into the star all envisioned.

PERSON helped fuel ORGANIZATION's PERSON Series championship in 2014 and runner-up finish in 2015. The ORGANIZATION drafted him in the third round in June and signed him for $554,100, and he made his full-season debut in 2016 with PERSON. While he doesn't have a plus tool, PERSON is an athletic player who can do a little bit of everything. His best and attribute is probably his power, which arrived in 2015 as he tied for the ORGANIZATION lead with 15 homers after going homerless in the year prior. PERSON's power doesn't come naturally, though, because his left-handed swing gets long and keeps him from making consistent contact when he aims for the fences. Combine that with an aggressive approach, and it's easy to understand why his strikeout rate spiked in 2015 between the college and pro ball.With average speed and arm strength, PERSON probably fits best in right field, where he played in college and in his pro debut. He's an instinctual defender with good range, and he's worked hard to improve his routes since turning pro.

PERSON established himself as one of the top hitters in the 2011 international crop while leading his GPE team to the ORGANIZATION World Series junior division title and playing in the Under PERSON All-America Game the summer before. When the ORGANIZATION signed him for $3.45 million and PERSON for $4.95 million on the same day, the consensus was that PERSON was the superior prospect. It hasn't played out that way, though he had his best pro season in 2015 and is putting up even better numbers this year.Unlike a lot of GPE' better position prospects, PERSON stands out more with his hitting ability than his raw power. He makes consistent line-drive contact, though he could use more patience at the plate. PERSON has the size and leverage to hit for average power once he gets stronger and learns to put more backspin on balls. PERSON is limited to first base because he's a well-below-average runner who lacks quick-twitch athleticism. He has put in a lot of time working on his defense and presents a big target at first base.

This is another reliever who, based on usage patterns, it appears is being developed for some kind of muti-inning role, perhaps to follow the opener. PERSON was acquired from GPE for PERSON, and after the ORGANIZATION had taken his early-career development slowly (PERSON was a raw college arm from GPE), the ORGANIZATION hit the gas pedal and quickly moved him to GPE in May. He thrived there, typically throwing 35 to 50 pitches once every three to five days. Most of those pitches are mid-90s fastballs that play up due to big extension, while some are above-average sliders. 
On paper, this reads like a standard two-pitch middle reliever, and for that reason, it's fair to question whether PERSON's usage might be caricaturing his velocity, and if his fastball would be this hard on back-to-back days, or if his usage would be more variable. But if this is just how PERSON is going to use him, then this is the stuff. PERSON threw 78 innings in 38 games. His four starts were some of his shortest outings. It's possible PERSON's usage has been for developmental reasons, but we tend to think he was being prepared for a fairly distinctive role before elbow trouble sidelined him for much of 2019, before he was ultimately traded as a PTBNL in the ORGANIZATION deal..

PERSON is a physical specimen, and scouts love his tools and potential.A plus runner, the young outfielder moves well for his size and frame. He has shown the ability to read and react well to balls on defense and has wowed scouts with his overall athletic ability. PERSON makes all of the routine plays in the outfield and his arm is playable in center field. That said, he could eventually move to right field.PERSON has shown raw power and is viewed as work in progress at the plate by some scouts, in large part because he needs to improve his timing on breaking balls and offspeed pitches. There are no major flaws in PERSON's game and he has the potential to be a breakout star in the class. PERSON like PERSON's makeup. He just needs more reps and game action.PERSON, who is related to Olympic legend PERSON of the GPE, trains with PERSON, PERSON and PERSON at ORGANIZATION in GPE. The D-backs are the favorite to sign him.

When the ORGANIZATION realized PERSON, a high school shortstop from GPE, wouldn't be around for their second selection in the 2014 Draft, they went ahead and nabbed him at ORGANIZATION. 24 overall.PERSON is an athletic shortstop with a very good chance of staying at the premium position. A switch-hitter with a projectable body, PERSON is a better hitter from the left side right now. There isn't much power at the moment, but he does have room to add strength to his frame. PERSON's best offensive tool will always be his speed, which plays well on both sides of the ball. He has the range, hands, arm and instincts to hold his position as well. PERSON's defense is ahead of his offense right now, but there is projection in his bat.PERSON is praised for his work ethic and makeup, and although it might take a while for him to reach his potential, there's no question he won't be outworked trying to get there.

PERSON burst onto the prospect scene in 2015, hitting 10 homers in 48 games in the ORGANIZATION at age 17. He signed as a shortstop but has moved down the defensive spectrum to right field, retaining his loose, lefty swing and physical projection. In the interim, PERSON has had maturity and consistency issues, which he appears to be moving past now. Longer-limbed power hitters typically take the longest to develop offensively, making his pro debut that much more surprising. He'll be 21 years old next year, with a chance to get to Double-A and regain the everyday player projection some saw in 2015.

PERSON's fuzzy shock of hair is the best in the system, and he's one of the more creative sequencers among PERSON farmhands as well. His front side flies way open during disconnection, and the dramatic manner in which his limbs bandy about during his delivery limit his fastball command, but also help create a weird angle on his stuff, which is quite good. He'll sit in the low-90s, his curveball has premium spin, and PERSON can manipulate the shape of his fastball and multiple breaking balls. There's a chance he ends up in a rotation so long as the command progresses a little bit, and PERSON's feel for pitching is promising in this regard. If it doesn't, he could be an excellent multi-inning reliever.

PERSON hit .402/.531/.819 as a sophomore and won the ORGANIZATION. A repeat performance as a junior would have made him one of, if not the greatest statistical performer in college history. After an early-season surge, PERSON started seeing a lot of breaking balls, about 15% fewer fastballs in PAC-12 play than he had during non-conference bouts. He was pitched around, and unable to make as much impact contact. But all the tools remain present. PERSON has a very selective approach, letting strikes he can't drive pass him by unless he has to protect. He has a very athletic swing despite being decidedly unathletic in every other way, enabling all fields power and high rates of contact. There's no margin for error for right-handed hitting first baseman, but if there's one prospect to be confident in hitting as much as is necessary to profile at first base, it's someone with this combination of visual evaluation and statistical track record. He's a longshot possibility at the first pick, but probably goes between three and five.

A late bloomer who went undrafted out of high school, PERSON parlayed a strong junior season as PERSON's Friday starter into becoming a second-round pick.Tall and lean on a 6-foot-5 frame, PERSON has some room to fill out. And what he has is already pretty good. The left-hander pitches downhill, with natural cutting movement on his fastball. His short, sharp slider is an out pitch at times. PERSON has solid feel for a changeup, though it's still a work in progress. He is generally around the plate with all of his pitches and has been one of the nation's top strikeout pitchers.Taken a round after the ORGANIZATION selected PERSON, PERSON gives GSP another college arm who could move fairly quickly through its system and into the big league rotation.

GPE won't wow you with tools, but he's the type that just goes out and gets the job done. The one thing he's shown he can do is hit. He makes a ton of contact, rarely strikes out, draws walks and looks like he should be able to continue hitting for a high average. He's the perfect No. 2 type hitter, one who can move runners, hit-and-run and hit when behind in the count. He makes the plays defensively without much flash. He played second base in the ORGANIZATION in 2011 and many feel that he'll eventually slide over there permanently and become a very solid everyday big leaguer on the right side of the infield.

PERSON pitched through pain in his final two years at ORGANIZATION (GPE) High and as a freshman at GPE before his elbow gave out, leading to PERSON surgery in the fall of 2014. He returned as a redshirt sophomore in 2016, capping his comeback with his first college complete game in the Big 12 Conference tournament before turning down the ORGANIZATION as a 34th-round pick. His stuff has bounced back further this spring, when he has been the ORGANIZATION' most effective starter.At his best, PERSON can deal at 92-94 mph and reach 96 with his fastball. He uses his size and an overhand delivery to generate steep downhill plane, helping his heater induce swings and misses as well as groundballs. He still has to prove he can maintain his velocity over a full schedule because it has dipped in the second half of the last two college seasons.While PERSON's secondary pitches all can grade above-average at times, his changeup is more consistent than his curveball and cutter. He has a sound delivery and arm action, though his control hasn't been as sharp this year as it has been in the past.

PERSON's father PERSON, currently with the ORGANIZATION as a quality control coach, has spent 37 seasons in pro ball as a player, manager and coach. His older brothers GPE (ORGANIZATION) and GPE (ORGANIZATION) both were late picks out of college and reached high Class A in the ORGANIZATION system. The best prospect in the family, PERSON is one of the top college shortstops available in this Draft.After a stress fracture in his back shortened his freshman season and still bothered him as a sophomore, PERSON is fully healthy and showing what he's capable of at the plate. With his smooth left-handed swing and an advanced approach at the plate, he makes contact with ease. He has deceptive raw power and could hit 12-15 homers per season in pro ball.Though he's an average runner out of the batter's box, PERSON is a step quicker underway and his high baseball IQ helps him make plays on the bases and in the field. He doesn't have the range and arm teams desire in a shortstop, so he may profile better as an offensive second baseman. PERSON love his makeup and believe he'll get everything he can out of his ability.

Entering summer showcase season, PERSON was known as something of an oddity: a switch-hitting, switch-throwing catcher who was also an ambidextrous reliever when needed. As the summer wore on, PERSON grew on scouts, was chosen as the backup catcher for PERSON, and quickly took the starting job from eventual PERSON second rounder PERSON. PERSON was able to do this (and eventually become a first round pick) due to his innate present feel for contact at the plate and receiving behind it. In addition to solid contact skills, PERSON also started to lift the ball in games closer to the draft and get to all of his fringy raw power. This polish helped to make teams less worried about his advanced age relative to his prep peers, and some scouts thought he was among the top 5-10 players in the entire draft. 
PERSON had a solid pro debut that was in line with the expectations of any of the pro scouts we talked to who watched the ORGANIZATION' ORGANIZATION club. He's an average runner and an above-average athlete for the position, projecting as an above-average defender with a 65-grade arm. Some clubs don't like the recent track record of prep catchers and considered taking PERSON and then moving him to third base, but his feel for catching is too advanced to throw away. There are some similarities to another prep catcher from the prior draft: M.J. PERSON of the ORGANIZATION. PERSON is a little twitchier while PERSON is a little more advanced in terms of skills. PERSON's mother is PERSON and he would be the first Native GPE big leaguer to debut since PERSON and the second ever from the ORGANIZATION, joining PERSON.

PERSON played mostly catcher until he went to the World Wood Bat Association World Championships in the fall of 2012 and worked at 92-93 mph off the mound. PERSON fell in love with his strong body and arm, and they became even more smitten when he hit 96 and unveiled a hard slider in a preseason scrimmage the following spring. Though he didn't maintain that stuff, he showed enough glimpses that the FACILITY spent a fifth-round pick and $400,000 bonus on him.PERSON remains extremely raw but still flashes enticing stuff. He usually operates at 91-95 mph and can reach 97 mph with his fastball, which also features some sink. His low-80s secondary pitches lack reliability but not promise, as he has a slider with some tilt and a changeup with some splitter action.Though he finds the strike zone, PERSON still lacks the command and consistency to miss bats. PERSON knew he'd be a long-term project and will remain patient with his development.

ORGANIZATION registered on the national scene in 2014 when he threw a complete-game shutout in the ORGANIZATION World Series, capping off two years of effective starting for a top-notch GPE program. His junior season was not as effective, but the ORGANIZATION thought enough of him to take him in the fifth round and watched him turn in another gem in GPE before signing in mid-July. He handled an assignment to the Class A Advanced PERSON to begin his first full season without difficulty, earning a promotion after just five starts. Double-A initially proved to be a stiffer challenge, but the left-hander appeared to be making adjustments as the year progressed. ORGANIZATION is the quintessential pitchability college lefty. When he's on his game, he's a master strike-thrower with a solid three-pitch mix. He'll throw his fastball in the 89-91 mph range and do a very good job of mixing in his slider and changeup to keep hitters off balance. His command suffered as a junior, partially because of pitch selection and partially because of a blister issue that bothered him on and off throughout his college career. Part of his problems in Double-A revolved around difficulties finding the strike zone. There is some projection to ORGANIZATION and his 6-foot-3 frame. Even with his inconsistencies, his track record says he has every chance to start at the big league level, albeit with the ceiling of a No. 4 or 5 starter.

A 2013 international signee out of the ORGANIZATION, PERSON opened eyes the next year during his impressive professional debut in the ORGANIZATION. That success carried over into his first stateside action in 2015, when he slashed .344/.380/.469 in 45 games between the ORGANIZATION and GPE York-Penn Leagues. PERSON advanced to full-season ball for the first time in 2016, only to miss a portion of the first half with an ankle injury and appear in just 73 games.PERSON's quick hands from the left side of the plate fuel his game as a slap hitter who predominantly hits the ball on the ground and sprays it from line to line. He's also an adept bunter and gets out of the batter's box quickly, utilizing his above-average speed. PERSON will never offer much in the way of power, but he makes enough hard contact to accrue his share of doubles and triples.A raw defender when he signed, PERSON was one of GPE's more improved outfielders in 2016 after making strides with his routes and angles to the ball. He's capable of playing center field but profiles better in left, where his speed and average arm strength are cleaner fits.

PERSON took home PERSON of the Year honors as a ORGANIZATION State sophomore in 2014 after he led the conference in all three triple-slash categories. He followed it up with a strong junior campaign, and the ORGANIZATION nabbed him with the first of their two first-round picks in June. After a sluggish start to his pro career, PERSON revamped his swing and began to put it all together in 2017, totaling 21 homers and 20 steals in Double-A. His production was less consistent last season in Triple-A, and he also missed some time with a hamstring injury, but the ORGANIZATION still gave him a look as a September callup, a challenge to which PERSON responded by hitting .250 with three homers in 17 games. The open, over-exaggerated crouch that PERSON employed at ORGANIZATION has evolved into a more upright and closed-off stance as a pro. It's enabled him to make better use of his hands and wrists, helping him catch up to velocity and tap into some power, though, overall, his swing lacks versatility. PERSON's patient approach and strong on-base skills have long been strengths, and he offers value on the basepaths with his average speed. A good athlete despite his stocky build, he's a fringy defender at both outfielder corners, but profiles better in left field due to his below-average arm strength. After his first taste of the Majors last season, PERSON is positioned to see even more playing time in 2019 as the ORGANIZATION continue their rebuild. An everyday role might be a stretch, given PERSON's overall profile, but he contributes in enough facets of the game to serve as useful bench player or a platoon option.

Non-drafted free-agent signings typically don't have too much in the way of expectations, often counted on to be organizational fillers. The way PERSON has been pitching since signing in July 2013, however, has made people sit up and take notice. PERSON is a big, strong lefty reliever some in the organization have likened to former ORGANIZATION. He'll throw his fastball in the 93-97 mph range and sits in the mid 90s consistently. His slider is developing and should at least PERSON average, sometimes flashing more. He needs to find the strike zone more consistently, even in relief, but he's missed a lot of bats in the early stages of his career. PERSON did have PERSON surgery in high school, back in 2011, forcing him to miss his freshman year at FACILITY. He transferred to junior college for 2013 and hasn't shown any health issues in 2015. He's 23, but he could start moving fast.

In a system particularly flush with middle-infield prospects, being known as the best defensive shortstop in the organization takes on more meaning. PERSON, a 10th-round pick given $200,000 to sign out of the GPE high school ranks in 2013, carries the mantle proudly.PERSON may have PERSON potential at the premium position. He has the best hands and actions in the system. PERSON's arm is a tick above average, but it's more than strong enough to make all the throws and his hands are plus. Because he just has average speed, his range isn't quite as good, but it's still easily above average. PERSON's bat is well behind the glove, largely because of a lack of strength. He does have an advanced approach at the plate, with excellent plate discipline. PERSON finished fourth in the LOCATION League in on-base percentage and second in batting average, though how his bat will play at higher levels remains to be seen.PERSON can get to the big leagues with his glove alone. His lack of strength could limit him to a backup or utility role. If PERSON can get stronger, that could change his profile quite a bit.

After pitching almost exclusively as a starter in his first five pro seasons, PERSON opened 2015 in the Double-A Richmond bullpen because the ORGANIZATION wanted him to stop pacing himself and attack hitters full bore. When they returned him to the rotation in GPE, he recorded a 2.34 ERA in nine starts. He was outstanding as a Double-A starter to open 2016, then found the going more difficult following a promotion to Triple-A in mid-May.While his future role may be uncertain, there's no question about PERSON's arm strength. He usually ranges from 91-95 mph with his fastball, which has some sink. He also can miss bats with his mid-80s slider, which tightened up and showed flashes of becoming a plus pitch more often last year. He also uses a changeup but it's not nearly as effective as his other two pitches. PERSON's 6-foot-7 frame gives him long levers that allow him to create difficult plane and angle with his pitches, but they also make it tough for him to repeat his delivery. He'll need to improve his command to remain a starter, and he'll also need to prove his durability because minor injuries have prevented him from exceeding 90 2/3 innings in a full season before 2016.

PERSON had an inconsistent high school senior season in 2012, running his fastball up to 98 mph and flashing a nifty curveball on some days, and losing velocity and his feel for spin on others. In need of pitching, the ORGANIZATION invested a second-round pick and $1.05 million in him. He was inconsistent in his first two seasons but had his best year as a pro in 2014 after taking his conditioning more seriously.PERSON usually pitches at 92-95 mph with his fastball, and he could regularly work in the mid 90s once he fully matures physically. His hard curveball shows promise, while his changeup is more of a work in progress.Chicago knew PERSON would be a long-term project who would need time to develop. His control and command took a nice step forward last season, and if he puts everything together, he could be a mid-rotation starter or a late-inning reliever.

A 26th-round pick by the ORGANIZATION from a GPE high school in 2012, PERSON struggled as a ORGANIZATION freshman before breaking out in 2014. He led the ORGANIZATION with eight home runs and established himself as the best power hitter in the 2015 college crop. He carried it over into his junior season before a broken hamate bone shelved him for a while.PERSON packs a lot of strength in his 6-foot-3, 248-pound frame and his well above-average pop extends to all fields. He can get too aggressive at times, though he does a nice job of shortening and controlling his left-handed swing. While he has arm strength and has played right field as a sophomore and junior, PERSON likely faces a move back to his freshman position of first base in pro ball. He's a well below-average runner but has the hands and enough athleticism to be a capable defender at first.A hamate injury won't deflate PERSON's stock and he still has the chance to join PERSON (2004) and PERSON (2009) as the only BC first-rounders ever.

One of the least experienced and more polarizing college pitchers available in the 2018 draft, PERSON has an electric, four-pitch mix and several developmental hurdles ahead of him. At a skinny 6-foot-1, there are scouts who doubt he can start based solely on his frame, though PERSON held mid-90s velocity deep into games as a junior at ORGANIZATION. If amateur scouts are to be believed, any of the following aspects of PERSON's current profile could change: his stride direction, his arm slot, his breaking ball usage (he has two that bleed together), and the movement profile of his fastball. PERSON was academically ineligible as a sophomore and only started 19 games in three years of college, so there's at least a reason he's behind his peers from a developmental standpoint. He has unteachable arm speed and feel for spin and even if he just ends up as a big league reliever, something that seems pretty reasonable given his talent, it would be a strong outcome for a third round pick. Like GPE, PERSON may move up this list quickly with refinement, but we'd like to see it fairly soon given his age.

PERSON's fastball exhibits several of the nuanced traits that aid velocity in missing bats. For one, his heater has a 12:30 spin axis, which means it has nearly perfect backspin, better enabling fastball rise. It also has an approach angle that plays well at the top of the strike zone, which, in combination with the rise and velocity, makes it the archetypal modern fastball. His secondary stuff is quite average but as long as he is locating his mid-80s slider and changeup -- something he has struggled with in his big league appearances this spring -- he should at least be a good backend starter or multi-inning reliever, and it's possible the secondary fastball characteristics are so strong that we're underselling him a little bit.

After having five right-handers selected in the top five rounds of the past four GPE, PERSON produced two more viable candidates for the 2017 Draft in relievers PERSON and PERSON. The ORGANIZATION' career saves leader with 27, PERSON was the first of the pair to be selected, going to the ORGANIZATION in the fourth round and then signing for $400,000. After reaching full-season ball in his professional debut, PERSON advanced to Class A Advanced Modesto in '18 and garnered midseason All-Star honors in the GPE League before getting sent to the Cardinals in return for PERSON Tuivailala.PERSON has a strong, durable frame and three pitches. He has a quick arm that consistently produces 93-95 mph fastballs with heavy sink that he can command to either side of the plate. PERSON usually throws his low-80s slider for strikes, and at times it can play like a cutter, with short, glove-slide slice. He shows some feel for a changeup but doesn't need it much in a relief role.PERSON's size and arsenal profile well in a big league bullpen, and he has the potential to get there quickly if he can refine his slider and improve his control.

Included in the trade that sent PERSON to the Phillies, May brings a high-octane arm to the ORGANIZATION system. He has been slowly evolving from a thrower to a complete pitcher. His fastball reaches 95 mph, with plenty of sink, and he has no trouble maintaining velocity deep into his starts. His best secondary offering now is his changeup and it has the chance to be an above-average pitch. May throws both a curve and slider, but both are inconsistent and are fringy. May has struggled with his command over the years. He had made progress, but in 2012, his first season in Double-A, he seemed to regress and his walk and hit rates went up. He'll still be just 23 for the 2013 season, so there's time yet for him to get moving back in the right direction.

The captain of the 15-and-under team from GPE that won a championship in GPE last August, PERSON is one of the top shortstops on the market.Scouts say PERSON is a solid defender with only a slightly above-average arm, but he is very polished for his age and can be counted on to make the routine plays. Moreover, PERSON has been praised for his fluid movements on the field and his reliable hands, leading many to believe that he will stay at shortstop as he grows and develops.The infielder has a line-drive swing to all fields and has been called a typical two-hole hitter, despite what has been referred to as "limited power." He has average running speed, but he's a good baserunner. There is some concern about PERSON's body type and durability, but his biggest supporters are hoping he gets stronger as he ages. PERSON trains with former ORGANIZATION shortstop PERSON in GPE.

PERSON PERSON built on his momentum from the ORGANIZATION, where he displayed one of the best left-handed swings while hitting .329 last summer, he might have gone in the top three rounds of the 2015. It hasn't quite worked out that way because he failed to drive the ball consistently while dealing with oblique and knee injuries.With his compact stroke and plate discipline, PERSON should continue to hit for average. But through the end of the regular season, he had homered just seven times in three college seasons. He has the bat speed and strength for 15-18 homer power in pro ball, though he's going to have to get more aggressive and turn on and lift more pitches to get there.PERSON opened this year as PERSON's shortstop before his injuries pushed him to third base, which would be a better fit as a pro. He lacks the quickness for shortstop and may not be more than an adequate defender at third base, though he does have a very strong arm. If he doesn't produce more pop he may be relegated to a utility role, though some scouts are intrigued by the possibility of turning him into a catcher.

After drafting PERSON out of GPE in the second round of the 2014 Draft, the ORGANIZATION challenged the hard-throwing reliever by sending him straight to Double-A for his first full season. He struggled there, taking a step back to right the ship. It may have been exactly what PERSON needed, as he got back to the LOCATION, threw well there and didn't allow a run during the ORGANIZATION League regular season. PERSON's development took another detour in 2016, when he missed most of the season dealing with a bone bruise near his elbow.When healthy, velocity remains PERSON's main tool. His fastball sits easily in the 97-98 mph range and he has touched triple digits. He backs up his fastball with an outstanding power slider and he is working on a changeup, which has the chance to be a usable pitch in the future. PERSON not only misses a ton of bats, but he improved at keeping his power stuff down in the zone and inducing ground-ball outs over the course of his first full season. ORGANIZATION continues to be an issue as he works on consistently repeating his delivery, though he did walk just one batter in eight AFL innings.The adversity PERSON has faced during his pro career thus far could make him a better pitcher. Assuming his command continues to improve, he has all the ingredients to close games at the highest level.

After struggling so much at ORGANIZATION A Asheville that he was demoted to short-season Tri-City in 2012, PERSON returned to the LOCATION League in '13. All he did the second time around was win the ORGANIZATION and the batting title with a .343 average.An improved swing was crucial to PERSON's turnaround. With his mechanics smoother than before, he has begun driving the ball more and tapping into his raw power. PERSON is a switch-hitter and hits for average well from both sides, but his power mostly comes as a left-hander.PERSON has also improved defensively. Still, most scouts believe he will eventually outgrow shortstop. PERSON has played some third base already and could also fit at second base if he does have to change positions.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 4, 2017 - PERSON, Calif.Favorite MLB Player: PERSON committed to GPE Diego State after garnering attention for his hard-throwing ability at ORGANIZATION. He has played in two ORGANIZATION Championship tournaments, won the 2015 GPE World Series and earned a spot on the 2016 Underclass 3rd Team for his efforts.Some scouts have noted that the right-hander has impressive stuff. PERSON can get his fastball up to 94 mph with armside run. He pairs the pitch with a powerful 78 mph curveball that has displayed a tight, 3/4 break at times. On the mound PERSON has a large frame and comes to the plate out of a 3/4 slot. He has medium extension after separation in his delivery and his strength is noticeable.

PERSON spent two years at ORGANIZATION before heading to GPE PERSON's, where he had one statistically middling season for the ORGANIZATION. He got $100,00 on day three of the 2015 draft and reached Hi-A as a starter before two injuries forced a late-season move to the bullpen in 2017. PERSON's fastball/breaking ball combo was very effective during that initial run out of the bullpen, and the ORGANIZATION left him there. He's since had two dominant relief seasons, including very low walk rates for a reliever, while reaching Triple-A. His breaking ball shape varies enough that it may be two different pitches, but for now he projects as a two-pitch reliever with a modren approach: fastballs up, breaking balls down. The fastball plays in large part due to it's vertical movement.

A two-sport athlete in college, PERSON has really only been playing baseball full time since 2016, so while he's advanced in age he isn't in experience. With that in mind, PERSON' 20 annual homers despite sky-high strikeout rates are pretty impressive. He has power, he runs well, he throws well. It's a traditional right field profile on its face, just one that is behind the developmental curve and of high risk because of the strikeouts. PERSON has to be added to the 40-man this offseason or risk being Rule 5 eligible, making him a trade candidate if a team likes his physical tools and has the 40-man space to let him simmer at Triple-A for another year or so.

PERSON signed at 19 and had been slow to develop (parts of 3 seasons in the ORGANIZATION) until 2019, when he skipped a level, then earned a mid-year promotion to Hi-A. He throws hard -- 91-96 with huge extension -- and his fastball has relevant movement up and away from lefty batters. He's well built but not very athletic, and he throws many non-competitive pitches because he struggles to repeat. Rule 5 eligible this winter, PERSON has relief potential because of his heater.

GPE of the return from the ORGANIZATION in the December 2014 PERSON trade, PERSON missed nearly two years recovering from PERSON surgery. He started slowly in his return to GPE in 2016, but finished as a dominant starter in the LOCATION champion's rotation. A double-jump to Double-A in 2017 with many from that staff has not gone well.PERSON's fastball sits 93-94 mph, though he showed late last year he can reach back for more when he needed it. His curve is his out pitch and can be one of the best breaking balls in the Minors at times. His feel for his changeup had improved, giving him the makings of three average or better weapons at his disposal.With the move to the upper levels, PERSON's command has regressed, both in and out of the strike zone. He's now ahead of the curve age-wise for his level, so a repeat in level wouldn't set him back too much.

As twitchy as catching prospects get, PERSON posts plus-plus pop times thanks to a combination of plus raw arm strength, efficient footwork and a transfer so quick it qualifies as slight of hand. He's also a promising receiver and, while physically projectable, scouts don't anticipate PERSON will get so big that he needs to abandon the position. He also has plus raw power projection and a good chance to get to much of it as a right-handed hitter, though his left-handed stroke is somewhat stiff and upright. PERSON is the best J2 catching prospect since PERSON (PERSON had more power projection and pure arm strength) and, ignoring hindsight, there's an argument that PERSON is superior because of how likely he is is to remain behind the plate (PERSON had mobility and receiving issues) and grow into a well-rounded, impact defender.

The ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON in the 17th round out of a GPE high school, and he might have gone in the top five rounds if he hadn't been determined to pitch with his older brother PERSON at ORGANIZATION State. After a season with the the 49ers, PERSON spent one year each pitching with his twin brother PERSON at ORGANIZATION (Calif.) CC, where they won a state championship in 2014, and at FACILITY. A fourth-round pick last June, PERSON signed for $550,000.PERSON can reach 95 mph with his fastball but usually operates at 90-92 mph with a two-seamer that plays up because of its sink and his ability to command it. While his low-80s slider shows flashes of becoming a solid offering at times, he gets around it and turns it into a less effective slurve at others. He also needs more consistency with his splitter/changeup, though he trusts the pitch and can get swings and misses with it.PERSON has a compact delivery that he repeats well, allowing him to pound the bottom of the strike zone. His lack of a true plus pitch likely limits his ceiling to that of a No. 4 starter, but he's a good bet to reach it. The ORGANIZATION like the way he competes and also think he could become a seventh-inning reliever if needed.

A big Cape PERSON performance lead to a huge junior year at ORGANIZATION, allowing the GPE native to go to his hometown Rockies at ORGANIZATION. 8 overall.Batters react to GPE's fastball as if he's throwing harder than 90-93 mph, because he has some deception in his delivery and the pitch has heavy life, and he can reach 95-96. He throws a true slider in the low 80s and can turn it into more of a mid-80s cutter at times. He'll also display an average changeup at times, getting good sink on it. GPE throws from a lower arm angle and features more effort in his delivery than scouts like to see in a starter. But he should be able to work out of a rotation in pro ball because he has two swing-and-miss pitches and throws strikes.

PERSON has dealt with multiple hamstring injuries and then altered his approach to contact after his initial struggles at Triple-A last year. It was a bad year and the industry has grown increasingly ocncerned about PERSON' ability to stay healthy, especially if it means he'll eventually move to left field. But he was running well late in the year and still has the strength in his wrists to do extra-base damage while making plenty of contact. He still projects as an everyday player with above-average upside and the ORGANIZATION trade clears a path for him to reach the Majors this year.

GPE has made a habit out of plucking big league arms out of GPE ball in trades, with PERSON, PERSON and PERSON all examples. PERSON needed PERSON surgery when the ORGANIZATION asked for him as part of a Jose Veras deal with the Tigers in mid-2013, but they still were attracted to his quick arm and tall body. He showed one of the highest ceilings in the system, but was also its most frustrating prospect because he totaled just 246 1/3 innings in his first eight pro seasons and drew an 80-game suspension last July after testing positive for performance-enhancing drugs. A little more than a year later, the ORGANIZATION packaged PERSON with PERSON and PERSON to the ORGANIZATION for PERSON. PERSON has the raw ingredients to become a successful starting pitcher. His fastball has gone from the mid-80s when he signed for $75,000 to 91-95 mph now, peaking at 98, with a lot of downhill plane generated by his 6-foot-7 frame. He has a power breaking ball that he can turn into a curveball (which can be a hammer at times) or a harder, though less consistent, slider, and his changeup also has its moments as a plus pitch.PERSON fills the strike zone, too, though big leaguers have taken advantage of the fact that his command isn't as sharp as his control. His velocity was down in 2017, though that likely was related to the bone spurs he had removed from his elbow in September. He had his elbow reconstructed in 2014 and had tendinitis in the joint in 2016, and he has yet to show any evidence of durability.

After barely pitching as a freshman and opening 2016 in GPE A&M's bullpen, PERSON took over as the ORGANIZATION' No. 1 starter by April. He would have gone in the top five rounds if signable but ultimately slid to the ORGANIZATION in the 20th. Back in GPE Station this spring, he was one of the best Friday starters in the LOCATION before going to the Nationals in the fifth round and signing for slot value. After pitching at 91-93 mph and hitting 96 as a sophomore, PERSON worked at 89-91 mph and topped out at 94 this spring. He commands his fastball well, albeit with little movement, and it sets up a plus changeup that ranked among the best in college baseball. He used a curveball more than a slider this year, and it gives him an average third pitch.Though PERSON throws plenty of strikes and has succeeded for two years in college baseball's best conference, there still are concerns about his long-term viability as a starter. He's a small right-hander who had PERSON surgery as a high school sophomore. Scouts do rave about his confidence and makeup and believe he'll get the most out of his ability.

An interesting potential swiss-army knife utility man who can also catch, GPE has quality bat-to-ball skills and has a chance to make more of an impact than the typical bench player because of his multi-positional versatility.

One of the best two-way players in college baseball, PERSON has doubled as a third baseman and closer for a resurgent GPE program the last two years. Though he ranks among the ORGANIZATION Division I saves leaders thanks to an 88-92 mph fastball and an effective slider, pro teams want him solely as a position player. He was three days too young to qualify as an age-eligible sophomore for the 2018 Draft, where he might have gone in first 10 rounds, and has boosted his stock this spring to where he could go as high as the third.PERSON makes consistent line-drive contact from the right side of the plate and has improved offensively in each of his three seasons with the ORGANIZATION. He has the strength and bat speed to hit for more power, and he shows at least solid raw pop in batting practice, but he'll probably top out at 12-15 homers per year unless he adds more loft to his swing. He puts the bat on the ball so easily that he rarely walks, another adjustment he'll have to make at the next level.PERSON has fringy speed out of the batter's box but a quicker first step that helps make him at least a solid defender at third base. He also has soft hands and a strong arm, though he needs to improve his defensive consistency. If everything comes together, he could be a .270 hitter with 20 homers who's an asset at the hot corner.

GPE is the typical quick-twitch GPE outfielder that lands in the highest bonuses each year. He has a big, present plus arm that could get even better with maturity. He's also an above average runner that projects for above average power and flashes above average bat speed. The questions about him revolve around his feel to hit in games, which then impacts the power he can show in games, and if he'll gain or lose a step as he matures, which would dictate a center field or right field fit.

The player who some scouts think PERSON resembles the most is a young PERSON has built his reputation on his big bat and big body. He's athletic and is able to transfer the raw power he shows off in batting practice into games. There's bat speed now and the potential for plus raw power in the future. There was some swing-and-miss to his game early on, but PERSON has improved his approach at the plate and has what was once considered a "sometimes wild swing" consistently under control. PERSON could end up in right field and has a chance to be a decent defender, but it's his offensive potential, not his defensive prowess, that will carry him, at least early in his career. He has also been praised for his overall makeup, specifically his competitiveness and the way he enjoys the game.PERSON is from ORGANIZATION, GPE, and trains with PERSON. The ORGANIZATION are the favorite to sign him.

The ORGANIZATION doubled down on shortstops at the outset of the 2012 international period, signing PERSON and PERSON ($725,000) on back-to-back days. PERSON has since become the A's top prospect after heading to GPE in the ORGANIZATION trade, leaving PERSON as the potential heir to the shortstop throne in GPE. He continued to climb the ladder in 2016, beginning the year back in the Class A Advanced PERSON and then reaching Double-A in August at age 20. Just three years removed from becoming a swing-hitter, PERSON shows good feel for the barrel from both sides of the plate with loose, twitchy wrists and good bat speed. He drives the ball more consistently as a lefty -- the side from which he's hit all but two of his home runs since the beginning of 2015 -- and should continue to add strength as he grows into his wiry-athletic frame. His right-handed swing is less impactful but yields consistent contact. PERSON saw both his strikeout and walk rates trend in a position direction in 2016, though he still has gains to make with his approach and pitch selection.Defensively, PERSON has the athleticism, range and plus arm to stick at shortstop but is lacking in finesse at the position and commits too many errors out of a lack of focus. That all should improve with experience, though, especially since PERSON has been a considerably younger player at every level.

PERSON originially joined the D-backs back in Dec. 14 as part of the three-team trade that sent him and PERSON from GPE to GPE and made PERSON a ORGANIZATION. His hopes on following up on a solid 2016 season that saw him reach Double-A for the first time were dashed by a shoulder injury that required surgery, keeping him off the field for all but 23 games in 2017. PERSON is once again healthy and ready to start working his way up to GPE. The switch-hitter has a really strong contact-first approach and has greatly improved his plate discipline and willingness to take walks. He may never be a huge power guy, though that tool is often the last to come, but with his new selectivity, he started tapping into his raw power for more extra-base authority and could be a double-digit home run guy in the big leagues. While he's played mostly shortstop, he's shown he can more than handle second base.PERSON eventually should settle in to being a solid utility player, though if more power comes, seeing him at second every day shouldn't be too surprising. For now, though, he'll focus on staying healthy and putting the shoulder issue in his rearview mirror.

Ask scouts to rank the top teenage prospects from the ORGANIZATION this year and PERSON will be high on the list. There are some that believe he's the best player from island in this year's class.Here's why: PERSON can hit to all fields and the ball jumps off his bat.But he's much more than a one-dimensional player. The GPE teen is athletic and has the potential to be a five-tool player. He has shown good footwork and the ability to defend. He has also impressed scouts with his strong and accurate arm. At the plate, PERSON has displayed a slight uppercut swing with quickness and strength.  PERSON and raised in the ORGANIZATION, PERSON played ORGANIZATION baseball and was groomed under the watchful eye of trainer PERSON. He has some experience playing in games and showcases in the GPE.

GPE PERSON in GPE, GPE, hasn't had a player drafted since PERSON was a Mariners 10th-rounder 35 years ago, but that will change when PERSON becomes one of the first outfielders to come off the board in June. Like PERSON, he stands out most with his speed, though PERSON has the offensive upside to exceed PERSON's brief big league career.PERSON ran a 6.32-second 60-yard dash at the LOCATION Professional Showcase last July, though he's more of a plus runner than a true burner. He's definitely quick enough to steal bases and patrol center field, where his below-average arm isn't a liability.Though the ORGANIZATION recruit still is developing as a hitter, he's not completely raw either. His bat speed is improving and he shows some feel for the barrel. PERSON won't ever be the focus of his game, but he can drive the ball to his pull side and could produce double-digit home run totals once he gets stronger.

After signing for $1.3 million as a fourth-round pick in 2012, PERSON developed more slowly than expected. He didn't reach full-season ball until 2014 and struggled when he got there, posting a 6.85 ERA in 11 starts in low Class A. This year he has looked more like the pitcher the ORGANIZATION thought they were signing, earning a promotion to high Class A after a month.PERSON has reclaimed the fastball velocity he displayed in high school, working at 92-93 mph and topping out at 96 repeatedly this year. His heater can be very tough to hit when he uses his 6-foot-6 frame to drive it down in the strike zone. His hard knuckle-curve can generate swings-and-misses as well.Though PERSON still has work to do with his changeup, it shows signs of becoming a usable third option. He's doing a better job of throwing strikes this year, which bodes well for his chances of remaining a starter at higher levels.

Two consecutive seasons lost to a combination of PERSON rehab and mononucleosis highlight a robust, early-career injury history for PERSON, who has been encouragingly healthy for the last two years. He works at the top of the zone with a low-90s fastball, and beneath it with a big, breaking 12-to-6 curveball used against left and right-handed hitters, and he bisects the plate horizontally with a cutter/slider and changeup. A 6% walk rate in 2018 was comfortably PERSON's career best, which may be real development or just something that will regress to PERSON's career mean. It's ORGANIZATION. 4 or 5 starter stuff from an arm whose injury history, which one could argue should soon be expunged, moves him toward the back of that FV group. He's at ORGANIZATION and may see the big leagues this year.

The ORGANIZATION went high-risk, high-reward when they took PERSON, the GPE high school standout, in the second round, and gave him a well over-slot bonus of $2 million to keep him from heading to GPE PERSON. His pro debut showed there's much work to be done and he repeated the rookie-level ORGANIZATION in 2015.Right now, PERSON is a bit of an all-or-nothing hitter. He has tremendous raw power and a ton of bat speed, with a lot of force and explosion in his swing. He will have to improve his pitch recognition and overall approach considerably for him to be able to progress so he can make more contact and tap into that power. PERSON does have a right fielder's arm, but his below-average speed does limit his range somewhat. PERSON will be the key for PERSON and he's far from a can't-miss prospect. But if it clicks, he's the type of high-ceiling player who could have a huge impact in a lineup.

When PERSON was at FACILITY in GPE, all he did was hit. After a bumpy pro debut in 2013, PERSON returned to swinging the bat well during his first full season, including a strong showing in the ORGANIZATION, though he wasn't able to replicate that with the move to Double-A in 2015.When PERSON is going well, he has a solid approach at the plate and knows how to work a walk. His simple swing enables him to make consistent contact, though he doesn't produce much power. He's a capable defender and gets rid of the ball quickly, but doesn't stand out and may eventually end up in a utility role. PERSON was sent down to Class A Advanced Jupiter after scuffling in GPE in the hopes he could rediscover his swing. If he can continue to make consistent contact, he might be able to carve out a role in the big leagues.

After an outstanding first full season in 2012 that saw him reach Double-A and lead the organization in ORGANIZATION and ORGANIZATION, PERSON was limited in 2013 by a shoulder injury. When healthy, PERSON works aggressively and goes right after hitters with his heavy sinker to produce plenty of groundballs. He can touch 97 mph with his fastball. His above-average slider has short and tight tilt to it, and his changeup sinks with a splitter-like action. A former two-way player in college, he's a good athlete who repeats his delivery well and throws a ton of strikes. He performed well in Spring Training in 2013 and, before his injury, appeared to be close to reaching the Major Leagues.

GPE is one of the youngest players in this year's class and won't be able to sign until he turns 16 in GPE, but that has not stopped scouts from raving about his potential.A physically mature third baseman with soft hands and an accurate plus-arm, GPE is a solid defender with good footwork around the bag. Offensively, GPE shows good bat speed and the ability to hit to all fields. He has displayed large power during batting practice, and it sometimes shows up in games.There is some concern about his ability to recognize pitches and that has swing can get long at times, but some scouts believe GPE is a sleeper and has the potential to be the top player out of this year's crop of prospects. PERSON also like his baseball IQ, his makeup and the notion that he's only going to get better as he grows older.

There might not be a player in this GPE class more universally liked by area scouts than PERSON. Getting decision-makers to sign off on taking a 5-foot-8 shortstop early will ultimately determine when the LOCATION commit hears his name called in June.The one thing no one questions is PERSON's ability to stick at shortstop. He is a plus defender with outstanding range and more than enough arm to make throws from all over the diamond, making highlight reel plays with regularity, even on big stages like the ORGANIZATION Game All-American Classic. While PERSON will never hit for power, he has added some strength in his lower half and should be able to continue to do so as he matures, allowing him to shoot the ball to the gaps. He's a plus runner with outstanding instincts, so he can stretch singles to doubles and doubles to triples. PERSON does play his home games on turf, so some of his times might be a bit inflated, but no one doubts his skills play on any surface.PERSON endears himself to scouts even more with his outstanding makeup and baseball IQ. His supporters see a Jose PERSON type profile, albeit one with less power, but who can stay at short. The success of an undersized player like PERSON might help allay some concerns and help PERSON come off the board in the early stages of the GPE, though there are bound to be some teams who won't take a player his size in the first round.Prospect Development PERSON - PERSON, GPE.

PERSON's natural hitting ability has helped him rise through the ORGANIZATION since being drafted out of the GPE high school ranks in 2010. He batted .309 and led the Double-A LOCATION with 37 doubles in 2014 before joining the ORGANIZATION as part of a trade package for PERSON that December. He was enjoying his first big league camp with his new organization when a wrist injury that required surgery put him on the shelf.PERSON understands the strike zone well, knows how to work a walk and makes consistent contact to all fields. While he has strength in his 6-foot-2, 220-pound frame, that has mostly translated to doubles in the ORGANIZATION, as his 11 home runs in 2014 with Double-A Birmingham are his career high.After beginning his professional career as a third baseman, PERSON moved across the diamond in 2013. He's an adequate defender at his new position but faces a tough profile as a right-handed-hitting first baseman without much power.

Outside of PERSON, PERSON may have more raw power than any high school middle infielder in the 2014 Draft class. He should add strength as he fills out his 6-foot-2 frame, and he already shows the ability to turn on above-average fastballs and pull them with authority.PERSON hasn't had a great spring with the bat, as his swing has looked stiff and his bat speed hasn't been as impressive as it has in the past. While he still can put on a show in batting practice, he has swung and missed in game action more than scouts would like.With just decent speed and quickness, PERSON almost certainly will move off shortstop at the next level, either at ORGANIZATION State or in pro ball. It's possible that he could be a second baseman, and his power and strong arm would allow him to profile well at third base.

PERSON was the first high school catcher drafted in 2012, with scouts being really attracted by his bat. Though he made strides behind the plate as a professional, PERSON was moved to the outfield by the D-backs in 2014.PERSON has a strong arm, and he has enough athleticism to be an adequate defender in time. His bat, however, remains the primary attraction. PERSON's bat speed and strength create plenty of raw power. How much of that power he is able to use remains to be seen. There's a lot of swing-and-miss in his game, and he will have to improve his pitch-recognition skills to reach his offensive potential.At 20 years old, PERSON still has time on his side as he works to make the necessary adjustments. But his struggles in his first experience in full-season ball show that he still has a long way to go.

The ORGANIZATION didn't place PERSON on the 40-man roster this offseason, leaving him exposed for the Rule 5 Draft, thinking most organizations wouldn't take a flier on a power hitter who only had 20 games above the A ball level. They were right, and the big, physical first baseman remained in the fold for the 2013 season. The raw power is legitimate, at least above-average. It hasn't shown up in games quite as regularly as it did during his breakout 2011 season, though he did finish with 48 extra-base hits in 2012 and 44 in '13. The strikeouts will continue to come, but so will the walks. He's an average defender, at best, though he'll be fine at first. It will be his bat that gets him to the big leagues.

The ORGANIZATION introduced one hefty, hard-throwing reliever to the big leagues last season in PERSON, and they have another on the way. ORGANIZATION has lowered his ERA in each of his four years in full-season ball, dropping it to a miniscule 1.19 in 2013.ORGANIZATION' main pitch is a fastball that usually operates in the mid-90s and has reached 99 mph. He gets good sink on his heater when he throws it more at 93-95. His slider lacks consistency but can hit the upper 80s and is a plus pitch when it's on. For someone with his power stuff, ORGANIZATION doesn't miss as many bats as he should. He doesn't have any problem finding the strike zone, but his long arm action enables hitters to see the ball and he has averaged just 6.3 strikeouts per nine innings during his first six pro seasons. He might fit as more of a middle reliever in the ORGANIZATION.

The son of current ORGANIZATION' vice president of amateur and international scouting PERSON, PERSON has a combination of solid stuff and advanced pitchability from the famed PERSON high school program that produced standouts like PERSON and PERSON, among many others.Finley pitches currently with an average fastball, thrown in the 89-92 mph range. He has one of the better breaking balls among high school pitchers in the class, showing an ability to really spin a good curveball. He doesn't throw his changeup much, but he as a good feel for it and it could at least average in the future. He's always around the strike zone and all of his offerings come from a clean and easy delivery.Finley's advanced feel for pitching and baseball bloodlines, not to mention a 20-strikeout performance in GPE, had him moving up some Draft boards as the spring unfolded.

The last high school outfielder from GPE to make a big Draft splash was, of course, PERSON. Only one prep bat from the FACILITY has gone prior to the fifth round since then (2011 second-rounder PERSON), and while PERSON isn't projected to make a Trout-like impact, seeing him join Thomore in this select group isn't out of the question.PERSON isn't the toolshed his more famous predecessor is, but he does have one strong carrying tool: his raw power. It's legitimate and it shows up presently. He's very physical now, without a ton of projection. He's more power over hit, with some length to his swing, but he does have good rhythm at the plate, giving him a better shot of tapping into that strength. PERSON will be an average runner in the future with a decent arm, likely profiling as a left fielder in the future.Committed to GPE, PERSON fits the corner outfield profile. A team that believes he'll hit enough to use that raw pop consistently will be the one to take him off the board in the top three rounds.

The ORGANIZATION' 10th-round pick in the 2015 Draft, PERSON was a senior signed out of PERSON who received a $25,000 bonus. He operated mostly as a swingman early in his pro career and had a strong first full season, albeit as a 23-year-old in the Class A GPE ORGANIZATION. A move up to Class A Advanced Potomac the next year was met with struggles, and the ORGANIZATION shifted him to the bullpen full-time when he repeated the level in 2018. He took quickly to the new role, pitching increasingly well as the season progressed before an eye-opening performance in the ORGANIZATION. He pitched his way from Double- to Triple-A in 2019 when he was sent to the ORGANIZATION for PERSON Elias.After working in the low 90s during the regular season, PERSON's fastball was consistently 95-96 mph with improved late life in the ORGANIZATION. He has an above-average slider, thrown in the mid-80s with good depth, and also can mix in a fringy changeup. He has below-average control of all three pitches, though it stands to improve as he becomes more comfortable with his improved stuff out of the bullpen. PERSON dominated same-sided hitters in the ORGANIZATION with his fastball-breaking ball combo, holding them to a .184 average without allowing an extra-base hit in 54 plate appearances. Such success highlights PERSON's potential as a left-handed specialist, though he'll first have to improve his control as he navigates the upper Minors.

PERSON was a top high school talent out of GPE in 2014 when the ORGANIZATION went well over pick value to sign him in the fifth round of that June's Draft. He was making slow, incremental progress, slowed periodically by injuries, when he was dealt to the Cardinals in July 2017 for international bonus pool money. He responded by having a breakout year, playing across two levels of the upper Minors and earning a spot on GPE' 40-man roster.PERSON has long had solid all-around tools with plus instincts that allow them to play up. More than anything, staying healthy was the key component in his leap forward in 2018 as he had a full season really for the first time in his career. He has a simple approach at the plate and was able to tap into the raw power he'd shown since high school by standing a little more upright at the plate and making his feet a little more narrow in his setup, leading to him more than doubling his career home run output heading into the season. PERSON has very good speed and excellent instincts on the basepaths, though he has to learn to be more efficient when stealing bases. His speed and instincts help him in the outfield, where he's above-average in center field and has more than enough arm to handle a corner spot if needed.If things keep moving in the right direction, PERSON has the upside to be a 15 homer-15 stolen base kind of offensive performer. He might be best suited as a valuable fourth outfielder, but seeing him play his way into an every day role in center field isn't out of the question.

GPE and physically projectable, PERSON is highly likely to move off of shortstop and over to third base (or perhaps the the outfield) as he fills out. His swing is picturesque but undercut by the length of his levers and he looks much better taking BP than he does in games, but there's a good chance he grows into monster power and he need only tap into most of it to profile.

One of three potential first-round picks from GPE, PERSON had an exceptional summer, sharing playoff ORGANIZATION honors in the ORGANIZATION and pitching well with the GPE collegiate national team after helping the ORGANIZATION win the ORGANIZATION World Series. He missed the first two weeks of the 2015 season with elbow soreness but bounced back after that.PERSON has a deep repertoire featuring four potential solid-or-better big league pitches and the ability to throw all of them for strikes. His best offering is his 90-96 mph fastball, and while he sometimes gets caught in between his curveball and slider, both can be weapons. His changeup similarly varies from inconsistent to effective. PERSON could have been a Draft pick in the top two rounds out of a ORGANIZATION high school in 2012 had he been signable away from GPE. The biggest knock on him is that he's just 6-foot-2 and 170 pounds, but he had been durable prior to this spring. His athleticism and sound delivery should allow him to remain a starter.

As a high school shortstop from GPE drafted by the GPE, PERSON draws some natural comparisons to PERSON. While PERSON can't match PERSON's lofty ceiling, he has acquitted himself well as a professional.PERSON has a good feel for the bat and makes consistent contact. Though a triple he hit off PERSON as a high school senior helped push PERSON up ORGANIZATION boards in 2012, he has below-average power.PERSON's athleticism and instincts help him defensively, but some scouts remain unconvinced he will be able to handle playing shortstop every day. With so many middle infielders already in the big leagues, GPE can afford to give him plenty of time to improve his defense and refine his overall game.

For whatever reason, hitting prospects in the ORGANIZATION organization tend to struggle when they first get to Triple-A Louisville. PERSON, for instance, hit under .200 his first two months of his first full year at the level in 2010. PERSON suffered the same fate in 2012 but recovered and made his Major ORGANIZATION debut in 2013. While he's a fringy hitter, there's no doubting his right-handed power, notably to the opposite field. His bat could get him to the big leagues, though he's limited to first base and is blocked in GPE by that PERSON fellow.

After a strong full-season debut in 2015, it looked like PERSON was starting to establish himself as an up-and-coming third-base prospect, one with the kind of power profile teams like to see from a corner infielder. An 80-game suspension following a positive test for the performance-enhancing drugs ORGANIZATION and ORGANIZATION leave everything somewhat in doubt.The ORGANIZATION had kept PERSON back in extended spring camp in 2015 to get the left-handed hitter to use the opposite field more. He bought in and was driving balls off the left-center-field wall early in his GPE ORGANIZATION season. While PERSON has decent contact skills, he needs to refine his approach to see more pitches and draw more walks so he can tap into his raw power more. His defense at third is below average, so he might have to move across the diamond to first. Consistency in the field has been an issue for PERSON, with some mechanical issues and subpar actions at times.PERSON came a long way in a short time, and there was hope he could develop into an average hitter with solid in-game power. The suspension puts a cloud over all of those projections.

If you were to just look at PERSON' 2016 stats and then be told that he's really only a viable defensive fit at first base, you'd call him a non-prospect. A broken finger caused the downturn in production and in 2017 PERSON was back to taking monster hacks that produce comfortably plus raw power. He's going to strike out and isn't especially patient, but he has a good chance to get to most of that power and pass PERSON on the ORGANIZATION depth chart early in the year.

The Aâs continue to aggressively pursue talent in GPE and they think PERSON has the chance to be a pretty exciting table-setter one day. He made his GPE debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2012, mostly playing right field alongside B.J. PERSON. And while he didnât hit like he did during his debut in the ORGANIZATION, the Aâs feel he has the chance to be a solid hitter, one who has shown an understanding of what his game should be, getting on base and running. He wonât have the power profile to be a prototypical right fielder, but he may man a corner with PERSON in center as they move up the system together.

A 12th-round pick from GPE who signed for $100,000 in the 2016 Draft, PERSON was largely a reliever in college. After a stunning pro debut pitching out of the bullpen, he moved into the rotation in 2017, finishing fourth in the system in strikeouts and sixth in ORGANIZATION, then moved up to Double-A, where he finished off a playoff no-hitter. His development is now in the hands of the D-backs, who acquired him in a three-team trade in February that sent PERSON to GPE York.PERSON's velocity ticked up at the start of his pro career, with his fastball jumping up to 93-97 mph. He continues to work on the consistency of his mid-80s slider and he's worked to refine his changeup and has had success with it. His stuff held up all year in his first full pro season and while making the transition from reliever to starter, though the ORGANIZATION kept him on a tight pitch limit. High spin rates on his fastball and breaking ball led to a lot of missed bats in 2017.PERSON has an athletic delivery that he can repeat well, which should lead to solid control. He had ulnar transposition surgery on his pitching elbow in the fall of 2015 and also missed time with back and knee issues in college, but he proved to be durable over 27 starts in 2017. Even if he returns to the bullpen, he could be a valuable arm for the D-backs in the future.

The wave of teenage talent currently at Hi-A drove PERSON to push PERSON straight to Double-A to start his first full season, and he's risen to the occasion, off to a pretty strong start, at least from bat-to-ball standpoint. A minimalistic swing enables him to make high rates of contact while the strength in PERSON's hands generates doubles power. It's not an exciting, athletic style of hitting but on an inoffensive, fundamentally sound defensive shortstop, it's a pretty interesting skillset. Barring a significant swing change, PERSON's offensive output will likely cap his ceiling in the 40/45 FV range, but for a third round pick who moves quickly, that's a great outcome.

The ORGANIZATION have a reputation for polishing throwers into pitchers and have another project on their hands after selecting PERSON from the Rockies in the big league phase of the Rule 5 Draft in December. Signed out of the ORGANIZATION in 2012, he was one of the hardest throwers in the ORGANIZATION. But he also spent three years in GPE ball and didn't make it to low Class A until 2017, which is one of the reasons PERSON didn't protect him.The Rockies clocked PERSON as fast as 104 mph and he generates consistent upper-90s fastballs with little effort. While he has a quick arm, impressive athleticism and little effort in his delivery, he has trouble controlling his heater. When he has to dial it down to throw strikes, it tends to get hit.PERSON also has a powerful slider in the upper 80s but has even more difficulty keeping it in the strike zone. He also has a changeup with similar velocity but it's not very effective and he's more of a two-pitch reliever. Despite his impressive radar-gun readings, PERSON actually has averaged less than a strikeout per inning as a pro and will need to add considerable polish to stick in GPE.

After three years pitching out of the ORGANIZATION of GPE bullpen, PERSON left as the school's career leader in saves with 30. Seeing him as a future left-handed big league reliever, the ORGANIZATION took him in the fourth round of the 2016 Draft. He spent just one summer with PERSON as he was sent to the ORGANIZATION in January 2017, along with PERSON in return for PERSON and PERSON. He reached Double-A in 2018, his second season in the organization, then capped things off in the ORGANIZATION League.PERSON' calling card is his breaking ball, and it's a real weapon against left-handed hitters but nasty enough to miss right-handed bats as well. He throws it with deception with late, sharp break, and hitters don't see it. It's the main reason why he carries a 12.2 K/9 ratio into the 2019 season. His fastball sits in the low-90s coming from a low three-quarters slot, allowing it to play up beyond the velocity.PERSON' progress has been slowed a bit by a lack of consistency and command, though it's clear his two-pitch mix is plenty to get big league hitters out. At the very least, he's a left-handed specialist. At the top end, he's a seventh-inning type reliever, with an PERSON O'Flaherty career path.
A potential plus defender at short, PERSON had strong numbers in a hitter-friendly college environment at ORGANIZATION. He's very patient, almost excessively so.

Acquired ahead of the 2019 deadline for PERSON, PERSON is a young relief prospect whose profile is driven by arm strength. He'll sit 93-97 and occasionally fool a hitter with his circle change, but everything else about him lacks consistency, especially his fastball command and breaking ball. The A's toyed with a cutter for PERSON at one point but scrapped that a month or two before he was traded. If the changeup can become more consistent, PERSON could be a good bullpen piece.

Drafted in the 35th round out of a ORGANIZATION high school by the ORGANIZATION in 2010, PERSON headed south for college, and he became the first first-round pick in GPE history. The 18th overall pick in '13, PERSON signed for $2,109,900, and he had no problem handling an assignment to low Class A in his pro debut.PERSON has a quality fastball that usually sits in the low 90s, and it has been clocked as high as 98 mph in shorter stints. His heater is difficult for batters to lift, because it features heavy life, and PERSON uses his large strong frame to pitch on a steep downhill plane.PERSON has two different power breaking balls, with his slider, which reaches the mid 80s, grading better than his upper-70s curveball. PERSON throws a changeup with deceptive arm speed and some fade, and if he refines his control, he has what it takes to be a front-line starter.

A prototypical right field prospect, GPE projects to have a plus arm at peak and his combination of bat speed and natural, pull-happy loft give him a chance to tap into what projects as plus raw power. He's already a sizeable young man but he's broad-shouldered and rangy and should continue to add weight and strength.

PERSON starred on the high school showcase circuit last summer and earned two victories in GPE to help PERSON win the 18-and-under PERSON Championships last December. One of the most advanced pitchers in the 2019 high school class, he had a chance to go as early as the third round before he didn't perform well down the stretch. If he follows through on his commitment to GPE, he should make an immediate impact as a freshman.PERSON won't wow anyone with the velocity on his fastball, which usually ranges from 88-90 mph and tops out at 93, but it's an effective pitch because it features nice sink and he commands it so well. His best offering is a mid-70s curveball with quality depth, and he can turn it into a harder slider with sharp break. He also demonstrates feel for a changeup with some tumble.His pitches play up because PERSON throws them all from the same high three-quarters slot, making it tougher for hitters to figure out what's coming. He has little effort in his simple delivery, repeating it with ease while pounding the strike zone with his entire repertoire. He doesn't have a lot of projection remaining in his strong 6-foot-2 frame, but he should be durable and has one of the higher floors among prep arms in this Draft.

When PERSON was coming out of the ORGANIZATION of GPE in 2015, he had one of the best power bats in the entire Draft class. Since the ORGANIZATION took him 34th overall that June, he has more than lived up to that hype, hitting 58 homers over his first two full seasons of pro ball and carrying a career .508 slugging percentage into the 2018 season.Thanks to a very quick bat, PERSON can drive the ball out of the park, and for extra bases, to all fields. There will always be some swing and miss to his game, but he did cut down his strikeout rate a touch in 2017 and he does offset the whiffs by drawing a good amount of walks. He has worked on his overall approach and tried to cut down on his swing to allow him to tap into his tremendous raw power consistently. PERSON is going to have to hit because he is a below-average defender in left field with a below-average arm. The ORGANIZATION love PERSON's work ethic and that he doesn't just spend all of his time in the cage working on his one carrying tool, instead putting in great effort to show he is capable enough to play the outfield regularly. The ORGANIZATION think he'll catch what he can get to and won't be a DH only. Either way, his power bat is just about ready to contribute in GPE.

The ORGANIZATION signed PERSON for $2 million just before the 2015 ORGANIZATION calendar turned over, then traded him to GPE for PERSON a few months later. In his pro debut, PERSON was a force of nature at Low-A before his in-game power tapered off after promotion to Hi-A Buies Creek. PERSON does have plus raw power and good feel to hit with a swing that has enough natural loft that scouts thihnk he'll hit for contact and power. That may take an adjustment that gets PERSON hitting the ball in the air more often, but the hope is that he just starts doing that naturally without mechanical compromise. PERSON looks athletic and fleet-footed enough to play an outfield corner right now but he's already a massive 225 pounds at a age 20 and will probably end up at first base. He has the physical capability to mash enough for first and his first season was encouraging. If the feel for airborne contact starts coming, he could move way up this list during the summer.

PERSON showed some promise in the lower levels of the ORGANIZATION system before getting buried by GPE's avalanche of position prospects. Acquired last December as the player to be named in the ORGANIZATION trade, he's enjoying his best season as a pro in his first as a Red Sox farmhand.A legitimate defender at shortstop, PERSON's quickness gives him solid range and his arm strength allows him to make all the necessary throws. He has the tools to play any infield position giving him utility value.PERSON employs a line-drive approach at the plate, though he makes contact so easily that it cuts into his walk totals. He has some modest gap power and the speed to steal an occasional base. He fits at the bottom of a big league lineup.

GPE PERSON had not had a player selected in the first three rounds since PERSON (ORGANIZATION) and PERSON (ORGANIZATION) in 1995. PERSON put an end to that drought in 2016, when he parlayed a dominant junior campaign into a second-round selection by the GPE.
