PERSON obliterated the school strikeout record of former big leaguer PERSON, fanning 133 in 109 innings, as he pitched the ORGANIZATION to their first Mid-American Conference tournament championship by winning two games in five days to take home ORGANIZATION honors.PERSON, who was one of the hardest-throwing lefty starters in the college ranks, usually pitches at 91-94 mph and peaks at 96 with late life on his fastball. Though he's not a big guy, he maintains his velocity deep into games and generates it without much effort in his delivery. There's some debate as to which is better, his low-80s slider or his tumbling changeup, but both should be at least average offerings.PERSON has three pitches and fills the strike zone, so he'll definitely be a starter going forward. He fared well against quality competition in the ORGANIZATION last summer, another point in his favor.

PERSON has long been on the national scouting radar, standing out as a prep underclass third baseman in GPE,  but his age and contact issues pushed him to ORGANIZATION. He barely played as a freshman, was solid as a sophomore, then broke out as a 22-year-old junior, hitting 19 homers en route to a .996 OPS while also posting top-of-the-scale amateur exit velocities as he grew into easy plus raw power. 
Since he signed as a 22-year-old and is a corner-based, power-over-hit bat, PERSON needed to perform quickly but a broken hamate limited his 2018 and may keep him from getting to that power in games until later in 2019. He is a fine right fielder and good athlete, but is just fringy defensively, so the pressure is on for his age-24 season, with only 47 career games at full-season levels.

PERSON led PERSON to its first-ever ORGANIZATION USA regular-season title in 2016, winning accolades as the league's player and defensive player of the year while playing through a broken hamate in his right hand. The ORGANIZATION made him the highest pick in GPE history, signing him for $1.1 million as the 51st overall choice, but haven't gotten to see much of him yet. The hamate injury hampered him during his pro debut, while repeated hamstring issues limited him to just seven games in 2017. Though he's just an average runner and taller than most shortstops at 6-foot-4, PERSON shouldn't have to move from shortstop. His instincts and quick first step improve his range, and his strong, accurate arm allows him to make all of the throws. If he winds up shifting to second base, he still should provide enough offense to profile as an everyday player.PERSON has a track record of making consistent line-drive contract from the right side of the plate, though he could use some more patience to draw more walks. His size gives him good leverage and more raw power than most shortstops, and he could produce 30 doubles and 12-15 homers annually. He won't steal many bases but is an effective runner.

In his three years at FACILITY, PERSON went from a wild freshman to an all-conference closer as a sophomore to an important member of the rotation. That evolution helped him go from being a 29th-round pick (signability played a role) as a GPE-eligible sophomore in 2017 to the 43rd overall pick in 2018, when the ORGANIZATION signed the right-hander for full pick value. PERSON was suspended 50 games in December after a second positive test for a drug of abuse.PERSON' calling card is his slider, considered to be the best college breaking ball in his GPE class. It's a mid-80s breaker with a high spin rate and so much break some saw it as a power curve, and it was a pitch he leaned heavily on in college. When PERSON is starting, he typically throws his fastball in the 90-95 mph range, but he sat in the mid-90s and touched 97 when he was relieving in 2017. He flashes an average changeup with some fade, a pitch he'll need more to succeed at the next level.Whether PERSON can remain a starter will depend largely on his command, which did improve in 2018, and whether his stuff will hold up over the course of a full season in a rotation. The Cards are committed to developing him in that role, with the knowledge his fastball-slider combination does look very good in shorter stints out of the bullpen.

PERSON is one for whom a 2018 swing change is more relevant because a lack of in-game power was the primary barrier between him and the offensive output approaching that which typically profiles at first base. A college catcher, PERSON walked more than twice as much as he struck out as a junior at GPE. Though almost nobody thought he'd be able to catch in pro ball, he was viewed as a safe, fast-moving draft prospect, albeit one with a limited ceiling due to defensive limitations. PERSON was exactly as advertised for the first two years of his pro career, and reached Double-A during his first full pro season though, as predicted, he hit for very little power, including a paltry .399 SLG% in the offensive paradise that is the ORGANIZATION. 
In 2018, PERSON added a more exaggerated leg kick and began lifting the ball more. A 45% ground ball rate at Double-A in 2017 turned into a 31% rate at Mobile the following year. He was eventually promoted to ORGANIZATION PERSON and ended up with more 2018 homers (16) than he had had in his previous two years combined. Will the change be enough? It's going to be close. PERSON posted a 102 wRC+ in 85 games as a 23-year-old at ORGANIZATION; the big league average at first base last year was 105. We have him projected as a low-end regular there, which might make him a viable alternative to PERSON and PERSON fairly soon.

PERSON was a left-hander with a fastball that topped out at 94 mph in high school, but the ORGANIZATION liked him more as a hitter and signed him for $800,000 as a sixth-rounder in 2011. He fractured his right kneecap in his first pro game and missed all of 2012 when it didn't heal properly, but he has made steady progress since. GPE lost him to the ORGANIZATION as the second overall pick in the Rule 5 Draft at the 2015 Winter Meetings, then got him back when he couldn't stick on PERSON's big league roster.PERSON doesn't have a plus tool, but he does have four that grade as average or better. He has hit for average at every Minor League stop, repeatedly barreling balls and using the entire field. He has some strength and the ORGANIZATION believe he's capable of double-digit home run totals, and he's starting to show that power this season after incorporating his legs more in his swing. With solid speed and average arm strength, PERSON is capable of playing all three outfield positions. After playing mostly center field earlier in his career, he has seen most of his time in left field this season. He earns praise for his constant hustle, but unless he starts hitting for more power, his ceiling will be as a fourth outfielder.

PERSON PERSON wasn't the only former first-rounder whom the ORGANIZATION received from the Indians in the PERSON trade in July. The 31st overall pick in 2014 and recipient of a $1.6 million bonus, PERSON led the low Class A ORGANIZATION in strikeout rate (9.7 per nine innings) in his first full pro season and reached Double-A at the end of his second. The ORGANIZATION made his older brother GPE, a right-hander, a supplemental first-round choice last June.PERSON pitches off a 92-94 mph fastball that can reach 96 with some run and sink. His go-to breaking ball is a power slider that usually arrives in the mid-80s, and he can vary its shape to come up with a low-80s curveball. While his changeup lags behind his other offerings for now, it flashes bat-missing potential and he could have four solid-or-better offerings once he's fully formed.PERSON's walk rate jumped from 2.7 per nine innings in 2015 to 3.8 last season, though his athleticism and delivery are good enough that he could develop average control. Because he's undersized at 5-foot-10, he has to stay on top of his pitches in order to generate much plane. He still needs time to develop, but he'll also open 2017 at age 20 and has the upside of a No. 3 starter.

PERSON impressed scouts before the 2014 GPE, consistently throwing his fastball 100 mph or more. The velocity made him one of the hardest throwers in GPE history as well as a candidate to become the first high school right-hander to go No. 1 overall. The ORGANIZATION ended up taking the 6-foot-5 Texan with the second pick of the GPE and signed him for $6 million, the largest bonus in franchise history. He is capable of getting heavy sinking life on his fastball, resulting in lots of ground-ball outs. Both PERSON's slider and changeup are below average and limit his bat-missing ability, although he did make strides with the former during instructional league, throwing it with improved depth and power. Once he returns from surgery, PERSON will have a ways to go with his control and command, but the ORGANIZATION believe both should improve as he becomes more comfortable repeating his delivery. He might not be as advanced as initially thought at the time of the GPE, but the size, stuff and arm strength still gives him top-of-the-rotation potential.

PERSON has shown impressive feel for a deep arsenal since signing with the ORGANIZATION out of GPE for $220,000 in 2012. The ORGANIZATION took notice of the right-hander's development and acquired him from GPE as part of the ORGANIZATION deal at the ORGANIZATION in 2015. After rising through PERSON's system, PERSON made his big league debut as a reliever in April 2017, his first of six bullpen appearances with the ORGANIZATION. He was back in the big leagues as a reliever in 2018 but otherwise spent much of the season in Triple-A PERSON's rotation. In November, the ORGANIZATION dealt PERSON to the GPE for PERSON. PERSON operates in the low 90s with late life but shows consistent plus velocity in shorter bursts. His changeup is a plus pitch as well as his best secondary weapon, one he throws against hitters on both sides of the plate, and he's adept at mixing in a legitimate palmball. PERSON also has a curveball and a slider, the latter flashing above-average potential with cutter action.Though he lacks physical projection, PERSON has proved plenty durable as a starter throughout his career and has the versatility to bounce between roles. PERSON should be given the chance to start in the Majors on the merits of his pitch mix, above-average control and durability. Should that not work out, he should have no problem becoming an effective long reliever given his ability to work multiple frames.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 4, 2017 - PERSON, GPEFavorite MLB Team: GPE ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON, a Saint Mary's commit, has been a staple of ORGANIZATION since he was selected onto the 2013 14U ORGANIZATION Development Program roster. And in 2016, PERSON had a stellar outing while playing for PERSON in the event's second game. He pitched 1.2 innings, giving up no hits and recording four strikeouts in his team's 6-3 loss to the ORGANIZATION. The strong-bodied right-hander has arm strength and is quick out front. He impresses scouts with a 90-92 mph fastball that sneaks up on hitters and pairs the heater with a curveball and an occasional slider. He has the look of a reliever and has the ability to continue to develop.
GPE has pro bloodlines, plus speed and athleticism and some offensive potential.

The ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON 28th overall in 2013, taking him nine picks after they selected PERSON lefty PERSON. The ORGANIZATION prep product dazzled during his first full season at ORGANIZATION A Peoria and then built on that success in 2015 at ORGANIZATION A Advanced Palm Beach, where he was leading the ORGANIZATION State League in ERA when PERSON dealt him to GPE for PERSON at the ORGANIZATION. PERSON logged just two starts with his new organization before landing on the disabled list with a sore lower back, and he's already landed on the shelf twice in 2016 during his time with Double-A Akron. Though he's always been a steady performer, PERSON's stuff has been on the decline since the start of 2015. His fastball sits at 86-92 mph with decent arm-side run and sink, and he shows feel for adding and subtracting with the pitch. His plus curveball isn't as sharp as it once was but it still represents the left-hander's best pitch, thrown with 12-to-6 shape and downer action. However, the southpaw dialed back its usage last season as he lost feel for the pitch, and it in turn caused him to rely too heavily on his changeup and below-average slider.PERSON's advanced command allows him to throw strikes with his entire repertoire, and he compensates for his lack of height by creating some downhill plan from a high three-quarters release point. Although the Indians love his competitiveness and high baseball IQ on the mound, they want him to throw his curveball more often moving forward.

In the first 51 years of the GPE, only eight high school second basemen have been selected in the first or the supplemental first round. The most recent is PERSON, who went 35th overall in 2014 and earned a $2 million bonus because he offered one of the best bat and speed combinations in that year's crop. Both of those tools translated immediately to pro ball, as PERSON hit .295 with 43 steals in 144 games against much older competition during his first two pro seasons, though his numbers have declined in high Class A this year. He has an advanced feel for hitting and and hits line drives to all fields, but his command of the strike zone hasn't been as strong as usual in 2016. While PERSON is not a big guy, he has impressive bat speed and could develop double-digit home run power once he matures physically.PERSON's well-above-average speed makes him dangerous on the bases, though he's still learning the nuances of stealing. The biggest concern with him remains his arm, which hasn't bounced all the way back since he had surgery to repair a torn labrum in 2011. The Rockies are confident that PERSON's arm will be playable and that he can become an average defender at second base, with center field a possible fallback.

As a high school underclassman, GPE looked like a hit-first tweener outfielder. He added a bunch of good weight and strength and had significantly more raw power when he arrived in the ORGANIZATION after signing. He has already begun trading a little bit of contact for significantly more game power. With added mass and strength typically comes a reduction in straight line speed, but GPE hasn't slowed down just yet and still looks like a possibility to stay in center, though most scouts who saw him in pro ball think he'll eventually move to left field. Regardless, there's a whole lot more bat here than there was on our pre-draft evaluation of GPE, who has risen to the top of the promising teenage hitter group in this system because he has a chance to hit for average and power while the rest are likely to do just one of those.

PERSON was released by the ORGANIZATION in June 2013, just one year after they had signed him out of the ORGANIZATION. He signed with the ORGANIZATION the following month but required surgery in the fall to repair a fracture in his right elbow, costing PERSON all of 2014. The ORGANIZATION added PERSON to their 40-man roster in November, and he returned to the LOCATION in 2017. PERSON generates easy plus velocity with his lightning-quick arm, sitting at 93-95 mph and touching higher at times. His above-average slider complements his fastball nicely, and the pairing enabled him to rack up 66 strikeouts in 53 total innings last season, during which he held hitters to a .116 average. PERSON also throws a splitter, giving him a chance against left-handed hitters. PERSON's control is below average, especially when it comes to his fastball, though much of that is tied to his inexperience. With improvement on that front, PERSON, whom the ORGANIZATION added to their 40-man roster in November, could reach the big leagues in 2017.

PERSON was an intriguing two-way prospect as a Miami high schooler, though his lackluster performance on the showcase circuit seemingly had him destined to attend PERSON A&M. Then his velocity shot up shortly before the 2014 Draft, and his 96-97 mph radar-gun readings earned him a second-round selection and an $833,900 bonus.PERSON usually operates in the low 90s with his running fastball, and his athletic delivery and slender build with room to add strength hint at more consistent velocity down the road. His secondary pitches are all works in progress, though he shows some depth to his curveball and some feel for his changeup.The Cardinals are excited to see how PERSON will progress in his first full year focusing solely on pitching. His frame is smaller than desired for a starter, but he throws with little effort and does a good job of filling the strike zone.

GPE may have posted the second-worst ORGANIZATION (4.69) of his career in 2016, but his year didn't lack positives. He worked a career-high 134 1/3 innings, ranked third in the Triple-A PERSON in strikeouts (122) despite not arriving there until mid-May and would have placed second in whiff rate (10.2 per nine innings) if he hadn't fallen just short of enough innings to qualify. He continued to build on that progress in 2017 -- until he received a season-ending suspension on July 1 after testing positive for performance-enhancing drugs.GPE's fastball sits at 91-94 mph and peaks at 96, but it's much nastier than its velocity alone would indicate. He's 6-foot-7 and his long levers give him great extension and create a difficult plane and angle when he keeps his delivery in sync. His secondary pitches lack reliability, though his mid-80s slider is solid at times and his fringy changeup is improving.San Francisco still envisions GPE as a starter, and he'll need to refine his changeup, control and command to succeed in that role in the big leagues. He could make for a very dynamic reliever, giving hitters an unusual look while theoretically adding more velocity in shorter stints.

On pure ability, PERSON could have been a first-round pick in the 2012 Draft. But he had an enigmatic high school career, allowing the ORGANIZATION to sign him in the second round for a slightly below-slot $500,000. Their system features several high-ceiling position players, and he has been the most consistently productive of the bunch. PERSON was turning in perhaps the best season of his career when he was included as part of the package sent to GSP in return for PERSON' lightning-fast hands and his strength allow him to drive almost any pitch he can reach. After swinging at just about every pitch that didn't bounce -- and some that did -- during his first three pro seasons, he has made impressive strides with his plate discipline in 2015. With moderate patience, he could be a force at the plate when he reaches the big leagues.PERSON has solid speed, though he doesn't always get the most out of it on the bases and in the field. He runs and throws well enough to play all three outfield positions but has spent most of his pro career in left field.

PERSON was expected to serve as ORGANIZATION's Friday night starter until a preseason oblique suffered during a bullpen session prior to Opening Day wiped out his entire junior season. While the ORGANIZATION still took a flyer on him in the 26th round in June, it appeared that the two sides were unable to strike a deal prior to the July 7 signing deadline. It later was revealed, however, that PERSON actually had submitted its $605,000 deal with PERSON nearly five minutes after the deadline had passed, and a corresponding investigation by PERSON determined that the signing was valid because the parties agreed to a contract before the deadline. He spent most of his pro debut with PERSON, pitching to a 0.78 ERA with 38 strikeouts in 35 innings, and continued to impress with PERSON in 2018. A 6-foot-4, 215-pound left-hander, PERSON can run his fastball up to 95 mph, albeit with little feel for where it's going. He features a pair of breaking balls in a curveball and slider, both of which currently grade as fringe-average but stand to improve with experience. The same can be said for his changeup, too. PERSON's feel for pitching leaves quite a bit to be desired, though he did make gains with both his control and command in his first full season. He has the raw components needed to stick as a starter at the next level, as well as the pure arm strength to become a late-inning reliever should that not work out.

Undrafted out of high school and sidelined for most of his sophomore year at FACILITY with a broken wrist, PERSON put himself on the prospect map with an all-star performance in the ORGANIZATION in the summer of 2014. He built on that momentum in 2015, topping ORGANIZATION Division I in runs (88), hits (106), total bases (188) and slugging (.749) while ranking second in hitting (.422). Signed for $1.7 million as a GPE second-round pick that June, he had a solid 2016 season at two Class A stops before GPE traded him to the Royals in February for PERSON has excellent feel for the barrel and should hit for average with his compact left-handed swing and line-drive approach. He's not a big guy, but he does have bat speed and the ball jumps off his bat. If he can control the strike zone as well as he did in college -- he fanned just 16 times in 60 games in 2015 -- he could be a .280 hitter with 15 homers per year.PERSON' plus speed gives him the ability to steal bases and chase down balls in center field. He played mostly left field in his pro debut, deferring to 2015 first-rounder PERSON when they broke into pro ball together at ORGANIZATION, but should get regular time in center this year. PERSON' only glaring weakness is his well below-average arm.

PERSON started asking about PERSON in trade talks shortly after he made his GPE debut last June. He played in just 15 games before a pitch broke his left wrist, but that was long enough for him to draw comparisons to PERSON. One club official said PERSON has the highest ceiling of any ORGANIZATION middle-infield prospect since PERSON's top-of-the-scale speed is his standout tool, allowing him to run wild on the bases and cover plenty of ground at shortstop. He's not just a slappy hitter, as he has the wiry strength to drive balls into the gaps. He needs to make more consistent contact but shows a willingness to draw walks.When PERSON signed for $225,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in 2012, there were some concerns about his arm strength. It has improved significantly and now rates as a plus, and there's no reason he should have to move off shortstop.

Scouting grades: Hit: 60 | Power: 50 | Run: 30 | Arm: 60 | Field: 55 | Overall: 60ORGANIZATION won the PERSON as college baseball's best two-way player in each of his first two seasons at ORGANIZATION after turning down the ORGANIZATION as a 34th-rounder out of high school, and he's a lock to do so again after dominating more than ever this spring. He's a potential No. 1 overall pick, though clubs are still split as to whether he'll be better as a hitter or a pitcher. The 2017 ORGANIZATION player of the year is a consensus top-10-overall choice either way, the first player regarded that highly since PERSON in 1973.ORGANIZATION usually opens games on the mound by working with a 90-94 mph fastball that loses a couple ticks of velocity by the middle innings. He could add more velo and maintain it better if he focused on pitching full-time, and his fastball command is so good that his heater is effective in the upper 80s. ORGANIZATION's curveball is a consistent plus pitch and he's working on refining a changeup that he hasn't needed much to this point in his career.ORGANIZATION's smooth left-handed swing and mature all-fields approach helped him lead the GPE college national team in hitting (.326) and on-base percentage (.434) last summer. Some evaluators consider him the best college bat in the ORGANIZATION and he's hitting for more power this year, showing the upside of a .300 hitter with 20 homers per season. His lack of speed limits him to first base, where he could become a solid defender with more work.

Over the course of multiple Drafts, the ORGANIZATION aggressively went after high-risk, high-reward high school pitching in later rounds. GPE was one of those picks, given an above-slot deal in 2010. He might be the first from that crop to impact the big league rotation.At first glance, it might be easy to put the "mid-rotation" label on GPE, but there might be more than meets the eye. He has more velocity on his fastball, hitting the mid 90s regularly, than the typical command-and-control starter. GPE's changeup has improved so much that it might be his second-best offering, and his curve gives him three Major League average or better pitches in his repertoire.It all comes from GPE's big 6-foot-5 frame and clean delivery. He has improved every year that he's been with the ORGANIZATION, and he is poised to knock on the door in 2014.

The top-rated international prospect during the 2013-14 signing period, PERSON signed with the ORGANIZATION for $2.8 million out of the ORGANIZATION. He emerged as one of baseball's best prospects in 2016, when he starred at the ORGANIZATION All-Star PERSON in GPE, topped the ORGANIZATION in slugging (.532) and ORGANIZATION (.901) and won the Class A circuit's ORGANIZATION award at age 19. Traded to the FACILITY Sox the following July as the headliner in a four-prospect package for PERSON, he has kicked his game up a notch further and been slowed only by pectoral and adductor strains in 2018.PERSON has few peers among prospects when it comes to hitting for average and power. His massive raw pop, generated with impressive bat speed and leverage from the right side of the plate, earns him comparisons to PERSON. He recognizes pitches well, makes savvy adjustments, doesn't try to do too much and is making progress with his plate discipline.Though PERSON may not offer much beyond his bat, he still can become a superstar. As he has gotten bigger and stronger, he has slowed and now has below-average speed. His arm strength also has regressed and he recorded just six assists in his first four pro seasons, so he now projects as a fringy left fielder.

PERSON pitched just 7 2/3 innings as a GPE freshman in 2015 before emerging as the closer for the ORGANIZATION and the GPE collegiate national team as a sophomore. Though he missed six weeks with a sore arm last spring, he continued to excel in the late innings and earned a slightly over-slot $390,000 bonus as a FACILITY fifth-rounder. He pitched well in his pro debut and converted both of his save opportunities in low Class A before tiring in the final two weeks.PERSON works off a fastball that ranges from 92-97 mph and tops out at 100, compensating for modest life by usually locating it well down in the strike zone. He backs up his heater with a low-80s slider that features nice bite at its best but also gets slurvy at times. He also has a fringy changeup that he may dust off more often after left-handers batted .341 against him in his first taste of pro ball.Some scouts who saw PERSON as an amateur thought he had the three-pitch mix and athleticism to make it as a starter, but GPE plans to fast-track him as a reliever. How quickly he moves will depend on his control and command, which were less reliable in his debut than they were in college. He has closer upside but will need more consistency to get there.

Sometimes repeating a level can do wonders for a prospect's career. Case in point is PERSON, who had to go back to the GPE League after scuffling there in 2015. The former ORGANIZATION farmhand, who came to the D-backs in the three-team trade that sent PERSON to the ORGANIZATION, hit his way out of the level in 2016 and kept on performing well in Double-A, all at the age of 20. However, his progress was slowed in 2017 by a shoulder injury that kept him out of action for a couple of months. PERSON excels with an innate ability to find the barrel of the bat, especially from the left side of the plate. He's a free swinger with tremendous hand-eye coordination, but one of the keys to his step forward last season was improved plate discipline and a better walk rate. That allowed him to increase his extra-base output, and he could eventually be a 10-12 home run kind of hitter. PERSON has played more shortstop than anywhere else since joining the organization and can make all the plays there. He's also shown the ability to play a more-than-capable second base. PERSON raised the bar a bit following his first full season in the organization but didn't get to replicate it because of injury in 2017. He still has the potential to be an everyday shortstop, but he could also move around to create more opportunities to get his bat into the lineup once he's ready for the big leagues.

PERSON entered the 2012 season as a candidate to go No. 1 overall in the draft, but a slump dropped him to the ORGANIZATION at the 24th pick. As a rare college shortstop talented enough to play there in the big leagues, he commanded a $2.05 million bonus. He has played as advertised in pro ball, shining with his glove while showing inconsistency with his bat.PERSON has all the tools and instincts necessary to win a ORGANIZATION at shortstop. He has smooth actions, reads balls off the bat well, has range to both sides and can make any throw from any angle. He's reliable, too, making just 27 errors in 249 games during his first three pro seasons.His bat remains a question mark after PERSON followed a .291/.371/.433 first half in Double-A last year by hitting .210/.260/.285 in Triple-A. While he'll probably hit at the bottom of a big league batting order, he does have some wiry strength for gap power and the patience to draw a few walks. He's a savvy baserunner with average speed.

One look at PERSON, a 6-foot-6 right-hander, and you think "durable starting pitcher." His inconsistencies on the mound, however, make some wonder if that's ultimately his best role, though he did make his big league debut as a starter in 2015.PERSON did shake off a slow start in his first taste of Triple-A in 2014 to finish the season well, but it left some question marks. PERSON's fastball has enough velocity, sitting in the low 90s and touching more than that at times. He throws it with good downward angle and sink when he's on, though he's up in the zone more than he should be. His changeup is his best secondary offering, with his slider coming in a close third. Both have the chance to be PERSON average, but again, he struggles to throw them consistently well. PERSON doesn't hurt himself with walks, but his command within the strike zone has hurt him. He'll continue to get work as a starter, but his fastball might play better in short relief, long-term.

PERSON was a big-time football recruit in high school, and he appeared intent on heading to ORGANIZATION to play quarterback and pitch. In a stunning move, GPE was able to sign him away from PERSON, with a franchise-record bonus at the GPE signing deadline in 2010.PERSON has moved through the ORGANIZATION quickly, first reaching Double-A Chattanooga as a 20-year-old. He has four pitches that project as GPE League-average or better offerings. PERSON's fastball sits in the low 90s, with good sink. He throws two breaking balls, and he has a good feel for his changeup.PERSON's loose easy delivery allows him to command all of his pitches well. That command and his advanced pitchability help him miss bats, despite not having a dominant offspeed offering. PERSON projects as solid middle-of-the-rotation starter, and he could get a chance soon in GPE.

For a 16-year-old, high bonus pitcher, PERSON was a rarity in a number of ways. Since he defected from GPE, he had a pretty long track record of high-level international competition. He pitched as a 14-year-old for the 15-and-under GPE team, and posted a 69 IP, 32 H, 2 XBH, 20 BB, 102 K line. Then, at 15 years old, he pitched for the 18-and-under team and posted a 21 IP, 16 H, 4 BB, 25 K line. He also struck out five of the six batters he faced in the ORGANIZATION showcase in February, which is the linked video. On top of that, PERSON flashes four above average to plus pitches, has hit 97 mph and has starter-caliber feel to pitch. He's also 6-foot-3 and 205 pounds, and has some room to add muscle. If you're looking for things to nitpick, there's some effort to his delivery that should be ironed out, and he does vary his arm slot, though it's by choice. The ORGANIZATION will try to limit him to two breaking balls and one slot, but recognize that PERSON could be one of those rare pitchers like PERSON who can be effective throwing the kitchen sink from a half dozen different arm slots. Going back to what's rare about PERSON, he seems to have it all, except for maybe an ideal present delivery and, obviously, stateside pro performance. This is about as high as we can rank a teenage pitching prospect who has only been seen a handful of times and hasn't really faced many hitters who can handle his stuff, but there's lots of room to grow on this 40+ FV if this trajectory continues.

There are college pitchers who are labeled as "performers," those whose numbers are better than their pure stuff would indicate they're capable of. Then there are hurlers whose stuff is actually better than the stats they put up. PERSON, who served as PERSON's Saturday starter in 2018, fits into the second category.PERSON has four pitches, all of which he is capable of throwing for strikes. He'll throw his fastball in the 90-94 mph range and he'll back it up with a pair of breaking balls. He'll throw a curve 79-82 mph and will also mix in a mid-80s slider that has cutter-like action to it. His 83-85 mph changeup gives him a fourth at least PERSON average offering. While his command hasn't been pinpoint, he is generally around the strike zone.PERSON's ceiling is that of a No. 4 or 5 starter at the next level, though he did put up better numbers largely as a reliever as a sophomore. For him to go in the top five or so rounds, teams will have to look past his numbers and have a feel that his stuff will play in a professional rotation.

The Cardinals have lately added a number of third basemen via the GPE, or at least players who played the position as amateurs. It's quite possible GPE is the one who has the best chance of being an everyday third baseman in the big leagues. He could be above-average defensively, with a very strong arm. He has below-average speed, but he's not a clogger on the bases, and that might help him range-wise as well. There's some pop in the ORGANIZATION's product's bat, and he should be able to hit enough to tap into that power fairly consistently. With PERSON already moving to the outfield, GPE could be the most advanced player at the hot corner in the system.

PERSON' age on draft day likely buoyed his stock among teams that rely heavily on models to build their draft board, as models tend to move younger players up the pref list. Not only was PERSON younger than most of his high school prospect peers, but potential shortstops with plus bat speed aren't often available past the draft's first few picks. Though his swing -- both the bat path and his footwork -- may need tweaks in pro ball, PERSON is capable of clearing his hips and unloading on pitches on the inner half. He struggles to make impact contact on pitches in other parts of the strike zone, but his hands have promising explosion and could yield all-fields doubles power with refinement. On defense, PERSON has plus infield actions, he's a 55 runner with sufficient middle infield range, and he has a chance to be a 50 glove at shortstop. His bat would play everyday at second and short if the ORGANIZATION get the swing dialed in. If they don't, he profiles as a good utility infielder.

It's not uncommon for a young catching prospect to be moved out from behind the plate to another position in order to let his bat develop. That prospect then moving back to his original position? Now that's a little more unique, but that's exactly what's happening with PERSON.Moved to right field for his full-season debut, PERSON regressed offensively compared to his first two summers of pro ball. He has tremendous raw power, but he wasn't able to tap into it with any consistency, striking out almost 36 percent of the time while in the ORGANIZATION. He did make some adjustments when he was sent back down to short-season ball. That move was made also to allow him to get back behind the plate. He has excellent arm strength, but there's work to be done on the other aspects of his defensive game. The D-backs are hopeful hitting the reset button and seeing some signs of life late in 2014 is a harbinger of things to come for PERSON, with a power profile they hope will play whether he can stick behind the plate or move back to right field.

ORGANIZATION used PERSON exclusively as a reliever on teams that went to the ORGANIZATION World Series finals in 2014 and 2015 (winning it all in his freshman year), and he dominated out of the bullpen while earning co-playoff ORGANIZATION honors in the ORGANIZATION in the latter summer. The ORGANIZATION tried him as a starter at the beginning of his junior season before shifting him back to the bullpen as a closer. The ORGANIZATION eased him into pro ball in short stints after signing him for $1.6 million as a second-rounder.As a lefty with three pitches and a durable frame, PERSON has the ingredients to pitch in the middle of a big league rotation. His 90-95 mph fastball plays up because it has late life and steep downhill plane. He also shows feel for a sinking changeup and has a three-quarters breaking ball that fluctuates between a low-80s slider and a high-70s curveball.Colorado is still undecided about PERSON's long-term role. Though he could move quickly as a possible high-leverage reliever, he also has mid-rotation potential and a fresh arm that logged just 96 1/3 innings in three seasons at ORGANIZATION. His control and command improved steadily during his college career, but to make it as a starter he'll have to show that he can maintain a quality fastball into the late innings.

PERSON has impressed scouts with his raw power and arm strength since high school. Defensively, he should be OK at first base, and when he was an amateur, some teams asked to see him in an outfield corner, something that could be revisited. PERSON racked up 40 saves during his four years at ORGANIZATION and dominated for two summers on the Cape before signing with the ORGANIZATION as a 10th-round pick in 2017. PERSON' fastball is below-average from a velocity standpoint, sitting mostly in the upper 80s, but he consistently gets it past hitters thanks to deception created by his low arm slot. Said slot gives his effective slider broad sweeping action, while his changeup drops off the table as it approaches the plate. The change is the better secondary offering, one that receives above-average grades from scouts, and was instrumental in him holding left-handed hitters to a .167/.254/.294 clip in 2018. He's an adept strike-thrower with all three pitches, demonstrating above-average control and command against hitters on both sides of the plate.But perhaps what's most intriguing about PERSON is that he can induce whiffs with relative ease. Working 66 2/3 innings in his first full season, he struck out 37 percent of the hitters he faced while averaging 13 strikeouts-per-nine. PERSON doesn't fit into a neat box as a big league reliever, but there's something to be said about his sustained dominance, and it would surprise no one in the organization if he continued his accelerated climb towards the Majors.

Former big leaguer PERSON has done a tremendous job since he took over as head coach of GPE Canyon University, moving the school from ORGANIZATION II to a successful ORGANIZATION I program and seeing eight of his players get drafted along the way. None of them has been taken before the ninth round, but GPE, who moved from the bullpen as a freshman to the Friday night starter the last two years, should easily surpass his predecessors.GPE has a solid enough three-pitch mix that he should be given every opportunity to start. He will throw his fastball in the 90-94 range, sitting around 92-94 consistently, while occasionally touching 96 mph occasionally. His fastball has been fairly true without a ton of deception to it this spring, so he does get hit at times more than you'd think. His changeup might be the better secondary offering. He sells it well with arm speed, some arm side fade, showing more deception with that than he does his fastball. His slider is average, with some late break to it.GPE throws strikes and has a solid feel for pitching, which gives him a chance to start. He did pitch out of the bullpen while on the GPE, with an uptick in velocity, providing a solid backup plan. But a team taking the right-hander in the top few rounds will see him as a future member of a rotation.

On a very deep ORGANIZATION of GPE staff, PERSON has carved out a niche as a very effective college closer. But the right-hander might have the stuff to start and a team taking him in the opening few rounds might give him every chance to do so.Out of the bullpen, PERSON is up to 95 mph with his fastball. But he has a four-pitch mix that could work out of a rotation. In back of that fastball, PERSON throws a hard curve/slider hybrid in the low 81-83 mph range, a cutter that sits around 86-88 mph and a low-80s changeup. He tends to be around the plate.PERSON did give some a glimpse of what he looks like as a starter in the ORGANIZATION last summer. Gators starters like A.J. PERSON and PERSON might go ahead of PERSON, but his potential in a rotation could see him come off the board not long after.

The ORGANIZATION lost a pair of outfield prospects in the 2015 Rule 5 Draft in PERSON, whom the ORGANIZATION selected with the ORGANIZATION. 1 pick, and PERSON. Originally a ninth-round Draft pick out of GPE in 2012, PERSON was left off the ORGANIZATION' 40-man roster in spite of a breakout 2015 campaign in which he hit .321/.427/.447 with 38 extra-base hits and 23 steals across three levels, finishing the year in Triple-A.A right-handed hitter, PERSON has a short, quick swing that yields a lot of contact, and he does a good job of using the whole field. His on-base skills have improved as he's moved up the ladder, thanks to a mature approach and advanced feel for the strike zone, and he knows how to use his plus speed when he gets on.PERSON's speed also makes him a rangy defender in the outfield, and he's capable of playing all three positions. PERSON was the consensus top prep arm in the class this summer, dominating hitters and peaking with PERSON in the fall. At that point, PERSON was commanding a lively 93-96 mph heater, a new, but already plus slider and at least and average changeup that he didn't need much. He returned over a month later and has been good down the stretch, peaking at 97 mph in multiple open workouts for scouts after his school was eliminated from the playoffs. He still hasn't shown the promise from the summer, as he's completely lost feel for his slider. He only threw the pitch in games this spring a handful of times and scouts speculated it made his arm hurt, but he threw it in some of the postseason workouts and simply had no feel for the pitch anymore.

The curveball that replaced it is similar to PERSON's curveball and is often a 45 or 50, maybe a 55 once a start but not often enough to project it as such. He's healthy, teams are clearing his medical and the arm speed is back, but his frame is now maxed-out and it's unclear where his breaking ball went and if it will come back. He's seen as very signable and the team that takes him will be banking on him returning to form; we've assumed there's a little more slider feel that will be teased out but not the 60 pitch of the summer.

The son of former ORGANIZATION player PERSON, this 6-foot-6 right-hander was delayed in the start of his senior season because of his own high school basketball exploits. He was rushing up ORGANIZATION boards as the spring progressed.A premium athlete, PERSON uses every inch of his frame to his advantage on the mound. Though he started late because his basketball team made a deep postseason run, PERSON was nonetheless up to 96-97 mph with his fastball in early outings. He combines that with hard, power curve that has very good bite to it. His changeup will be his third pitch, but he's shown some feel for it and it should be a viable option in the future. PERSON's size, athleticism, stuff and projectability had decision-makers rushing in to see him in GPE. The ORGANIZATION commit has risen to close to the top of the high school pitching list and could very well hear his name called in the first round.

PERSON entered his senior year of high school as a talented two-sport project with a, having size and arm speed, but inconsistent command, offspeed stuff, and somewhat strange east/west elements to his delivery. His superior athleticism shone through in the spring, along with improved direction to the plate, and the ORGANIZATION popped him ninth overall in 2016 with an eye toward PERSON becoming a frontline starter. 
Early in pro ball, PERSON had some real trouble with strike-throwing, then slowly settled in. He has two easy plus pitches in his fastball and curveball, but his changeup is almost always below average, and his command comes and goes. His fastball plays up due to his excellent extension, but he gets so much extension that he overstrides and it reduces the amount of feel he has, both in his changeup and command. If PERSON can dial down the aggression in his delivery a bit, the starter traits should come to the forefront and give the ORGANIZATION a No. 2 or 3 starter.

PERSON doesn't have premium stuff, but his results since being drafted in the 20th round in 2011 have forced evaluators to take note of him. When healthy, PERSON succeeds without overpowering stuff thanks to his deceptive delivery, command and pitchability. He hides the ball well and throws from a low arm slot, making it tough for hitters to pick up the ball. His fastball sits around 90 mph and he mixes in a short slider and changeup. PERSON has exclusively worked as a starter in the ORGANIZATION, scouts have long felt he might fit better in the bullpen. That's where he's likely to get his chance to stick with the ORGANIZATION, once he gets back on the mound.

PERSON flashed promise but lacked consistency during his three years in UNC-Greensboro's starting rotation. The ORGANIZATION acquired PERSON and PERSON last ORGANIZATIONvember in exchange for 2014 first-rounder (ORGANIZATION. 6 overall pick) PERSON, and he made his big league debut in June after a strong start to his season in Double-A.A towering presence on the mound, PERSON uses his 6-foot-8 frame to create a steep downhill plane to the plate and generate weak ground balls. He pitches with an average fastball, sitting at 90-92 mph and touching 94 with his heater, though it tends to play up because he hides the ball and gets good extension over his front side. PERSON's changeup is his best secondary pitch and receives above-average grades from scouts, and he also can flash average with a curveball that has a big 12-to-6 shape but inconsistent pace.PERSON is athletic for his size and repeats his delivery well. He projects to have at least average control and command of his three-pitch mix, giving him the potential to develop into a ORGANIZATION. 4 starter.

It's possible PERSON would have been PERSON's best everyday option at catcher toward the end of last year, but a desperate need for pitching depth facilitated his trade to PERSON for PERSON. PERSON is an athletic catcher with a plus arm, average receiving skills, and some feel to hit. After struggling to perform with the bat during the first several years of his career, PERSON has two straight season of league-average offensive performance at ORGANIZATION and Triple-A. He has a pull-and-lift style of hitting, but not enough raw power to optimize that kind of approach. He's a safe bet to be a quality backup and has a non-zero chance to hit a little more than we expect and be a low-end regular.

ORGANIZATION fans should get ready for another GPE to pitch in GPE very soon. PERSON is the nephew of former big leaguer PERSON, who spent several years pitching for the ORGANIZATION. He's knocking on the door, having reached Triple-A in 2012, though he missed considerable time with injuries. When he was on the mound, he continued to show tremendous stuff while developing a better feel for pitching. The arm strength has always been there and GPE shows a plus fastball, up to 96-97 mph. There's some sink to it as well and he gets a good amount of ground-ball outs as a result. He throws both a slider and a curve. The curve is better, especially when he stays on top it, throwing it with tight spin. The slider has a cutter action to it and both it and his changeup have the chance to be average pitches. If his command can continue to improve, he has the chance to contribute as a starter. If not, he'll definitely contribute out of the bullpen.

PERSON doesn't have as much experience playing center field as you'd expect for a 65 to 70 runner from GPE that's played on some solid teams domestically and internationally. He played in the corners in deference to more experienced defenders and also played a good bit of first base in GPE to save his arm, since he also pitched. Like most GPE defectors, he's cleaned up his frame a bit since leaving the island and also added more speed and power. PERSON should be able to stick in center, but he just hasn't been seen playing the position in many games recently, though he has enough arm for right field if for some reason he needs to slide to a corner. There's power for 15-18 homers, but it'll likely play lower than that with his more contact-focused approach; most scouts I spoke with hanging a 50 on his bat and a 45 on his game power (12-15 homers), easily projecting him as an everyday player if he sticks in center as expected. It isn't the most electric, toolsy GPE prospect in recent memory, but it's roughly comparable to PERSON, with less raw power. PERSON is a good bit younger than PERSON and will get far less due to some uncertainty about his skills and the limits of the international pools. The ORGANIZATION and ORGANIZATION have shown the most interest after PERSON's camp decided to wait for the next signing period, though it sounds like the ORGANIZATION made an attempt to sign him at the end of the last period.

PERSON didn't pitch as a sophomore at ORGANIZATION (GPE) JC, then transferred to PERSON and set the ORGANIZATION' single-season (19) and career (27) saves records, surpassing current Pirates shortstop PERSON in the latter category. A $1,000 senior sign by the Athletics in the 22nd round of the 2014 Draft, PERSON recorded a 1.37 ERA in his first two years as a pro and saved 27 games in his first full season while reaching Double-A. He reached Triple-A in his first year in the ORGANIZATION' system after being acquired in a trade for PERSON, but he drew a 50-game suspension in the offseason after testing positive for a stimulant.PERSON may be small (5-foot-10, 170 pounds) and possess below-average fastball velocity, but he is effective because he's extremely deceptive, mixes four pitches and locates them where he wants. His fastball maxes out at 93 mph, but hitters don't punish it because it features good life and he works it to both sides of the plate and down in the strike zone. His best offering is his solid curveball, and he also can get swings and misses with his average slider and changeup.Throwing from a variety of arm slots to keep hitters off-balance, PERSON has dominated left-handers as well as right-handers. He's a good bet to become at least a middle reliever in the big leagues and could ascend to that role in 2016.

PERSON may have come off the board earlier in the 2014 Draft if not for a bout of forearm tightness that sidelined him for three weeks as a high school senior. The ORGANIZATION were thrilled to find him still available with the 30th-overall pick, and then signed him for $1.75 million. PERSON rewarded the ORGANIZATION by dominating in his first two pro seasons and then reached Double-A at age 20 in 2016. However, it will now be up to the ORGANIZATION to further his development after they acquired PERSON and PERSON in the ORGANIZATION Lucroy-Jeremy Jeffress Trade Deadline blockbuster.PERSON combines stuff and feel better than most young pitchers. His strong build allows him to maintain his 92-97 mph fastball deep into ballgames, and his low-80s slider gives him a plus second pitch. PERSON threw his changeup sparingly as an amateur, but has developed it enough as a pro to where scouts view it as a potentially average pitch. Meanwhile, a clean and repeatable delivery has helped to make PERSON an accomplished strike-thrower early in his career.Much like GPE, PERSON impressed last summer in his brief ORGANIZATION debut, and he continued to do so in 2017, his first full year with the organization. He lacks projection in his physical 6-foot-3 frame and needs to stay healthy, but PERSON has both the stuff and command profile to develop into a No. 2 starter.

As PERSON was breaking out in 2014 in the upper levels of the ORGANIZATION' system, PERSON was doing the same in the lower levels. Making his professional debut, the 17-year-old excelled, first in the ORGANIZATION and then the GPE, where he was the third-youngest position player. He was having an impressive sophomore campaign, too, before he fractured his right thumb in GPE, prematurely ending his 2015 season.PERSON makes a lot of contact, thanks to his quick swing, excellent hand-eye coordination and innate feel for the barrel. He has a line-drive stroke and, while power will never be a part of his game, drives the gaps well. His above-average speed gives him all the tools to fit at the top of the order.PERSON has a strong arm, and scouts believe he has the skills necessary to remain at shortstop. The island of GPE has produced several talented middle infielders in recent years, and PERSON has a strong chance to continue the line.

The D-backs weren't able to land GSP out of high school in the 2011 Draft after taking him in the 33rd round, and the lefty went on to GPE PERSON and joined the ORGANIZATION as a 10th-rounder a year later. When the opportunity arose to bring GSP into the fold at the ORGANIZATION in 2014, the D-backs didn't miss a second time, getting the southpaw as part of the ORGANIZATION deal with PERSON. GSP blossomed with the D-backs and earned his first taste of the Majors in 2017, only to be traded for the second time in his career during the offseason when he was shipped to the ORGANIZATION in a three-team trade with the ORGANIZATION. GSP pitched across two levels, reaching Triple-A in 2016 while leading the organization in strikeouts and finishing second in ORGANIZATION, though he struggled to repeat those results in 2017, both in Triple-A and the ORGANIZATION. He has had success with a solid, if unspectacular, three-pitch mix, commanding all pitches fairly well. His fastball is above-average, thrown in the 90-95 mph range, and he's shown the ability to reach back for more when he needs it. His curveball has developed into a plus pitch and he has good feel for his changeup. When he's on his game, he executes his gameplan better than most.There could be more in the tank for GSP, an encouraging sign for a guy who already is on the cusp of a big league job. His 150- and 147 2/3-inning seasons in 2016-17 are a pretty good predictor of what kind of workhorse starter he is going to be in the big leagues.

PERSON has visible on-field leadership qualities and was the vocal protagonist of an ORGANIZATION club team that lost the league championship series to the ORGANIZATION. He's wiry and projectable but already strong, and he has present pull power that projects to plus. He also has plenty of arm for the left side of the infield and has seen time at short, but he almost certainly will move to third at some point, and there's a non-zero chance he ends up in right field. PERSON has some pitch recognition issues that lead to strikeouts. Those create uncertainty about his profile, but they'll be more acceptable if he can stay on the dirt. He could be an athletic, power-hitting corner bat in the big leagues so long as he hits a little bit.
GPE lefty with high effort delivery. Lives in the low-90s and has 40 command, but both the secondaries -- curveball and changeuup -- flash plus.

As a GPE high schooler, PERSON emerged as an early-round prospect for a handful of teams late in the 2016 Draft process. He ultimately turned down the ORGANIZATION as 30th-rounder to attend ORGANIZATION, where his father PERSON had played en route to a big league career. Much like former ORGANIZATION star PERSON, an GPE first-rounder in 2018, PERSON has confounded evaluators with the dichotomy between his success with metal bats (.939 ORGANIZATION, 42 homers in two-plus years with the ORGANIZATION) and struggles with wood (.570 ORGANIZATION, three homers in two summers in the ORGANIZATION).If scouts were convinced that PERSON will hit with wood, he'd likely be the first college shortstop drafted in June. A switch-hitter, he has some timing issues and a swing that tends to get long, leading to strikeouts. His strength and leverage already generate plus raw power, and he should have more as he fills out his lanky 6-foot-3 frame.There are no holes in the rest of PERSON's game. He produces solid to plus run times and uses his speed to steal a few bases and cover ground at shortstop. He's tall for the position but should be able to remain there with his athleticism and strong arm.
